record.title: Big Data
record.desc: Big data, coupled with analytics, can offer organizations impressive opportunities for improving efficiency and operations. Yet the possibilities for using big data to ask new business questions and meet market needs can be even more intriguing. How can big data provide the means for businesses to be more proactive?

record.title: Case Studies in Funding Innovation
record.desc: These five case studies in funding innovation look at the realities of what it takes for philanthropy to fund breakthrough social innovation and examine how organizations interested in nurturing innovation can better find and fund new ideas with the potential for outsized social impact.

record.title: Digital Transformation
record.desc: Digital transformation isn't driven by mastery of the technologies, but by the ability to articulate the value of digital technologies to an organization’s future. The capacity to digitally reimagine an organization is determined in large part by a clear digital strategy supported by leaders who foster a culture that embraces change.

record.title: The Future of the Tech, Media, and Telecom Industry
Moving Towards Value in Health Care
Smart Mobility
record.desc: This collection takes a data-driven look at what metropolitan areas can gain from four alternative mobility approaches—ridesharing, bike commuting, carsharing, and on-demand ride services—and explores ways that  governments can encourage their use.

record.title: The Exceptional Company
record.desc:
Also see:

» Three rules for success: Michael Raynor at TEDx University of Nevada (video) 

Deloitte Director Michael Raynor, co-author of the book "The Three Rules: How Exceptional Companies Think," discusses why the three rules for success work, especially when it is not obviously a good idea.

record.title: The Solution Economy
record.desc: In today’s new “solution economy,” solving social problems is becoming a multidisciplinary exercise that challenges businesses, governments, philanthropists, and social enterprises to think holistically about their role and their relation to others—not as competitors fighting over an ever-shrinking pie, but as potential collaborators looking to bake something fresh that serves as many stakeholders as possible.

record.title: Water
record.desc: In the past, businesses have generally viewed water as a minimal operational cost and not a strategic issue. However, water has now emerged as a critical economic, environmental, and social issue for both corporations and the public sector in response to increased water demand, climatic risks, and potentially negative impacts on brand value.

record.title: 3D Opportunity
record.desc: 3D printing—also known as additive manufacturing—offers organizations the ability to break performance trade-offs, reducing the capital required to achieve scope and/or economies of scale. If the past is prologue, the role that additive manufacturing plays in the manufacturing value chain will likely grow in scope, scale, and complexity.

record.title: Behavioral Economics and Management
record.desc: Behavioral economics is the study of how psychological, social, and emotional factors often conflict with and override economic incentives when people make decisions. When applied to management, behavioral economics can help us uncover ways to limit the organizational impact of biases and cognitive limitations—or ethically exploit them to help drive enterprise value.

record.title: Trends - Business Trends 2013
record.desc: Eight trends have the potential to upend long-held assumptions, energize strategic planning efforts, and fundamentally shift the business environment for individual companies or industries. Our Business Trends 2013 collection explores each and how to use it advantageously.

record.title: Building on the BRICs
record.sub-title: Redraw the global map of opportunity and competition
record.desc: As growth slows in the BRIC countries, multinationals from developed nations may find seven new emerging markets to hold enticing opportunities.
record.headline2: Redraw the global map of opportunity and competition

record.title: Emerging Market Talent Strategies
record.sub-title: Creating an effective global talent model
record.desc: Managing talent effectively in emerging markets takes a flexible approach that can help open the flow of ideas between markets and provide localized approaches.
record.headline2: Creating an effective global talent model

record.title: Manufacturing beyond China
record.sub-title: New options. New opportunities. New risks.
record.desc: While China’s role in manufacturing will likely remain significant, its future course may veer away from “factory to the world” toward “factory to China.”
record.headline2: New options. New opportunities. New risks.

record.title: Partnerships for the Future
record.desc: The growing complexity of social and economic challenges is driving new, innovative forms of collaboration between governments and businesses.

record.title: Preface to Business Trends 2013
record.desc: Read about eight trends that have the potential to upend long-held assumptions, energize strategic planning, and fundamentally shift the business environment for individual companies or industries.

record.title: Reengineering Business Intelligence
record.desc: Coupling social data with traditional internal and external data sets can offer the potential to generate near-real-time business insights.

record.title: The Responsible Enterprise
record.desc: Accelerating growth of corporate interest in ESG issues suggests that a new era of the responsible enterprise may be here to stay.

record.title: The Rewired Customer
record.desc: How can companies shape and sense consumers’ rapidly evolving modes of engagement—with retailers and with each other—to support future growth?

record.title: The Scale Paradox
record.desc: Disruptive technologies, combined with analytics, can help companies on both ends of the size spectrum overcome the historic limitations of smaller and larger scale.

record.title: Trends - Business Trends 2014
record.desc: “Business Trends 2014: Navigating the next wave of globalization” explores nine trends that are reshaping the business environment, driven by long-term, potentially irreversible, shifts in the global economy. Read the report and download the PDF.

record.title: Another billion
record.desc: Given economic and demographic change, global demand is shifting toward emerging markets. Reaching and serving “another billion” consumers may require companies to reach beyond existing strategies.

record.title: Anticipatory supply chains
record.desc: Supply chains are evolving into rich, data-intensive networks that not only perform efficiently and recover quickly from disruptions, but may also be able to spot and avert risks.

record.title: Business and social impact
record.desc: Growth will involve engaging with the social needs and complexities of emerging and frontier markets. These issues are no longer just the government’s responsibility, or purely philanthropic efforts.

record.title: The C-suite: Time for version 3.0?
record.desc: The next-generation C-suite must transcend functional boundaries to secure enhanced alignment and coherence, without defaulting back to the command-and-control arrangements of a bygone era.

record.title: CFO as Chief Frontier Officer
record.desc: CFOs are very well positioned to navigate and lead growth in new markets—given their abilities to manage risk, provide objective counsel, and bring analytical rigor to strategic choices.

record.title: City planet
record.desc: Companies will approach cities not only for market growth, but also as talent centers, innovation hubs, learning laboratories, and “proving grounds” for solutions to the world’s toughest problems.

record.title: Giants, old and new
record.desc: The field is set for a new, highly competitive game as firms from emerging markets with distinctive strengths take on longer-established corporations—which enjoy their own hard-won advantages.

record.title: Innovation from everywhere
record.desc: After centuries of near uni-directional innovation—from the West to the rest—we are in the early days of a massive rebalancing, aided by connective technologies. Innovation now happens everywhere.

record.title: Introduction
record.sub-title: Navigating the next wave of globalization
record.desc: New consumers. New collaborations. New leadership. How will the next wave of globalization impact your organization?
record.headline2: Navigating the next wave of globalization

record.title: Social business, global business
record.desc: As social media, technologies, and data become more broadly used within global companies, companies are building the processes and the organizational structure to grow globally as social businesses.

record.title: Trends - Business ecosystems come of age
record.desc:
Introduction

The notion of business ecosystems is now a crucial focal point for innovation, analysis, and strategic planning. Explore how organizations can thrive in a world of ecosystems by reading the report below,downloading the PDF,  and watching the video.

record.title: Beyond design thinking
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: Design thinking without deep analysis and synthesis can be reckless. Leading companies are seeking to do both recursively and in integrated new ways to manage complexity, derive insights, and catalyze innovation in fast-changing ecosystems.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: Blurring boundaries, uncharted frontiers
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: Long-standing boundaries and constraints that have traditionally determined the evolution of business are dissolving, allowing new ecosystem possibilities to flourish.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: Introduction: Business ecosystems come of age
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: Businesses are moving beyond traditional industry silos and coalescing into richly networked ecosystems, creating new opportunities for innovation alongside new challenges for many incumbent enterprises.
record.headline1: Introduction: Business ecosystems come of age
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: The new calculus of corporate portfolios
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: The rise of business ecosystems is compelling strategists to value assets according to an additional calculus, often generating different conclusions about what should be owned.
record.headline1: The new calculus of corporate portfolios
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: Minimum viable transformation
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: Leaders are taking lessons from the startup playbook on “minimum viable products” to launch minimum viable transformations—lightweight and readily adaptable versions of potential new business models.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: The power of platforms
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: Properly designed business platforms can help create and capture new economic value and scale the potential for learning across entire ecosystems.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: Regulating ecosystems
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: As ecosystems enable more rapid, cross-cutting innovation, regulators are challenged to create policies and solutions that protect the public’s interests and are also dynamic enough to keep pace with innovation.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: Supply chains and value webs
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: Supply chains are increasingly becoming value webs that span and connect whole ecosystems of suppliers and collaborators; properly activated, they can play a critical role in reshaping business strategy and delivering superior results.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: Wicked opportunities
record.sub-title: Part of the Business Trends series
record.desc: “Wicked problems”—ranging from malaria to dwindling water supplies—are being reframed as “wicked opportunities” and tackled by networks of non-governmental organizations, social entrepreneurs, governments, and big businesses.
record.headline2: Part of the Business Trends series

record.title: The Future of Mobility old
record.desc: Breakthroughs in self-driving cars are only the beginning: The entire way we travel from point A to point B is changing, creating a new ecosystem of personal mobility. The shift will likely affect far more than automakers—industries from insurance and health care to energy and media should reconsider how they create value in this emerging environment.

record.title: Industry 4.0 old
record.desc: The term Industry 4.0 encompasses a promise of a new industrial revolution—one that marries advanced manufacturing techniques with the Internet of Things to create manufacturing systems that are not only interconnected, but communicate, analyze, and use information to drive further intelligent action back in the physical world.

record.title: Industry 4.0 and the chemicals industry
record.sub-title: Catalyzing transformation through operations improvement and business growth
record.desc: Industry 4.0, which combines digital and physical advanced technologies, can potentially transform the chemicals industry, itself the backbone of many end-market industries. Through the dual areas of business operations and growth, these technologies enable “smart” supply chains and factories, as well as create new business models.
record.authors: Stefan Van Thienen|Andrew Clinton|Monica Mahto|Brenna Sniderman
record.headline2: Catalyzing transformation through operations improvement and business growth

record.title: Industry 4.0 and manufacturing ecosystems
record.sub-title: Exploring the world of connected enterprises
record.desc: The marriage of advanced manufacturing techniques with information technology, data, and analytics is driving another industrial revolution—one that invites manufacturing leaders to combine information technology and operations technology to create value in new and different ways.
record.headline2: Exploring the world of connected enterprises

record.title: Internet of Things
record.desc:
The Internet of Things puts digital information to work in the world.

Use the interactive graphic below to explore our insights on the IoT and how these insights connect to specific industries, business issues, roles, and essential concepts. Or scroll down for a complete list of articles. (On mobile devices, the interactive graphic will open in a new window.)

Learn more

» Discover: Deloitte's offerings around the Internet of Things at Deloitte.com

» Watch: The IoT and the new economics of creating and capturing value (video)

Deloitte Director Michael Raynor discusses how companies have been able to innovate their methods of value generation through information in his keynote address at the IoT Solutions World Conference in Barcelona, Spain.

» Watch: Strategy and the Internet of Things (video)

Deloitte Director Michael Raynor explains how the Internet of Things will transform value creation and what it means for value capture in his keynote address at the TM Forum in Nice, France.

» Subscribe: Receive IoT insights

record.title: Signals for Strategists
record.desc: The Signals for Strategists series highlights emerging technology and business trends for senior strategy, operations, and technology executives. Each issue focuses on a single trend with significant implications for large companies in multiple industries. Our trend-sensing methodology involves assembling diverse signals, or pieces of evidence, that collectively tell a story of change and significant business impact. In times of rapid change, leaders need to keep an eye on the horizon. Signals for Strategists can help.

record.title: A renaissance in the domestic oil and gas industry
record.desc: Two innovations that led to a boom in domestic natural gas and oil production—horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing—are creating opportunities as well as challenges across the value chain.
record.headline1: A renaissance in the domestic oil and gas industry

record.title: Big companies now have a hand in the collaborative economy
record.desc: Mobile, social, and geolocation technologies have propelled collaborative commerce well beyond the realm of bartering and tag sales to impact almost every consumer sector of the economy. Big brands are now starting to invest and partner to establish a foothold in the collaborative economy.
record.headline1: Big companies now have a hand in the collaborative economy

record.title: Corporate accelerators
record.sub-title: Spurring digital innovation with a page from the Silicon Valley playbook
record.desc: Every executive today wants to boost innovation beyond what comes out of in-house R&D. Increasingly, companies are setting up corporate accelerators to nurture start-up companies, aiming to tap into new ideas and technologies.
record.headline2: Spurring digital innovation with a page from the Silicon Valley playbook

record.title: Cyber crime fighting
record.desc: Enterprises have to go on the offense to protect themselves from a rising tide of cyber crime. Collective intelligence and human judgment supported by advanced security analytics can help.

record.title: Digital marketing and the mind of the CMO
record.desc: The rising importance of digital media, marketing, and commerce is elevating the importance of the chief marketing officer as strategist, innovator, and buyer of advisory services and technology.
record.headline1: Digital marketing and the mind of the CMO

record.title: The dual roles of the CIO in the digital age
record.desc: The rapid adoption of digital technologies is putting new pressures on IT organizations. As spending on cloud, mobile, analytics, and social technology soars, CIOs have the opportunity to help drive strategy, innovation, and revenue growth. At the same time, these technologies present major new challenges in the traditional domain of IT: building and integrating information systems while cost-effectively operating a reliable and secure infrastructure. Today’s CIO must play a dual role: builder of technology and builder of the business.
record.headline1: The dual roles of the CIO in the digital age

record.title: Intelligent automation: A new era of innovation
record.desc: Intelligent automation—the combination of artificial intelligence and automation— is already helping companies transcend conventional performance tradeoffs to achieve unprecedented levels of efficiency and quality. Applications range from the routine to the revolutionary: from collecting, analyzing, and making decisions about textual information to guiding autonomous vehicles and advanced robots.
record.headline1: Intelligent automation: A new era of innovation

record.title: Internet of Things
record.sub-title: Dedicated networks and edge analytics will broaden adoption
record.desc: Business interest in the Internet of Things continues to grow, with two trends driving an expansion of IoT applications and possibilities: the emergence of new wireless communications networks and the arrival of "edge computing" IT infrastructure.
record.headline2: Dedicated networks and edge analytics will broaden adoption

record.title: Machine learning is going mobile
record.desc: Computers today are eager to learn—and with new cognitive technology, they can do so even when offline. A new generation of applications and devices that can sense, perceive, learn from, and respond to their users and environment will reshape how many businesses engage with customers—and the world.

record.title: MOOCs teach corporations about new opportunities
record.desc: Massive online open courses (MOOCs) have received a lot of attention over the last two years for their potential to disrupt higher education. Though they are not yet well known in the corporate sector, MOOCs are about to have a major impact there as well. Companies are starting to employ MOOCs in areas ranging from recruiting and training to marketing and branding.
record.headline1: MOOCs teach corporations about new opportunities

record.title: The future of knowledge work
record.desc: Online talent marketplaces and emerging technologies are changing how companies find and engage talent. To stay competitive, firms need to embrace the future of knowledge work.

record.title: The Internet of Things
record.desc: The Internet of Things will beckon companies to revise business models, integrate evolving technology, use analytics to create insight, manage security and privacy, and design new organizations.

record.title: The transformation of manufacturing
record.desc: Changes are sweeping the world of manufacturing. Advanced materials and innovative production technologies are maturing. Digital manufacturing techniques are gaining adoption. These technology trends are offering manufacturers new ways to compete, innovate, and grow profitably even as they face challenges from volatile energy costs, workforce shortages, proliferating regulations, and a host of evolving risks.

record.title: Beyond bitcoin
record.sub-title: Blockchain is coming to disrupt your industry
record.desc: Blockchain technology can potentially make a great many things more secure and accountable: financial transactions, micropayments, IoT applications, health records, corporate audits, and more. If you’re not up to speed on blockchain, you need to be.
record.headline2: Blockchain is coming to disrupt your industry

record.title: Upgrading blockchains
record.sub-title: Smart contract use cases in industry
record.desc: Paper contracts can take weeks to travel around the globe, while digital documents are uncomfortably easy to forge. Is there a way to automate transactions to make them smoother, more efficient, and more secure for all parties? Leaders are looking at blockchain and smart contracts as a viable solution.
record.headline2: Smart contract use cases in industry

record.title: 3D printing: “Complexity is free” may be costly for some
record.desc: Additive manufacturing (AM)—the proper technical term for 3D printing—is likely to have an enormous impact on all our lives, but that doesn’t mean it’s going to be good for every business.
record.headline1: 3D printing: “Complexity is free” may be costly for some

record.title: 3D opportunity and the digital thread
record.sub-title: Additive manufacturing ties it all together
record.desc: While additive manufacturing has become a crucial part of the design process, it has not reached critical mass at the enterprise level. The digital thread—a single, seamless strand of data that stretches from the initial design to the finished part—can help scale and enhance AM capabilities.
record.headline2: Additive manufacturing ties it all together

record.title: 3D opportunity serves it up
record.desc: Additively manufactured food may be more of a novelty than an industry game-changer—for now. Yet advances in technology and innovations in its application could mean that science fiction may become fact sooner than expected.

record.title: 3D opportunity for end-use products
record.sub-title: Additive manufacturing builds a better future
record.desc: As the technology improves, product manufacturers are increasingly using additive manufacturing (AM) to enable new designs and improve product performance relative to products manufactured with conventional techniques.
record.headline2: Additive manufacturing builds a better future

record.title: 3D opportunity for technology, media, and telecommunications
record.desc: Technology, media, and telecommunications companies make additive manufacturing (AM) possible in the first place. Now, through innovations in content, software, fabrication techniques and systems, materials, and services, these firms have the chance to meaningfully shape AM adoption across industries.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for technology, media, and telecommunications

record.title: 3D opportunity for intellectual property risk
record.desc: In a shifting value chain, information related to an object’s additive manufacturing (AM) design could become more valuable than the object itself―yet intellectual property law is struggling to keep pace with AM technology advances. A risk assessment framework helps AM stakeholders develop appropriate economic models and IP licenses.

record.title: 3D opportunity for product design
record.sub-title: Additive manufacturing and the early stage
record.desc: With additive manufacturing, product designers can design for performance with less regard for traditional limitations of design for assembly or manufacturing, allowing them to accomplish what may be less practical using other manufacturing techniques.
record.headline2: Additive manufacturing and the early stage

record.title: 3D opportunity for quality assurance and parts qualification
record.desc: Why aren't more manufacturers using 3D printing? One reason is that AM-produced parts and products must be of consistent quality, strength, and reliability, and guarantees have been hard to come by. The good news: A well-planned quality process can solve the problem.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for quality assurance and parts qualification

record.title: 3D opportunity for the talent gap
record.sub-title: Additive manufacturing and the workforce of the future
record.desc: As additive manufacturing (AM) transforms the engineering and manufacturing industries, the broader manufacturing workforce is struggling to adapt to the rapid pace of change. An agile workforce planning process can help to bridge the AM talent gap.
record.headline2: Additive manufacturing and the workforce of the future

record.title: 3D opportunity for aerospace and defense
record.desc: The aerospace and defense industry is increasingly using additive manufacturing to reduce material costs, decrease labor content, and increase availability of parts at point of use, which may have a dramatic impact on the supply chain.

record.title: 3D opportunity for the automotive industry
record.desc: New developments in additive manufacturing processes will likely benefit production within the automotive industry as well as alter traditional manufacturing and supply chain pathways.

record.title: 3D opportunity in medical technology
record.desc: Additive manufacturing capabilities align well with the needs of the medical device segment, enhancing product customization and enabling efficient, cost-effective production and delivery.

record.title: 3D opportunity in tooling
record.desc: The use of additive manufacturing to fabricate tooling can not only reduce lead times and costs, but also improve functionality and enhance the ability to customize.

record.title: 3D opportunity for the supply chain: Additive manufacturing delivers
record.desc: Using additive manufacturing technologies to evolve supply chains can offer companies strong value and a competitive advantage. Explore some of the potential benefits, from lower costs and risks to greater flexibility and agility.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for the supply chain: Additive manufacturing delivers

record.title: 3D opportunity for the Department of Defense
record.desc: In an era of unsustainable defense budgets and increasingly complex enemies, advanced manufacturing holds the potential to help the United States to meet its mission and responsibilities in both arenas.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for the Department of Defense

record.title: 3D opportunity for life cycle assessments
record.desc: Life cycle analysis (LCA)—traditionally used to assess environmental impacts—can also help quantify the potential savings of adopting additive manufacturing techniques, allowing companies to look beyond traditional cost models and metrics to more holistically determine how AM may benefit the business.

record.title: The 3D opportunity primer
record.desc: If the past is prologue, the role that additive manufacturing plays in the manufacturing value chain will likely grow in scope, scale, and complexity.

record.title: 3D opportunity and cyber risk management
record.desc: While cyber risk is pervasive, additive manufacturing (AM) is one area where it can be especially dangerous.

record.title: Cognitive Technologies
record.desc: This collection explores the impact of cognitive technologies on organizations and helps leaders make wise strategy and technology choices. Because cognitive technologies extend the power of information technology to tasks traditionally performed by humans, they can enable organizations to break prevailing trade-offs between speed, cost, and quality.

record.title: Cognitive technologies all set to transform business processes
record.desc: Some cognitive technology vendors and customers are moving past the “science project” phase and using artificial intelligence (AI) to transform business processes. Now is the time for businesses to consider the areas suitable for AI and how they can help transform key processes.
record.headline1: Cognitive technologies all set to transform business processes

record.title: The thinker and the shopper
record.sub-title: Four ways cognitive technologies can add value to consumer products
record.desc: The time could be ripe for consumers and consumer products companies to embrace cognitive technologies, which can offer companies ways to deliver benefits to consumers to a greater degree than previously possible.
record.headline2: Four ways cognitive technologies can add value to consumer products

record.title: Cognitive technologies for health plans
record.sub-title: Using artificial intelligence to meet new market demands
record.desc: New developments in cognitive technologies can help health plans use artificial intelligence to help improve cost-effectiveness, customer service, and population health.
record.headline2: Using artificial intelligence to meet new market demands

record.title: Cognitive technologies in the technology sector
record.sub-title: From science fiction vision to real-world value
record.desc: The technology sector’s interest in cognitive technologies is reaching fever pitch. Here’s how some tech companies are using cognitive technologies to create innovative new products and services, pursue new markets, and even reimagine their businesses.
record.authors: Daniel T. Pereira|David Schatsky|Paul Sallomi|Robert (Bob) Dalton
record.headline1: Cognitive technologies in the technology sector
record.headline2: From science fiction vision to real-world value

record.title: Purple people: The heart of cognitive systems engineering
record.sub-title: The past, present, and future of cognitive technology’s power users
record.desc: Cognitive technologies will change the way we do business. And purple people—those who possess a mix of business and technology skills—have a big role to play. Able to speak the language of both business and technology, they will serve as translators between those worlds, focusing on making cognitive systems useful in a business context.
record.headline1: Purple people: The heart of cognitive systems engineering
record.headline2: The past, present, and future of cognitive technology’s power users

record.title: Cognitive technology
record.desc: One of the most significant developments in technology in coming years will likely be the use of smart machines—cognitive technologies—to replace human labor.

record.title: Innovation in audit takes the analytics, AI route
record.sub-title: Audit analytics, cognitive technologies to set accountants free from grunt work
record.desc: The advent of analytics and cognitive technology does not mean the end of human auditors. It means an end to painstaking checking and crossfooting of debit and credit entries and the beginning of auditing careers that thrive on understanding, monitoring, and improving analytical and cognitive systems.
record.headline1: Innovation in audit takes the analytics, AI route
record.headline2: Audit analytics, cognitive technologies to set accountants free from grunt work

record.title: Cognitive applications: Home runs versus base hits
record.desc: Some companies are aiming at dramatic results such as finding a cure for cancer using cognitive applications, while others are focusing on more prosaic areas such as billing. What's the correct approach?
record.headline1: Cognitive applications: Home runs versus base hits

record.title: Will cognitive automation spell the end of outsourcing?
record.desc: It’s not yet clear whether cognitive automation will kill business process outsourcing completely or merely transform the industry, converting outsourcers into cognitive process overseers. All we know is that smart machines are coming, and they promise to change the face of outsourcing as we know it today.
record.headline1: Will cognitive automation spell the end of outsourcing?

record.title: Onslaught of the smart machines
record.sub-title: How companies can make the most of cognitive technologies
record.desc: How should organizations capitalize on and cope with cognitive technologies in the workplace? Should they simply designate the last person to leave the office, schedule their departure date, and point out the location of the light switch?
record.headline2: How companies can make the most of cognitive technologies

record.title: Demystifying artificial intelligence
record.sub-title: What business leaders need to know about cognitive technologies
record.desc: Artificial Intelligence still sounds more like science fiction than it does an IT investment, but it is increasingly real, and critical to the success of the Internet of Things.
record.headline2: What business leaders need to know about cognitive technologies

record.title: The rise of cognitive agents
record.sub-title: Will humans prefer to talk to machines?
record.desc: As a new generation of personal, social robots is introduced to consumers in the next few years, they are likely to play a larger role in customer support.
record.headline2: Will humans prefer to talk with machines?

record.title: Executive Transitions
record.desc: There is no standard background for transitioning into a C-suite role, and no magic formula for success. Some individuals are elevated to the role from within an organization, others are hired from outside. Some have a few days to prepare, others have weeks or months. Some land in public companies, some in family-owned businesses, some in government agencies. All these differences make every executive's journey unique.

record.title: CIOs, take your CFO to dinner and pay for it
record.desc: I’ll leave the wine-pairing to the sommelier, but here’s a menu of topics for conversation that can fruitfully accompany each course.
record.headline1: CIOs, take your CFO to dinner and pay for it

record.title: Chief Financial Officer (CFO)
record.desc: Chief financial officers (CFOs) are expected to manage risk, provide objective counsel, and bring analytical rigor to strategic choices, which makes them crucial drivers of corporate performance.

record.title: How CFOs can own analytics
record.desc: By taking the lead in applying analytics to operational decisions as well as financial data, CFOs can strengthen ties throughout the business and expand their influence outside core finance functions.

record.title: Congratulations on your promotion. Now give up your old job.
record.desc: Beware the traps of doing your old job in addition to your new one for an extended period of time and overestimating the quality of the staff you inherit.
record.headline1: Congratulations on your promotion. Now give up your old job.

record.title: Navigating the four faces of a functional C-level executive
record.desc: As a C-level executive, you will generally have to assemble a team that ensures the operator and functional stewardship activities are taken care of, freeing your time for the strategist and catalyst faces.
record.headline1: Navigating the four faces of a functional C-level executive

record.title: Crossing the chasm: From operator to strategist
record.desc: Many CFOs start out as operators in the finance role and as stewards addressing controls and compliance—roles that often continue to dominate throughout their tenures. Here are some ways that CFOs can cross the chasm to a more strategic role.
record.headline1: Crossing the chasm: From operator to strategist

record.title: Defining—and delivering—your talent agenda
record.desc: New CFOs quickly grasp that getting talent right is often crucial to attaining their overall goals. Research suggests that there are four main pillars to an efficient talent agenda.

record.title: Turnaround strategies for dysfunctional teams
record.desc: Incoming executives may inherit less-than-effective leadership teams when they take over. Three common dysfunctions include collective delegation upward in an attempt to avoid accountability, low collective energy, and organization silos. Some turnaround strategies for new executives to deal with dysfunctional teams and boost their performance.

record.title: Executive transitions: Elevate your leadership communication strategies
record.desc: New CxOs often struggle to put in place a leadership communication strategy that can help influence stakeholders and achieve objectives; communications support is scarce and, when available, lacks a systematic approach. Here’s a simple model to help new C-level executives create and execute a communications program aligned to their core objectives.
record.headline1: Executive transitions: Elevate your leadership communication strategies

record.title: Elevate your transition priorities
record.desc: Explaining priorities with reasonable specificity and articulating the ways they will help your key stakeholders is of the utmost importance.

record.title: Enhance confidence in your transition priorities
record.desc: Incoming executives need to be realistic about priorities and the time required to drive specific results, and clear about the risks that can impede success and the resources that specific priorities will require.
record.headline1: Enhance confidence in your transition priorities

record.title: Managing transitions: CFO regrets
record.desc: Getting a slow start on their talent needs and skimping on cultural due diligence are their two biggest regrets about their first year on the job, say many CFOs we interviewed.

record.title: The myth of 'the first 90 days'
record.desc: Best-selling business books are placing perilous time constraints on newly minted members of a C-suite, but there’s good news for executives: these timeframes are merely a best-selling myth.

record.title: Navigating change: How CFOs can effectively drive transformation
record.desc: Many CEOs are increasingly looking to their CFOs to help drive organizational transformations. What can a CFO do to effectively support and influence change?
record.headline1: Navigating change: How CFOs can effectively drive transformation

record.title: Catalyzing organizational culture change
record.desc: Culture is like an iceberg. The bulk of it, the submerged part, comprises the shared beliefs and assumptions that are often shaped over generations and can sometimes punch a hole through titanic corporate initiatives. Which is why changing organizational culture can be both a priority and a challenge.

record.title: Executive transitions: Dealing with the passed-over rival
record.desc: While Machiavelli suggests executing former princes and rivals, today we should avail ourselves of more civilized, and even cooperative, strategies. So how should you deal with a passed-over rival?
record.headline1: Executive transitions: Dealing with the passed-over rival

record.title: Executive transitions: The perils of the "rescue fantasy"
record.desc: While there are no fixed and simple answers to decisions pertaining to people, knowing critical trade-offs and a process to engage them may help you better navigate these decisions.
record.headline1: Executive transitions: The perils of the "rescue fantasy"

record.title: Protecting your time in executive transitions
record.desc: Many executives in our transition labs use four strategies to manage their time: screen, schedule, routinize, and delegate.
record.headline1: Protecting your time in executive transitions

record.title: Seven steps for re-recruiting and engaging your new team
record.desc: As a new executive, how can you engage your new team and gain their followership? These steps can help you deal with anxiety about your intentions and the direction in which you want to lead the team, make a connection with far-flung team members, and use your energy and time optimally.
record.headline1: Seven steps for re-recruiting and engaging your new team

record.title: A plain English talent agenda for your transition
record.desc: As a transitioning executive, setting a talent agenda is a top priority, but framing it in a way that will allow the human resources function to help translate your ideas into reality is no easy task.
record.headline1: A plain English talent agenda for your transition

record.title: Executive transitions: Drivers of team performance
record.sub-title: Do you have a team? Do you want a team?
record.desc: When taking over a new executive role, it’s worth asking colleagues, stakeholders, and team members themselves a few pointed questions about how they view your inherited team. What you learn may surprise you.
record.headline1: Executive transitions: Drivers of team performance
record.headline2: Do you have a team? Do you want a team?

record.title: The journey to CFO
record.desc: Today, there are large numbers of women in the finance functions of major corporations but disproportionately few women chief financial officers (CFOs). To help close the gap, Deloitte’s CFO Program and the Women’s Initiative set out to learn how women became successful CFOs. Building on the interviews of 15 leading women CFOs in the United States and Europe, CFO recruiters at major search firms, and other senior executives, we synthesized critical lessons useful for anyone aspiring to become a CFO.

record.title: Executive transitions: What traits do you recruit for?
record.desc: Six fundamental leadership traits—curiosity, courage, perseverance, integrity, confidence, and empathy—might help you identify high-potential staff.
record.headline1: Executive transitions: What traits do you recruit for?

record.title: Industry 4.0 and the chemicals industry
record.sub-title: Catalyzing transformation through operations improvement and business growth
record.desc: Industry 4.0, which combines digital and physical advanced technologies, can potentially transform the chemicals industry, itself the backbone of many end-market industries. Through the dual areas of business operations and growth, these technologies enable “smart” supply chains and factories, as well as create new business models.
record.authors: Stefan Van Thienen|Andrew Clinton|Monica Mahto|Brenna Sniderman
record.headline2: Catalyzing transformation through operations improvement and business growth

record.title: Industry 4.0 and manufacturing ecosystems
record.sub-title: Exploring the world of connected enterprises
record.desc: The marriage of advanced manufacturing techniques with information technology, data, and analytics is driving another industrial revolution—one that invites manufacturing leaders to combine information technology and operations technology to create value in new and different ways.
record.headline2: Exploring the world of connected enterprises

record.title: The Future of Mobility
record.desc: Breakthroughs in self-driving cars are only the beginning: The entire way we travel from point A to point B is changing, creating a new ecosystem of personal mobility. The shift will likely affect far more than automakers—industries from insurance and health care to energy and media should reconsider how they create value in this emerging environment.

record.title: The future of auto retailing
record.sub-title: Preparing for the evolving mobility ecosystem
record.desc: How will tomorrow's car salesman sell customers on ridesharing and autonomous vehicles? As the future of mobility arrives, automakers and dealerships may need to rethink their traditional operations to appeal to customers looking for customization and connectedness.
record.headline2: Preparing for the evolving mobility ecosystem

record.title: Insuring the future of mobility
record.sub-title: The insurance industry's role in the evolving transportation ecosystem
record.desc: If people stop driving, what will auto insurers, well, insure? The rise of ridesharing and autonomous cars—as part of the new mobility ecosystem—means that the insurance industry should reconsider its time-honored business model. While some revenue streams will likely dry up, new ones will begin flowing.
record.authors: John Matley|Malika Gandhi|Emily Yoo|Bill Jarmuz|Stefan Peterson
record.headline2: The insurance industry's role in the evolving transportation ecosystem

record.title: The promise of smart mobility
record.sub-title: Part of the "Smart mobility" research report
record.desc: Emerging alternatives to traditional car ownership—including ridesharing, carsharing, bike commuting, and on-demand ride services—can not only get people where they want to go, but also help address public policy problems such as congestion, traffic accidents, and air pollution.
record.authors: Dr. Peter Viechnicki|Abhijit Khuperkar|Tiffany Dovey Fishman|William D. Eggers
record.headline2: Part of the "Smart mobility" research report

record.title: Navigating a shifting landscape
record.sub-title: Capturing value in the evolving mobility ecosystem
record.desc: Who will guide tomorrow's road warriors? Looking ahead to the future of mobility, one key to capturing value could be to help individuals get more value out of mobility by serving as trusted advisers—on matters ranging from where to go to how to get there and even whom to take along.
record.headline2: Capturing value in the evolving mobility ecosystem

record.title: Financing the future of mobility
record.sub-title: Auto finance in the evolving transportation ecosystem
record.desc: How will the rise of carsharing and self-driving vehicles alter the landscape for auto financiers? It might dramatically change the number and size of loans—and who needs them. Increasingly, customers will be not individual car owners but businesses, and we anticipate overall loan volumes to decline.
record.headline2: Auto finance in the evolving transportation ecosystem

record.title: The future of mobility
record.sub-title: How transportation technology and social trends are creating a new business ecosystem
record.desc: Will technological advances and shifts in social attitudes lead to our no longer owning or driving vehicles? The global auto industry's transformation has far-reaching implications for how we move from point A to point B and, in turn, affects carmakers, energy companies, insurers, health care, government funding, and more. Value shifts as a new ecosystem of mobility emerges.
record.headline2: How transportation technology and social trends are creating a new business ecosystem

record.title: Behavioral Economics and Management
record.desc: Behavioral economics is the study of how psychological, social, and emotional factors often conflict with and override economic incentives when people make decisions. When applied to management, behavioral economics can help us uncover ways to limit the organizational impact of biases and cognitive limitations—or ethically exploit them to help drive enterprise value.

record.title: Going rogue
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors affect decisions related to work process deviation
record.desc: Deviation from standard work processes is common. But rather than view process deviation as the enemy, companies can use it to drive positive outcomes by applying behavioral principles in the workplace.
record.headline2: How behavioral factors affect decisions related to work process deviation

record.title: The healthy choice
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors create influential health campaigns
record.desc: By designing health communications using behavioral economics principles, governments and organizations can go beyond raising awareness to “nudge” people to make more healthful choices.
record.headline2: How behavioral factors create influential health campaigns

record.title: Ignoring bad news
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors influence us to sugarcoat or avoid negative messages
record.desc: People will often ignore or even distort the information they collect when it is “bad news.” How does this impact organizational learning and performance—and what, if anything, can or should businesses do about it?
record.headline2: How behavioral factors influence us to sugarcoat or avoid negative messages

record.title: Gaming away the leadership gap
record.sub-title: Linking gamification and behavioral science to transform leadership development
record.desc: Is gamification the “next big thing” for training programs? If so, why? Learn how leading-edge organizations are infusing gaming into the mix, the results, and how you can make it happen where you work.
record.headline2: Linking gamification and behavioral science to transform leadership development

record.title: Navigating coverage
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors affect decisions in health care plan selection
record.desc: The shopper for health plans is increasingly becoming the individual consumer rather than organizations. How can health plans and exchanges help consumers effectively navigate the complex set of variables they need to weigh to make an informed choice?
record.headline2: How behavioral factors affect decisions in health care plan selection

record.title: Loving the one you’re with
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors influence responses to customer rewards and incentives
record.desc: Thanking customers as a way to kindle loyalty seems straightforward enough. It’s not. Learn how behavioral biases can affect outcomes.
record.headline2: How behavioral factors influence responses to customer rewards and incentives

record.title: Breaking up is hard to do
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors affect consumer decisions to stay in business relationships
record.desc: While emotional biases may help keep consumers “locked in” to unsatisfying business relationships, there is a price to be paid in terms of consumers’ attitudes toward a company’s offerings and the potential impact on future customers.
record.headline1: Breaking up is hard to do
record.headline2: How behavioral factors affect consumer decisions to stay in business relationships

record.title: Toeing the line: Improving security behavior in the information age
record.desc: Security needs to be viewed through a wider lens. Beyond technology investments, security begins and ends with people: their behaviors, motivations, and habits. Learn tangible ways leaders can link culture to strategies to actions to safeguard their organizations—and build stronger cultures.
record.authors: Joe Mariani|Dr. Kwasi Mitchell|Dr. Michael Gelles|Eddie Bitzer|Christine Elliott
record.headline1: Toeing the line: Improving security behavior in the information age

record.title: Stop or not?
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors affect decisions related to work interruptions
record.desc: What can managers do to combat productivity losses caused by distractions and interruptions? In some cases, common-sense interventions carry the day. But in others, a counterintuitive approach turns out to be more effective.
record.headline2: How behavioral factors affect decisions related to work interruptions

record.title: Covering all the bases
record.sub-title: Overcoming behavioral biases to help individuals achieve retirement security
record.desc: A full 86 percent of Americans believe we’re facing a looming retirement crisis. So how can organizations help people save enough? Understanding—and leveraging—behavioral economics tools can have a huge impact. Here’s how.
record.headline2: Overcoming behavioral biases to help individuals achieve retirement security

record.title: Does scarcity make you dumb?
record.sub-title: A behavioral understanding of how scarcity diminishes our decision making and control
record.desc: When people lack the tools and resources needed to operate effectively, they fall prey to the scarcity mind-set. If left unchecked, scarcity can have deleterious effects on performance. The good news is, leaders have an opportunity to help prevent scarcity before it happens.
record.headline2: A behavioral understanding of how scarcity diminishes our decision making and control

record.title: Behavioral strategy to combat choice overload
record.desc: Behavioral researchers have identified a dizzying array of concepts involved in applying “nudge” tactics to business management. Here’s a straightforward way for managers to make sense of them all.
record.headline1: Behavioral strategy to combat choice overload

record.title: Global Human Capital Trends
record.desc: Powerful forces are driving change for both HR functions and the organizations they serve, creating talent challenges—as well as potential solutions—radically different from those faced by previous generations of leaders.

record.title: Trends - Global Human Capital Trends 2014
record.desc: The Global Human Capital Trends 2014 report highlights 12 trends that embody ways that the 21st-century workforce is pushing organizations to innovate, transform, and reengineer their human capital practices. Read the report below, download the full report, and explore our survey data in the interactive Human Capital Trends Dashboard.

record.title: Beyond retention
record.desc: Survey respondents say retention and engagement is the second biggest human capital challenge they face (after leadership). What’s the secret to becoming a “talent magnet” in the coming years?

record.title: Corporate learning redefined
record.desc: It’s a new age for learning and development. Online content, MOOCs, collaboration tools, and social media now fuel a training model where employees own their skills and experts share knowledge freely.
record.authors: Josh Bersin|Josh Haims|Bill Pelster|Bernard van der Vyver

record.title: From diversity to inclusion
record.sub-title: Move from compliance to diversity as a business strategy
record.desc: The world has become highly diverse, but many companies have not—especially when it comes to combining diversity with the inclusive culture needed to truly drive value.
record.headline2: Move from compliance to diversity as a business strategy

record.title: The global and local HR function
record.desc: A new model of “high-impact” HR blends globalized talent practices for consistency and mobility with localized flexibility to attract, retain, and manage people appropriately.
record.headline1: The global and local HR function

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: CEOs and HR leaders see talent as a major challenge to growth. Where should you focus? Our survey of 2,500+ respondents in 90+ countries reveals 12 critical trends shaping the human capital agenda.

record.title: Leaders at all levels
record.sub-title: Close the gap between hype and readiness
record.desc: Leadership remains the top human capital concern—and the largest “readiness gap” in our survey. The need: to develop new leaders faster, globalize leadership programs, and build deeper bench strength.
record.headline2: Close the gap between hype and readiness

record.title: The overwhelmed employee
record.desc: Too much access to information has turned us into “overwhelmed” employees. Nearly every company sees this phenomenon as a challenge to productivity and overall performance, but struggles to handle it.

record.title: Performance management is broken
record.sub-title: Replace "rank and yank" with coaching and development
record.desc: Companies worldwide are questioning their forced-ranking, rigid rating systems and once-a-year appraisal processes. This is the year a new model of performance management will likely sweep through HR.
record.headline2: Replace "rank and yank" with coaching and development

record.title: Race to the cloud
record.sub-title: Integrate talent, HR, and business technologies
record.desc: Cloud-based HR technology promises to integrate people systems, enable learning and talent management, and reengineer recruiting. But massive adoption of new software is harder than it seems.
record.headline2: Integrate talent, HR, and business technologies

record.title: The reskilled HR team
record.sub-title: Transform HR professionals into skilled business consultants
record.desc: HR pros need an increasingly wide range of skills, not only in talent areas, but also in understanding how the business works, makes money, and competes. How are HR teams staying current and viable?
record.headline2: Transform HR professionals into skilled business consultants

record.title: Talent acquisition revisited
record.sub-title: Deploy new approaches for the new battlefield
record.desc: Talent acquisition and recruiting are undergoing rapid disruption, challenging companies to leverage social networks, aggressively market their employment brand, and re-recruit employees every day.
record.headline2: Deploy new approaches for the new battlefield

record.title: Talent analytics in practice
record.sub-title: Go from talking to delivering on big data
record.desc: Analytics is an exciting and fast-growing area in human resources, but many companies are lagging. How can they address this game-changing area of HR to move quickly and methodically into the future?
record.headline2: Go from talking to delivering on big data

record.title: The quest for workforce capability
record.sub-title: Create a global skills supply chain
record.desc: Organizations now compete globally for scarce technical and professional skills. How can they locate and develop this talent when it takes years to develop expertise?
record.authors: Josh Bersin|Jen Stempel|Bernard van der Vyver
record.headline2: Create a global skills supply chain

record.title: Human Capital Trends 2014 survey
record.desc: Take a deep dive into 10 selected results from the 2014 Global Human Capital Trends survey.

record.title: Trends - Global Human Capital Trends 2015
record.desc: The Human Capital Trends 2015 report highlights 10 trends that are reshaping the nature of work and the ways organizations approach talent management. Read the report below, download the full report, and explore our survey data in the interactive Human Capital Trends Dashboard.

record.title: Machines as talent
record.desc: What is the future of cognitive technology in HR? And what should business and talent leaders do about it now?

record.title: Leadership
record.desc: If nearly every company recognizes that developing leaders is a critical talent problem, why are so few companies making progress in addressing it?

record.title: Culture and engagement
record.desc: Employee engagement and culture are now business issues, not just topics for HR to debate. And there’s no place for organizations to hide.

record.title: Introduction: Leading in the new world of work
record.desc: The new world of work presents organizations with challenges that require a new playbook—one that makes HR more agile, forward thinking, and bolder in its solutions.
record.headline1: Introduction: Leading in the new world of work

record.title: Learning and development
record.desc: Companies see an urgent need to build skills and capabilities, and they are now focused on transforming their learning organizations and strategies.
record.authors: Josh Haims|Jen Stempel|Bernard van der Vyver

record.title: Workforce on demand
record.desc: The on-demand workforce offers companies the ability to tap into extensive networks of innovators, technical experts, and seasoned professionals.

record.title: HR and people analytics
record.desc: Still too few organizations are actively implementing HR analytics capabilities to address complex business and talent needs.

record.title: People data everywhere
record.desc: The time has arrived for HR to leverage the valuable insights people data can yield—from both internal and external sources.

record.title: Performance management
record.desc: Innovative new performance management models are now becoming an imperative as businesses modernize and improve their talent solutions.

record.title: Reinventing HR
record.desc: Several factors are converging that should make reinventing HR a critical priority for companies around the world.

record.title: Simplification of work
record.desc: Work simplification is one response to employees overwhelmed by increasing organizational complexity, information overload, and a 24/7 work environment.

record.title: HR
record.sub-title: Growing momentum toward a new mandate
record.desc: Good news: This year’s Global Human Capital Trends survey shows an improvement in the HR organization’s skills, business alignment, and ability to innovate. But as companies change the way they are organized, they must embrace the changing role of HR as well.
record.authors: Erica Volini|Art Mazor|Frank Schaefer|Akio Tsuchida|Brett Walsh
record.headline2: Growing momentum toward a new mandate

record.title: Digital HR
record.desc: A new world for HR technology and design teams is on the horizon. Mobile and other technologies could allow HR leaders to revolutionize the employee experience through new digital platforms, apps, and ways of delivering HR services.
record.authors: Michael Stephan|Shinichiro Uzawa|Erica Volini|Brett Walsh|Roberta Yoshida

record.title: Engagement
record.desc: Employee engagement and retention today means understanding an empowered workforce’s desire for flexibility, creativity, and purpose. Under the evolving social contract between employer and employee, workers become “volunteers” to be reengaged and re-recruited each day.

record.title: Design thinking
record.desc: Design thinking takes aim at the heart of unnecessary workplace complexity by putting the employee experience first—helping to improve productivity by designing solutions that are at once compelling, enjoyable, and simple.

record.title: Learning
record.desc: Corporate learning departments are changing from education providers to content curators and experience facilitators, developing innovative platforms that turn employee learning and development into a self-driven pursuit.
record.authors: Bill Pelster|Josh Haims|Jen Stempel|Bernard van der Vyver

record.title: The gig economy
record.desc: How can a business manage talent effectively when many, or even most, of its people are not actually its employees? Networks of people who work without any formal employment agreement—as well as the growing use of machines as talent—are reshaping the talent management equation.

record.title: Introduction—The new organization
record.desc: Four powerful forces are driving change for both HR functions and the organizations they serve, creating talent challenges—as well as potential solutions—radically different from those faced by previous generations of leaders.

record.title: Leadership awakened
record.desc: Leaders of all ages, genders, and cultures are now poised to take the reins at organizations around the world. How ready will these future business leaders be to take charge in an increasingly complex global marketplace?
record.authors: Nicky Wakefield|Anthony Abbatiello|Dimple Agarwal|Karen Pastakia|Ardie van Berkel

record.title: Shape culture
record.desc: The impact of culture on business is hard to overstate: 82 percent of the respondents to our 2016 Global Human Capital Trends survey believe that culture is a potential competitive advantage. Today, new tools can help leaders measure and manage culture toward alignment with business goals.
record.authors: Marc Kaplan|Ben Dollar|Veronica Melian|Yves Van Durme|Jungle Wong

record.title: Organizational design
record.desc: Hierarchical organizational models aren’t just being turned upside down—they’re being deconstructed from the inside out. Businesses are reinventing themselves to operate as networks of teams to keep pace with the challenges of a fluid, unpredictable world.
record.authors: Tiffany McDowell|Dimple Agarwal|Don Miller|Tsutomu Okamoto|Trevor Page

record.title: People analytics
record.desc: The use of analytics in HR is growing, with organizations aggressively building people analytics teams, buying analytics offerings, and developing analytics solutions. HR now has the chance to demonstrate ROI on its analytics efforts, helping to make the case for further investment.
record.authors: Josh Bersin|Laurence Collins|David Mallon|Jeff Moir|Robert Straub
