The Internet of Things puts digital information to work in the world.

Use the interactive graphic below to explore our insights on the IoT and how these insights connect to specific industries, business issues, roles, and essential concepts. Or scroll down for a complete list of articles.

record.title: The Analytics of Things
record.desc: While it’s undeniably useful to connect inanimate objects and sensors to the Internet, that’s only a first step in terms of doing something useful with all those connected devices.

record.title: Opting in: Using IoT connectivity to drive differentiation
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in insurance
record.desc: Connectivity is changing the way people engage with their cars, homes, and bodies—and insurers are looking to keep pace. Even at an early stage, IoT technology may reshape the way insurance companies assess, price, and limit risks, with a wide range of potential implications for the industry.
record.headline1: Opting in: Using IoT connectivity to drive differentiation
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in insurance

record.title: Editorial: Master or servant?
record.desc: Making the most of IoT-enabled capabilities, while avoiding the temptations of change for its own sake, requires understanding what is likely to change, and what isn’t. Organizations must still think carefully about value capture, for which proven constructs such as competitive position and competitive advantage remain indispensable.

record.title: Smart buildings: How IoT technology aims to add value for real estate companies
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in the CRE industry
record.desc: Yesterday, the value of commercial real estate was all in location. Tomorrow, much of it will be in information—and how CRE companies can use that information to build relationships with customers and strengthen tenant engagement.
record.headline1: Smart buildings: How IoT technology aims to add value for real estate companies
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in the CRE industry

record.title: Who owns the road? The IoT-connected car of today—and tomorrow
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in automotive
record.desc: The connected vehicle has been the most visible and familiar example of Internet of Things technology. But as cars become increasingly software-driven, the real IoT developments in the auto industry are behind the scenes, as automakers and software providers both lay claim to the driver’s seat.
record.authors: Simon Ninan|Bharath Gangula|Matthias von Alten|Brenna Sniderman
record.headline1: Who owns the road? The IoT-connected car of today—and tomorrow
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in automotive

record.title: The power is on: How IoT technology is driving energy innovation
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in the electric power industry
record.desc: As conservation efforts and alternative energy ramp up, electric utilities can no longer count on customers using more and more power. How to survive? With a new focus on efficiency and cost control, based on technology—particularly Internet of Things applications.
record.headline1: The power is on: How IoT technology is driving energy innovation
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in the electric power industry

record.title: The derivative effect: How financial services can make IoT technology pay off
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in the financial services industry
record.desc: Can financial services, which deals mostly with the intangible, benefit from Internet of Things technology? Absolutely—and not only from more and better data about clients' physical assets. IoT applications aim to transform finance along with every other sector.
record.headline1: The derivative effect: How financial services can make IoT technology pay off
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in the financial services industry

record.title: Anticipate, sense, and respond: Connected government and the Internet of Things
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in government
record.desc: Like companies, government agencies are striving to deliver quality services in increasingly complex environments. And the public sector is also looking at ways to apply Internet of Things technology to find new value for citizens, aiming to enhance capabilities, streamline processes, and engage partners.
record.headline1: Anticipate, sense, and respond: Connected government and the Internet of Things
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in government

record.title: No appointment necessary: How the IoT and patient-generated data can unlock health care value
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in health care
record.desc: Doctors have gathered data on patients’ ailments and histories since Hippocrates, and current, accurate information is critical to effective health care. By making measurements and analysis automatic, IoT applications promise to help improve and personalize care—and create new value for industry players.
record.headline1: No appointment necessary: How the IoT and patient-generated data can unlock health care value
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in health care

record.title: Devices and diseases: How the IoT is transforming medtech
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in the medical devices industry
record.desc: As the health care system increasingly values efficiency and outcomes, Internet of Things applications are changing medtech strategy, business models, and operations. But in the IoT ecosystem, medical-device companies share space with players from adjacent industries; some will be competitors, others collaborators.
record.headline1: Devices and diseases: How the IoT is transforming medtech
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in the medical devices industry

record.title: Continuing the march: The past, present, and future of the IoT in the military
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in defense
record.desc: Military commanders have always lived and died by information—both quantity and quality. No surprise, then, that the US military has been an early adopter of the Internet of Things and is looking to expand its applications. But this new technology brings with it organizational and security challenges that present both opportunities and obstacles.
record.headline1: Continuing the march: The past, present, and future of the IoT in the military
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in defense

record.title: Connected barrels: Transforming oil and gas strategies with the Internet of Things
record.sub-title: The Internet of things in the oil and gas industry
record.desc: In the oil and gas industry, the promise of IoT applications lies not with managing existing assets, supply chains, or customer relationships but, rather, in creating new value in information about these. An integrated deployment strategy is key for O&G companies looking to find value in IoT technology.
record.headline1: Connected barrels: Transforming oil and gas strategies with the Internet of Things
record.headline2: The Internet of things in the oil and gas industry

record.title: Shipping smarter: IoT opportunities in transport and logistics
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in shipping
record.desc: It’s always been essential for shipping companies to keep track of where everything is, and Internet of Things applications have made that easier. But the IoT is also expanding the ways in which T&L firms function—­cutting costs, increasing efficiency, and creating new revenue possibilities.
record.headline1: Shipping smarter: IoT opportunities in transport and logistics
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in shipping

record.title: Beyond the dumb pipe: The IoT and the new role for network service providers
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in telecom
record.desc: During the rise of the Internet, communication services treated their network providers as little more than “dumb pipes,” providing bandwidth. The IoT revolution, requiring a dramatic increase in strong, secure communication links, offers providers an opportunity to not only play a larger role but to create new value.
record.headline1: Beyond the dumb pipe: The IoT and the new role for network service providers
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in telecom

record.title: Inside the Internet of Things (IoT)
record.sub-title: A primer on the technologies building the IoT
record.desc: Explore the inner workings of the Internet of Things in this deep dive into some of the technologies that make it possible.
record.authors: Jonathan Holdowsky|Monica Mahto|Michael E. Raynor|Mark Cotteleer
record.headline2: A primer on the technologies building the IoT

record.title: Closing the digital divide: IoT in retail’s transformative potential
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in the retail industry
record.desc: The Internet of Things is poised to transform the retail industry, virtually eliminating the choice/customization trade-off and redefining sources of competitive advantage. And the return on investment may be more compelling than some retailers appreciate.
record.authors: Tracie Kambies|Michael E. Raynor|Derek M. Pankratz|Geetendra Wadekar
record.headline1: Closing the digital divide: IoT in retail’s transformative potential
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in the retail industry

record.title: The Internet of Things: New labels, new models
record.desc: Although the Internet of Things has not entirely changed the rules of the game—in the form of the fundamental laws of economic activity—it is shifting the ways in which companies can achieve valuable, inimitable differentiation.
record.headline1: The Internet of Things: New labels, new models

record.title: Will IoT technology bring us the quantified employee?
record.sub-title: The Internet of Things in human resources
record.desc: Wearables and other IoT-based devices are helping millions of us better ourselves. Can employers convince everyone to use the same technology to make work more efficient, productive, and pleasant? All that data offers great potential for workplace gains—as long as everyone’s on board with the program.
record.headline1: Will IoT technology bring us the quantified employee?
record.headline2: The Internet of Things in human resources

record.title: Turnkey IoT
record.sub-title: Bundled solutions promise to reduce complexity and accelerate ROI
record.desc: Incorporating Internet of Things technology into products and services can represent quite an undertaking: There's a world of sensors and networking technology, plus legacy IT systems that must be integrated. How to get everything up and running quickly? Some companies are turning to bundled IoT systems.
record.headline2: Bundled solutions promise to reduce complexity and accelerate ROI

record.title: Will patients and caregivers embrace technology-enabled health care?
record.desc: It’s one thing for health care providers to implement new IoT technology—and quite another for patients and caregivers to embrace it.

record.title: Tech Trends
record.desc: Deloitte’s seventh annual Technology Trends report explores eight trends that illustrate ways that today’s CIOs can shape tomorrow for every corner of their organizations. Read about the trends below, download the full report, and explore our interactive tablet app.

record.title: Tech Trends 2014
record.desc: In our fifth annual report, we outline 10 trends that exemplify the unprecedented potential for emerging technologies to reshape how work gets done, how businesses grow, and how markets and industries evolve. Delve into the trends below, download the full report, and explore our interactive tablet app.

record.title: CIO as venture capitalist
record.desc: CIOs are borrowing from the playbooks of venture capitalists and reshaping how they run the business of IT.

record.title: Cloud orchestration
record.desc: CIOs should be making deliberate investments in developing advanced integration and data management capabilities to support cloud-to-cloud and cloud-to-core models.

record.title: Cognitive analytics
record.desc: Cognitive analytics offers a way to bridge the gap between big data and the reality of practical decision making.

record.title: Industrialized crowdsourcing
record.desc: Today, technology makes crowdsourcing possible on an industrial scale, with potentially disruptive impacts on both cost and innovation.

record.title: Digital engagement
record.desc: With more and more parts of the business becoming digital, the CIO has an opportunity to build a new legacy for IT.

record.title: Exponentials
record.desc: Exponentials represent unprecedented opportunities as well as existential threats. Explore five with far-reaching, transformative impact.

record.title: In-memory revolution
record.desc: The sweet spot for in-memory technologies is where massive amounts of data, complex operations, and business challenges demanding real-time support collide.

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: Explore 10 trends that offer CIOs the opportunity to shape tomorrow and to transform “business as usual.”

record.title: Real-time DevOps
record.desc: Early adopters of real-time DevOps have the opportunity to profoundly impact their IT shop, accelerating IT delivery, improving quality, and better aligning with the business.

record.title: Social activation
record.desc: The power of social activation is unleashed when others advocate an organization’s message in their own words to their network.

record.title: Technical debt reversal
record.desc: Understanding, containing, and mitigating technical debt can be a platform for a renewed level of trust and transparency with the business.

record.title: Tech Trends 2015
record.desc: In our sixth annual Technology Trends report, we outline eight trends that could potentially disrupt the way businesses engage their customers, how work gets done, and how markets and industries evolve.

record.title: Ambient computing
record.sub-title: Putting the Internet of Things to work
record.desc: More than the sum of its devices, the Internet of Things links technologies together to create new services and opportunities.
record.headline2: Putting the Internet of Things to work

record.title: Amplified intelligence
record.desc: Applying advanced techniques like machine learning and predictive modeling to massive, complex data sets helps amplify our intelligence for more effective decision making.

record.title: CIO as chief integration officer
record.desc: CIOs can help drive innovation by serving as a link between the business strategy and the IT agenda—fusing the vision for tomorrow with the realities of today.

record.title: Dimensional marketing
record.sub-title: New rules for the digital age
record.desc: The modern era for marketing is being formed around four new dimensions: customer engagement, connectivity, information, and next-generation technology.
record.headline2: New rules for the digital age

record.title: Exponentials
record.desc: Exponentials represent unprecedented opportunities as well as existential threats. Explore six with far-reaching, transformative impact.

record.title: Introduction
record.sub-title: Tech Trends 2015: The fusion of business and IT
record.desc: A fundamental transformation is happening in the way C-suite leaders and CIOs collaborate to leverage disruptive change, chart business strategy, and pursue potentially transformative opportunities.
record.headline2: Tech Trends 2015: The fusion of business and IT

record.title: Core renaissance
record.desc: As focus shifts from performing business processes to enabling innovation, reinvented core systems can form the foundation for growth and new service development.

record.title: IT worker of the future
record.desc: Tackling the scarcity of technical talent likely means cultivating a new species of IT worker with habits, incentives, and skills that are inherently different from today’s.

record.title: Software-defined everything
record.desc: Much of the operating environment can now be virtualized, automated, and orchestrated, positioning infrastructure as a competitive differentiator that can help fuel innovation.

record.title: API economy
record.desc: Application programming interfaces can extend the reach of an organization’s core assets, allowing them to be shared, reused, or even resold as a new revenue stream.

record.title: Augmented and virtual reality go to work
record.sub-title: Seeing business through a different lens
record.desc: While the consumer world waits for dominant augmented and virtual reality players to emerge, businesses can fast-track adoption—and begin the process of fundamentally reimagining how work gets done.
record.headline1: Augmented and virtual reality go to work
record.headline2: Seeing business through a different lens

record.title: Autonomic platforms
record.desc: Almost all traditional IT operations could be candidates for autonomic computing—which really means taking automation to the next level by basing it in machine learning.

record.title: Blockchain: Democratized trust
record.sub-title: Distributed ledgers and the future of value
record.desc: Trust is foundational to business, yet maintaining trust—particularly throughout a global economy—is expensive, time-consuming, and, in many cases, inefficient. Could blockchain applications become part of the answer?
record.headline2: Distributed ledgers and the future of value

record.title: Industrialized analytics
record.sub-title: Data is the new oil. Where are the refineries?
record.desc: To realize data’s full potential takes more than talent, platforms, and processes. It requires creating a structure for data assets and their use in analytics that can enable repeatable results and scale.
record.headline2: Data is the new oil. Where are the refineries?

record.title: Right-speed IT
record.desc: Separating “innovation” from “maintenance” can be bad for IT morale. Forward-thinking CIOs are embracing delivery models that distribute agile experience more evenly across teams, seeking to optimize enterprise IT at a speed that’s right for the entire IT organization.

record.title: Internet of Things: From sensing to doing
record.sub-title: Think big, start small, scale fast
record.desc: The IoT’s true value lies in its disruptive potential for reimagining business processes and, ultimately, rewiring business, government, and society. Realizing that potential means shifting IoT applications’ strategic focus toward not just sensing, but doing.
record.headline1: Internet of Things: From sensing to doing
record.headline2: Think big, start small, scale fast

record.title: Reimagining core systems
record.sub-title: Modernizing the heart of the business
record.desc: Accelerating digital transformation and emerging technologies such as sensors, connected devices, blockchain, and cognitive computing are making it a strategic imperative to revitalize legacy core systems to drive untapped value.
record.headline2: Modernizing the heart of the business

record.title: Social impact of exponential technologies
record.desc: With great power comes great responsibility—and disruptive technologies are potentially some of the most powerful forces in the business world today. How can CIOs help businesses use exponential technologies to drive transformative change and positive social impact?

record.title: Introduction: Innovating in the digital era
record.desc: Technology leaders are in a rare position to imagine a future, and then harness innovation to build it responsibly from the realities of today.
record.headline1: Introduction: Innovating in the digital era

record.title: Patterns of Disruption Series
record.desc: Disruptive innovation doesn't just happen at random. History shows that it’s possible to identify specific patterns of disruption—disruptive strategies that, when combined with certain marketplace trends, can topple industry incumbents.

record.title: Patterns of disruption: Anticipating disruptive strategies in a world of unicorns, black swans, and exponentials
record.desc: Established industry incumbents perpetually face the risk of being disrupted by new entrants using new technologies, business models, or approaches to capture marketplace leadership. Are there ways for incumbents to recognize the potential for disruptive strategy in advance?
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar
record.headline1: Patterns of disruption: Anticipating disruptive strategies in a world of unicorns, black swans, and exponentials

record.title: Converge products
record.desc: “Bundling” functions from formerly distinct products into a single offering can give customers a more economical and convenient way to access those functions—which can disrupt those making and selling specialized products.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar

record.title: Distributed product development
record.desc: Using collaboration and information-sharing technology, organizations today can mobilize a multitude of third parties to help develop products and services, potentially leaving less-innovative competitors behind.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar

record.title: Expand market reach
record.sub-title: Connecting fragmented buyers and sellers—wherever, whenever
record.desc: By making more products available to a larger audience, technologies such as the Internet are making it possible for organizations to fulfill the “long tail” of demand, disrupting incumbents that rely on high-volume sales of relatively few items.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar
record.headline2: Connecting fragmented buyers and sellers—wherever, whenever

record.title: Patterns of Disruption Case Studies
record.desc: Disruptive innovation doesn't just happen at random. History shows that it’s possible to identify specific patterns of disruption—disruptive strategies that, when combined with certain marketplace trends, can topple industry incumbents.

record.title: Turn products into product platforms
record.sub-title: Providing a foundation for others to build upon
record.desc: Rather than focus solely on guarding information, creators of product platforms balance the need to protect intellectual property with the value that can be created by allowing third-party innovators to build on the core product to meet a wide range of needs.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar
record.headline2: Providing a foundation for others to build upon

record.title: Unbundle products and services
record.sub-title: Giving you just what you want, nothing more
record.desc: Products like newspapers and pop-music albums—once thought to be the smallest viable unit of sale—are now being disaggregated into their component parts, thanks to new technologies that change the economics of production and distribution.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar
record.headline2: Giving you just what you want, nothing more

record.title: Unlock assets from adjacent markets
record.desc: Today, a business can be a major transportation-for-hire company without owning any vehicles, or offer travelers accommodations worldwide without owning any hotels. How are companies like these using adjacent markets—and are they making traditional, capital-intensive business models obsolete?
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar

record.title: Align price with use
record.sub-title: Reducing up-front barriers with usage-based pricing
record.desc: Today, pay-per-view isn’t the only thing you buy on a per-use basis. Companies are now offering usage-based pricing on everything from cars to car insurance, giving them rich insight into how, when and where customers use products and threatening to upend traditional business models where revenues depend on ownership.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar
record.headline2: Reducing up-front barriers with usage-based pricing

record.title: Shorten the value chain
record.sub-title: Transforming the stages of value delivery
record.desc: The changed economics of value delivery can challenge the viability of incumbents with long, complex value chains. New technologies are allowing marketplace entrants to eliminate whole stages of the value chain, often dramatically reducing capital and infrastructure costs.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Maggie Wooll|Andrew de Maar
record.headline2: Transforming the stages of value delivery

record.title: Digital-Age Transportation
record.desc: The average commuter spends 34 hours a year stuck in traffic. Here’s how the Internet of Things can integrate technologies, change behavior, and get us moving.

record.title: Enforcement actions in the banking industry
record.desc: Regulators issue hundreds of enforcement actions to banks each year. Recent research sheds light on current trends in the number, type, and severity of these actions, with implications for ways that banks may be able to better anticipate and respond to them.
record.authors: Val Srinivas|Daniel Byler|Richa Wadhwani|Alok Ranjan|Vamsi Krishna
record.headline1: Enforcement actions in the banking industry

record.title: From follower to leader
record.sub-title: Innovation strategies in retail financial services
record.desc: How can followers approach innovation in their quest to overtake industry pioneers?
record.headline2: Innovation strategies in retail financial services

record.title: Future Tense
record.sub-title: What two years of Dodd-Frank may tell banks about the future
record.desc: It’s clear that the principles embedded in Dodd-Frank are here to stay. While some adjustments may be made around the edges of this monumental law, the core principles targeting systemic risk are set.
record.headline2: What two years of Dodd-Frank may tell banks about the future

record.title: Winning in middle-market banking
record.desc: Although many middle-market customers seem satisfied with their current banking relationships, that’s no guarantee of success in the future. Here are three strategies that can help banks sharpen their competitive positioning and compete against new players.
record.authors: Deron Weston|Val Srinivas|Philip Jacob|Lincy Francis Therattil|Richa Wadhwani

record.title: Mobile financial services
record.sub-title: Raising the bar on customer engagement
record.desc: The increasing ubiquity of mobile technologies suggests opportunities for financial services companies to cultivate deeper customer engagement and boost brand loyalty.
record.headline2: Raising the bar on customer engagement

record.title: Shifting retail bank pricing models
record.sub-title: Managing the transition to unbundled services
record.desc: Unbundled, fee-per-service pricing could offer banks an attractive alternative to the traditional “free checking” model—if they can successfully navigate challenges in strategy and implementation.
record.headline2: Managing the transition to unbundled services

record.title: Bank board risk governance
record.sub-title: Driving performance through enhanced risk oversight
record.desc: Boards of directors at large banks may have built a strong risk oversight foundation, but many still have work to do in adopting leading practices.
record.headline2: Driving performance through enhanced risk oversight

record.title: Consumer & Industrial Products
record.desc: Consumer products companies are looking to maximize profits and market share in an interconnected, competitive environment. Challenges for these organizations include meeting the changing demands of customers, maneuvering through a consolidating market, and executing strategies to grow profitably.?

record.title: A Crisis of the Similar
record.sub-title: Innovation in the consumer products industry
record.desc: Consumer products today suffer from a crisis of the similar. Differences between brands are not significant enough for any brand to stand out. Yet there is hope for companies that think innovatively.
record.headline2: Innovation in the consumer products industry

record.title: CPG companies: Your next growth opportunity has a user name and password
record.desc: With the pace of digital commerce in packaged goods expected to accelerate, CPG companies should act now with a coordinated, systematic approach.
record.headline1: CPG companies: Your next growth opportunity has a user name and password

record.title: Digital commerce in the supermarket aisle
record.desc: New research suggests that there may be more growth potential in the e-commerce channel than many CPG executives realize.
record.headline1: Digital commerce in the supermarket aisle

record.title: The profit margin squeeze: Structural strategies for consumer product companies
record.desc: The profit margin squeeze explores the challenges consumer products companies face due to the combination of rising and volatile input costs and a price sensitive consumer. Nearly every step from farm to retailer has been impacted by surging commodity costs driven by rising food demand, constrained food supply, rising energy costs and global economic uncertainty. This report explores the structural strategies that can help companies improve resilience to changes, while providing flexibility to respond.
record.headline1: The profit margin squeeze: Structural strategies for consumer product companies

record.title: The three rules in consumer products
record.desc: Shifts in the consumer products (CP) marketplace are driving CP companies to reconceive what it means to be better before cheaper and to pursue revenue before cost.
record.headline1: The three rules in consumer products

record.title: Consumer product trends
record.desc: What challenges could the consumer product industry be facing five years from now? CPG companies can prepare themselves for a range of possible futures by harnessing technology, reinventing brands, and exploring new business models.
record.authors: Pat Conroy|Kim Porter|Rich Nanda|Barb Renner|Anupam Narula

record.title: 2012 Survey of U.S. Health Care Consumers: Five-Year Look Back
record.desc: Conducted annually since 2008, Deloitte’s longitudinal study aims to give a comprehensive view of health care consumerism, a view that goes beyond conventional boundaries of health and health care.
record.headline1: 2012 Survey of U.S. Health Care Consumers: Five-Year Look Back

record.title: Preparing the doctor of the future
record.sub-title: Medical school and residency program evolution
record.desc: The basic structure of US medical education has hardly changed in the past 100 years. Yet in the 21st century, doctors must navigate a dizzying array of high technology, new regulations, and shifting patient expectations. How can medical schools better prepare the physician of tomorrow?
record.authors: Harry Greenspun| MD|Ken Abrams| MD|Arielle Kane
record.headline1: Preparing the doctor of the future
record.headline2: Medical school and residency program evolution

record.title: A consumer-driven culture of health
record.sub-title: The path to sustainability and growth
record.desc: The Affordable Care Act has disrupted the US health care market's current fee-for-service economic model. Out of this disruption may emerge an open, consumer-driven health care ecosystem focused on transparency, actionable insights, collaboration, and engagement.
record.headline2: The path to sustainability and growth

record.title: A matter of choice, not chance
record.sub-title: Challenges in providing health care for the elderly
record.desc: Aging, chronic, and end-of-life care is currently guided more by chance than by careful planning. There seems to be a vacuum in this area that providers and other industry players could turn into an opportunity for innovation.
record.headline1: A matter of choice, not chance
record.headline2: Challenges in providing health care for the elderly

record.title: Medical home 2.0
record.desc: The goal of the patient-centered medical home (PCMH) is to deliver continuous, accessible, high-quality, patient-oriented primary care—coordinated by a primary care physician, supported by information technologies, and delivered by a multi-disciplinary team of allied health professionals. The Deloitte Center for Health Solutions’ second such report outlines the current state of the PCMH under new federal health reform legislation, reviews primary results from several pilots programs and discusses how PCMHs may evolve going forward.

record.title: Making sense of hospital rankings
record.desc: Several organizations rank health care facilities nationally. But a study comparing these rankings yielded disconcerting results. Rankings varied widely from group to group, with many “high performing” hospitals on one list landing among the worst performers on another.

record.title: Ready, set, (triple) aim
record.desc: Explore the impact that value-based care could have on health care costs, population health, and patient experience in the United States.

record.title: Health Plans
record.desc: Health plans today face more than an adjustment. They are playing a new role in helping new populations get new kinds of care in new ways. Instead of just changing practices, they may have to embrace new value propositions to thrive.

record.title: Breaking constraints: Can incentives change consumer health choices?
record.sub-title: Part of a Deloitte series on innovation
record.desc: Innovative incentive programs may well help individuals overcome the inertia that limits engagement in wellness programs, disrupting the trade-offs people make when pursuing health care goals.
record.headline1: Breaking constraints: Can incentives change consumer health choices?
record.headline2: Part of a Deloitte series on innovation

record.title: New payment models in health care
record.desc: Could and should physician membership organizations take the lead? Yes, but they need to tread carefully; if they get ahead of their membership, they may risk rebellion, as a recent case illustrates.
record.headline1: New payment models in health care

record.title: Insurance
record.desc: The insurance industry is facing change on an extraordinary scale. Insurance companies are wrestling with issues brought on by globalization, technological advances, regulatory changes, heightened competition, and shifting customer demand. In such a complex environment, insurance company leaders need insights into the drivers behind these challenges.

record.title: Voice of the annuities consumer
record.sub-title: Exploring innovative approaches to accelerate annuities market growth
record.desc: Despite a generally promising annuities market outlook, insurers may need to address several fundamental systemic challenges to increase market penetration, widen their prospect base, and keep sales on an upward trajectory.
record.headline2: Exploring innovative approaches to accelerate annuities market growth

record.title: Overcoming speed bumps on the road to telematics
record.sub-title: Challenges and opportunities facing auto insurers with and without usage-based programs
record.desc: Behavior-based telematics is disrupting the auto insurance market, challenging non-participating carriers to follow the lead of early adopters or look for new ways to level the playing field.
record.headline1: Overcoming speed bumps on the road to telematics
record.headline2: Challenges and opportunities facing auto insurers with and without usage-based programs

record.title: The voice of the personal lines consumer
record.desc: What makes personal lines insurance buyers tick in the current business environment?
record.headline1: The voice of the personal lines consumer

record.title: The out-of-sync advisor: Applying disruptive innovation to serve non-consumers of wealth management advice
record.sub-title: Part of a Deloitte series on innovation
record.desc: Over a third of mass affluent investors do not currently work with a financial advisor. How could disruptive innovations in service models help turn these investors into wealth management clients?
record.headline1: The out-of-sync advisor: Applying disruptive innovation to serve non-consumers of wealth management advice
record.headline2: Part of a Deloitte series on innovation

record.title: The future of wealth in the United States
record.desc: How might the distribution of wealth across the generations shift over the next 15 years? These models of generational wealth trends in the United States shed light on what may be in store—both for Americans and for wealth management firms.
record.headline1: The future of wealth in the United States

record.title: Making retirement security a reality
record.sub-title: What can financial institutions and advisors do?
record.desc: The retirement advisory industry is positioned to make a significant dent in alleviating the looming retirement crisis. But to do this, financial services firms may need to devise new ways of delivering appropriate, affordable retirement advice to a wider range of clients.
record.headline2: What can financial institutions and advisors do?

record.title: Life Sciences & Health Care
record.desc: Life sciences companies face ongoing pricing and cost pressures, driving a focus on operating performance within an evolving regulatory and risk environment. Yet opportunities may lie in the adoption of new business models enabled by scientific and technological advances.

record.title: Big pharma's market access mission
record.desc: The rising power of private and government payers in the United States requires a fundamental shift in how pharmaceutical companies communicate value—and a step change in market access capabilities.

record.title: Invigorating biopharma
record.sub-title: How the three rules can drive superior performance
record.desc: Though changing industry dynamics may call for cost containment in the short term, biopharma companies can emerge with new strategies that are again oriented toward non-price value and growth.
record.headline2: How the three rules can drive superior performance

record.title: The three rules in medical technology
record.desc: Viewing performance through the lens of three straightforward rules can help medical technology companies navigate profound changes in the US health care ecosystem.
record.headline1: The three rules in medical technology

record.title: Transforming commercial models to address new health care realities
record.desc: The new realities of the health care industry make it imperative for biopharmaceutical companies to explore alternative commercial models to supplement traditional go-to-market strategies.
record.headline1: Transforming commercial models to address new health care realities

record.title: The road to value-based care
record.desc: Value-based payment models for health care have the potential to upend traditional patient care and business models. What can your organization do to effectively make the shift?
record.authors: Wendy Gerhardt|Leslie Korenda|Dr. Mitch Morris|Gaurav Vadnerkar

record.title: The future of manufacturing
record.sub-title: Making things in a changing world
record.desc: The changing economics of production and distribution, along with shifts in consumer demand and the emergence of “smart” products, are pushing manufacturers to explore radically new ways of creating and capturing value.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Duleesha Kulasooriya|Craig A. Giffi|Mengmeng Chen
record.headline2: Making things in a changing world

record.title: Location, location, location
record.desc: Sometimes, it makes sense to spend more to conveniently locate capacity.

record.title: Manufacturing opportunity
record.sub-title: A Deloitte series on making America stronger
record.desc: Americans take a dim view of the manufacturing sector’s health and future prospects. Public policies that encourage innovation and talent can help the country regain its global lead in manufacturing.
record.headline2: A Deloitte series on making America stronger

record.title: High-performance manufacturers
record.sub-title: What separates the best from the rest
record.desc: Three straightforward rules. Ten sets of important manufacturing capabilities. What can manufacturing executives learn from them about company competitiveness and performance?
record.authors: Craig A. Giffi|Bharath Gangula|Michelle Drew Rodriguez
record.headline2: What separates the best from the rest

record.title: Following the capital trail in oil and gas
record.desc: Oil and gas companies are facing a new environment of lower prices and faster investment cycles, calling for a more dynamic approach to the capital supply chain.
record.headline1: Following the capital trail in oil and gas

record.title: Energy's Next Frontiers
record.sub-title: How technology is radically reshaping supply, demand and the energy of geopolitics
record.desc: Technology is making more energy resources available to more actors than ever before. This holds the promise of generating much greater energy security for countries, companies, and individuals.
record.headline2: How technology is radically reshaping supply, demand and the energy of geopolitics

record.title: Made in America: The economic impact of LNG exports from the United States
record.sub-title: A report by the Deloitte Center for Energy Solutions and Deloitte MarketPoint LLC
record.desc: United States LNG exporters might benefit from selling to foreign buyers, but how would such exports impact domestic consumers of natural gas?
record.headline1: Made in America: The economic impact of LNG exports from the United States
record.headline2: A report by the Deloitte Center for Energy Solutions and Deloitte MarketPoint LLC

record.title: Navigating a Fractured Future
record.sub-title: Insights into the future of the North American natural gas market
record.desc: Previously uneconomic shale gas deposits have over the past decade been converted into valuable energy resources. This has increased supply, but recent economic events have hit demand. The price of natural gas has plummeted in North America, forcing producers to ask themselves some difficult questions. Deloitte analyzed the future of North American gas market under various scenarios, to answer some of these questions, with findings summarized in this report.

Google did it by implementing what we refer to as a shaping strategy.

Factors like economic lethargy in Europe and America, and fast-paced growth in emerging markets present both rare opportunities and daunting risks.

It turns out that the major "success studies" are routinely fooled by randomness, studying companies that are indistinguishable from lucky random walkers. Why has this phenomenon led so many researchers astray, and what are the implications for the practice of management?

record.title: Mayo Clinic
record.sub-title: A case study in work environment redesign
record.desc: Mayo Clinic supports its collaborative culture with social collaboration software and physical innovation spaces to improve performance.
record.headline2: A case study in work environment redesign

record.title: Metrics That Matter
record.desc: Social software presents a set of unique capabilities to address operating challenges and improve operating metrics. Companies that embrace this opportunity will have a distinct advantage over their competitors, with the experiences of two early adopters suggesting a strategy for deriving tangible performance improvements and achieving short-term impact with a modest investment in social software tools.

record.title: What if the road to inclusion were really an intersection?
record.desc: While traditional diversity and inclusion frameworks have helped bring more diverse talent into organizations, what got organizations here will not get them where they want to be. An intersectional approach that reaches all facets of corporate life is often more fruitful.
record.headline1: What if the road to inclusion were really an intersection?

record.title: SAP
record.sub-title: A case study in work environment redesign
record.desc: Through the SAP Community Network, an online platform that attracts over 2 million monthly visitors, SAP draws on a robust network of customers, partners, and thought leaders to help solve problems.
record.headline2: A case study in work environment redesign

record.title: How to learn when you’re playing at scale
record.desc: The scalable efficiency model as it has traditionally been pursued—granular demand forecasting, rigid processes, and standardization to ensure predictability and minimize variances—is not only increasingly difficult; it is fundamentally incompatible with learning.
record.headline1: How to learn when you’re playing at scale

record.title: The six signature traits of inclusive leadership
record.sub-title: Thriving in a diverse new world
record.desc: Diversity of markets, customers, ideas, and talent is driving the need for inclusion as a new leadership capability. Here are six attributes of leaders who display the ability to not only embrace individual differences, but to potentially leverage them for competitive advantage.
record.headline1: The six signature traits of inclusive leadership
record.headline2: Thriving in a diverse new world

record.title: Taking the reins as a business school dean
record.desc: Business school deans have a complex role—yet many newly minted deans find that the experiences they acquire in academia and industry do not adequately prepare them for their new responsibilities.
record.headline1: Taking the reins as a business school dean

record.title: Taking the reins as a CIO
record.desc: Proficiency in the foundational skills of running an IT department will only make for a good CIO. A great CIO possesses and applies capabilities that create value for the business.
record.headline1: Taking the reins as a CIO

record.title: Taking the reins: Managing CFO transitions
record.desc: The Deloitte CFO Program interviewed more than 20 CFOs from varied companies, most with more than $2 billion in revenues. Our research shows that taking on the role of CFO is an intense journey that places new and conflicting demands on personal time and relationships. This report shares practices that successful CFOs have used to navigate transitions, with a special emphasis on those critical questions that need to be asked.
record.headline1: Taking the reins: Managing CFO transitions

record.title: Talent 2020: Surveying the Talent Paradox from the Employee Perspective
record.desc: Organizations need to ask themselves the fundamental questions of the talent paradox: Are workers truly satisfied? Or are they just “making do” with their current jobs because of a difficult market?
record.headline1: Talent 2020: Surveying the Talent Paradox from the Employee Perspective

record.title: Getting the right people in the right seats
record.desc: Getting the “right people in the right seats” as quickly as possible is likely to free up your time to attend to the truly important issues. A few key questions can help you identify where you may have to replace key staff, reassign staff to other roles they are better suited to, or invest in training and coaching to upgrade their skills.
record.headline1: Getting the right people in the right seats

record.title: Talent development: A key to attracting and retaining highly skilled people in your industry
record.desc: Management should consider that an effective way to attract and retain talent is to create an environment where talented people can develop.
record.headline1: Talent development: A key to attracting and retaining highly skilled people in your industry

record.title: Talent Edge 2020: Perspectives from the Consumer and Industrial Products Industry
record.sub-title: An industry view of the "Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal" survey
record.desc: Consumer and industrial product companies have found it challenging to compete for talent globally and manage talent training programs. An industry with a high-level of layoffs nonetheless faces talent shortages in the critical areas of growth and innovation. This report is based on the findings of the Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal report, which includes a survey of about 300 senior executives worldwide.
record.headline1: Talent Edge 2020: Perspectives from the Consumer and Industrial Products Industry
record.headline2: An industry view of the "Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal" survey

record.title: Talent Edge 2020: Perspectives from the Financial Services Industry
record.sub-title: An industry view of the "Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal" survey
record.desc: This report on talent issues in the financial service industry finds that companies are trying to find an equilibrium between austerity measures and investing for future expansion. Cutting and managing costs, while retaining key employees, are prime concerns of the executives surveyed. About half of the executives polled worldwide cited talent shortages in strategic functions such as R&D and leadership despite high unemployment in the U.S. and abroad.
record.headline1: Talent Edge 2020: Perspectives from the Financial Services Industry
record.headline2: An industry view of the "Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal" survey

record.title: Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal
record.desc: "Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for a New Normal" is the first installment of a post-recession longitudinal study that explores the changing talent priorities and strategies of global and large national companies. This inaugural edition features results from an October 2010 survey of 334 senior business leaders and human resource executives worldwide.
record.headline1: Talent Edge 2020: Blueprints for the New Normal

record.title: Talent Edge 2020: Building the recovery together
record.sub-title: What talent expects and how leaders are responding
record.desc: Many companies are not addressing the critical needs and potential frustrations of their employees—and often do not have a realistic picture of how employees see them, according to a March 2011 survey of employees at companies worldwide. While corporate executives and talent managers may be tempted to believe the talent market has returned to normal and they can go back to “business as usual” now that the economy is growing again, our survey suggests that this strategy could leave companies on the losing side of the competition for talent.
record.headline1: Talent Edge 2020: Building the recovery together
record.headline2: What talent expects and how leaders are responding

record.title: Talent Edge 2020: Redrafting Strategies for the Uneven Recovery
record.desc: The latest edition of our survey series, Talent Edge 2020, builds on the findings of the previous two reports. As economic growth revs and sputters, leadership development and succession planning emerge as key concerns. Thirty-eight percent of the surveyed executives agree that growing top-and bottom line is a priority, and 33 percent say expanding into new markets is important. But to do that, companies will need leaders capable of steering their companies on both scale (efficiency and cost) and focusing on regional markets.
record.headline1: Talent Edge 2020: Redrafting Strategies for the Uneven Recovery

record.title: TechShop
record.sub-title: A case study in work environment redesign
record.desc: Maker space provider TechShop designs for open innovation by creating a community that encourages “chance” encounters and rapid experimentation.
record.headline2: A case study in work environment redesign

record.title: The new government leader
record.sub-title: Mobilizing agile public leadership in disruptive times
record.desc: What makes an effective government leader in a world where citizens expect real-time engagement with their institutions and whose social problems often defy siloed solutions?
record.headline2: Mobilizing agile public leadership in disruptive times

record.title: The silent leader
record.desc: To reclaim a reputation for competency, government will need a culture that values capable managers, and public servants with the courage to tell the unpleasant truths to their political masters.

record.title: Three lessons about talent from Tibetan Buddhist monks
record.desc: Whether in business, extreme sports, online gaming, or other fields, there are patterns to how individuals organize for mutual learning and achieve higher levels of performance.
record.headline1: Three lessons about talent from Tibetan Buddhist monks

record.title: Time, talent, and relationships
record.desc: There are three fundamental resources that executives must manage during a transition: time, talent, and relationships.

record.title: Too bad you thought they were too good
record.desc: The common wisdom behind excluding the over-qualified is straightforward; despite an initial expectation of strong performance, employers fear the applicant will soon become bored and leave the firm.
record.headline1: Too bad you thought they were too good

record.title: Unlocking the passion of the Explorer
record.sub-title: A report in the 2013 Shift Index series
record.desc: By adopting new ways of working focused on eliciting and amplifying the passion of certain workers, organizations will benefit from the sustained performance improvement that these individuals create.
record.headline1: Unlocking the passion of the Explorer
record.headline2: A report in the 2013 Shift Index series

record.title: W. L. Gore
record.sub-title: A case study in work environment redesign
record.desc: The maker of Gore-Tex fabrics embraces fluid teaming and “dabble time” as ways to spur productivity and encourage innovation.
record.headline2: A case study in work environment redesign

record.title: What Darwin can teach government
record.sub-title: Harnessing "positive deviants" to help solve vexing problems within your organization
record.desc: Like species, workforces can go through an evolutionary process, driven by individuals with unusual but favorable behaviors—“positive deviants.” Here’s how organizations can nurture these behaviors.
record.headline2: Harnessing "positive deviants" to help solve vexing problems within your organization

record.title: Winning friends and influencing stakeholders
record.desc: A new CFO can do three important things to create supportive relationships with stakeholders—from the CEO down—to effectively execute important priorities.

record.title: Work environment redesign
record.sub-title: Accelerating talent development and performance improvement
record.desc: The way the workplace is constructed—physically, virtually, and managerially—can have a critical impact on employee productivity, passion, and innovation.
record.headline2: Accelerating talent development and performance improvement

record.title: Passion at work
record.sub-title: Cultivating worker passion as a cornerstone of talent development
record.desc: By cultivating the traits of worker passion in their workforce, organizations can make sustained performance gains and develop the resilience they need to withstand continuous market challenges and disruptions.
record.authors: John Hagel|John Seely Brown|Alok Ranjan|Daniel Byler
record.headline2: Cultivating worker passion as a cornerstone of talent development

record.title: Workforce resilience
record.sub-title: An international comparison of the public and private sectors
record.desc: Government workforces have not been immune to the pressures of the Great Recession and the volatility of recent years. How have governments around the world responded?
record.headline2: An international comparison of the public and private sectors

record.title: Workplace redesign
record.desc: As individuals and organizations experience the increasing pressures of the Big Shift, where better to do creative and revolutionary things than in our workplaces?

record.title: You’ve found the passionate. Now what?
record.desc: Supporting the learning of the passionate is the other half of the equation.
record.headline1: You’ve found the passionate. Now what?

record.title: Zappos
record.sub-title: A case study in work environment redesign
record.desc: Internal wikis and blogs, skills-based advancement, and weekly “Zuddles” to garner feedback from peers all figure prominently in Zappos’ famously egalitarian, customer-oriented culture.
record.headline2: A case study in work environment redesign

record.title: Deloitte Review
record.desc: Deloitte Review explores ideas and issues that are top of mind for today's forward-thinking organizations, helping business and government leaders better understand and capitalize upon the macro forces that are shaping the marketplace. Each issue brings together insights from subject-matter specialists on a diverse range of topics, from health care reform and cyber risk to big data, behavioral economics, the Internet of Things, and more.

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 1
record.desc: Life’s most rewarding opportunities aren’t all that easy. Playing scales for years won’t make you a concert pianist. And even if a clutch and manual gearbox set your blood racing, years of navigating the parking deck at the office won’t have you racing historic sports cars. So it goes with business, where the success that gets a company to shareholder and business school-darling status demands more than balancing the books and pushing product out the door on time.

record.title: Culture and the Myth of the Black Box
record.sub-title: Why you can—and should—manage your company's culture
record.desc: Culture is often viewed as the magical elixir that makes great companies great and there is ample evidence that cultures steeped in innovation, fellowship and other good things have a pervasive effect. But culture is not an arcane art. It is the outcome of decisions—conscious or otherwise—about an organization and the best companies take an active hand in managing their cultures.
record.headline1: Culture and the Myth of the Black Box
record.headline2: Why you can—and should—manage your company's culture

record.title: On convergence: A conversation with Forbes publisher Rich Karlgaard
record.desc: New media have changed overnight our perspectives on news, information and entertainment. Can print survive — profitably? Are video podcasts destined to replace television? What will the publishing industry look like in a decade? In an excerpt from the recently published Convergence Conversations, Ed Moran interviews Rich Karlgaard, publisher of Forbes magazine.
record.headline1: On convergence: A conversation with Forbes publisher Rich Karlgaard

record.title: The Overconfidence Trap
record.sub-title: Getting it half-right won’t work in the high-stakes game of M&A integration
record.desc: Conventional wisdom gets a bad rap. Much of what we intuitively know about mergers and acquisitions—and there is a sagging bookshelf on the subject—is borne out by the facts. But being “almost right” about expectations and priorities isn’t enough. The reality is far more nuanced.
record.headline2: Getting it half-right won’t work in the high-stakes game of M&A integration

record.title: The Service Revolution
record.desc: For manufacturers, services have often been regarded as an onerous obligation and stocking spares a complex and thankless sort of business that gives cost accountants ulcers. Yet with unprecedented pressures on product margins and the threat of commoditization, services may the best opportunity for profit and differentiation.

record.title: The Strategy Paradox
record.sub-title: An excerpt from the newest perspective on those surprise twins, success and failure
record.desc: According to author Michael Raynor, most strategies are built on specific beliefs about the future. Despite our fixation on forecasts, however, no one can predict the future, making it risky to bet the house on even the most brilliant strategy. Yet breakthrough success requires true commitment to a strategy. How can companies resolve this paradox?
record.headline2: An excerpt from the newest perspective on those surprise twins, success and failure

record.title: The Two Faces of Risk
record.sub-title: Cultivating risk intelligence for competitive advantage
record.desc: Enlightened executives don’t just worry about bad things that could happen, such as the theft of sensitive customer data. They also sweat the good things that might occur—the next hit product. How well does your organization anticipate and manage the various incarnations of risk?
record.headline2: Cultivating risk intelligence for competitive advantage

record.title: Wealth with Wisdom
record.desc: Getting older is a fact of life, but for businesses an aging society presents unique opportunities — and pitfalls. From product design, to the packaging of products and services, the changing needs of an affluent older generation require a systematic look by executives hoping to serve it profitably.

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 10
record.desc: We each have a calling. It might be revealed in the intense focus of Formula One racing champion Sebastian Vettel, whose mechanical intuition helped him nurse a car with gearbox problems to second place in the 2011 Brazilian Grand Prix. Or the intuitive directing of Clint Eastwood. Or the designer’s eye of the late Steve Jobs. We romanticize the accomplishments of talented individuals, but companies often have their own version of a calling.

record.title: A Delicate Balance
record.desc: For analytics projects to succeed, the strengths and limitations of data-driven analytics and expert decision-making must counterbalance each other. “Data mining” must give way to “data dialogues”.

record.title: At the Court of King Henry
record.sub-title: A visit and conversation with Henry Chesbrough on all things open innovation and the challenges of sustaining the open business model
record.desc: Since Henry Chesbrough’s first book on open innovation was published in 2003, the idea has become a widely accepted model of innovation management. It is founded on the theory that companies should become adept at looking beyond their own four walls to trade unused intellectual property and source new ideas from third parties back into their own organizations in order to stimulate their stagnating innovation processes.
record.headline1: At the Court of King Henry
record.headline2: A visit and conversation with Henry Chesbrough on all things open innovation and the challenges of sustaining the open business model

record.title: Headwinds, tailwinds and the riddles of demographics
record.desc: Demographic trends and their influences on workforces vary widely between countries and regions. Different regions — even countries within regions — are in different stages with regard to current and future labor forces, suggesting that labor strategies should be tailored to the local situation. That variation brings both complexity and opportunities for companies with a presence in several regions.
record.headline1: Headwinds, tailwinds and the riddles of demographics

record.title: I Have Not Yet Begun to Shop … Or Have I?
record.sub-title: Smarter phones, smarter shoppers and strategies for a new consumer perspective
record.desc: Smartphone-equipped consumers remain a minority, yet their attitudes and behaviors, as well as increasingly capable devices and a proliferation of mobile applications, suggest a much larger customer base in the future. For these mobile consumers, the pre-store and in-store shopping process is being redefined with a range of players vying for a prominent role in enabling, guiding and constructing business models around those consumers.
record.headline1: I Have Not Yet Begun to Shop … Or Have I?
record.headline2: Smarter phones, smarter shoppers and strategies for a new consumer perspective

record.title: Integrated reporting: The new big picture
record.desc: Integrated reporting aims to incorporate everything from strategy through risk management; from financial reporting to the inclusion of other capitals (societal and environmental impacts), and to meet the needs of a broad a group of stakeholders. It intends to interlink these elements in a way that makes their interdependencies clear. In doing so, it may represent the most significant change to the reporting rulebook in years.
record.headline1: Integrated reporting: The new big picture

record.title: Is Your Corporate Footprint Stuck in the Mud?
record.desc: Geography is a key driver of corporate performance, affecting factors such as talent attraction and retention, operating costs, exposure to risk and shareholder value. Companies that proactively manage their global footprint — in good and not-so-good times — can gain a competitive advantage that is difficult to replicate, literally positioning the organization globally to achieve its strategic objectives, both in the short term and for the future.
record.headline1: Is Your Corporate Footprint Stuck in the Mud?

record.title: Making the most of your marketing DNA
record.desc: Most marketing organizations execute the same basic activities. But not all great marketing organizations make identical choices. Both the great brand-builder and the great product innovators can be great marketers, but the underlying capabilities and choices that allow each to succeed are different and not necessarily interchangeable. Knowing this can influence how a company invests its incremental marketing dollars.
record.headline1: Making the most of your marketing DNA

record.title: Sustainability 2.0
record.sub-title: Using sustainability to drive business innovation and growth
record.desc: Sustainability can drive innovation by introducing new design constraints that shape how key resources are used in products and processes.
record.headline2: Using sustainability to drive business innovation and growth

record.title: The mobile elite
record.sub-title: Tactics for growth in a 4G world
record.desc: With the growing ubiquity of mobile devices comes a set of unique challenges for companies riding the wireless wave of opportunity. Throw the impending arrival of the broadband 4G era into the mix and uncertainty levels are set to spike as the scramble for competitive advantage intensifies. But how can companies ride out this volatility? In the short term, viable pathways to growth need to be secured — or else the masters of mobile risk being marginalized by a growing army of upstarts.
record.headline2: Tactics for growth in a 4G world

record.title: The talent paradox
record.sub-title: Critical skills, recession and the illusion of plenitude
record.desc: Despite high unemployment, companies are having trouble filling job vacancies, with shortages often occurring in critical, skilled roles with high barriers to entry and crucial to a company’s success. A targeted retention strategy, with an increasingly sophisticated view of what employees are looking for, what they value and why they leave, can help companies navigate this talent paradox.
record.headline2: Critical skills, recession and the illusion of plenitude

record.title: To Thine Own Self Be True
record.sub-title: Sustaining superior performance requires knowing what should change and what should stay the same
record.desc: Case-based analysis suggests that although each of three types of strategic change—Position, Market and Competency—can succeed, changing Position brings with it the greatest risks, while changing Markets and Competencies are typically more successful paths to enduring performance. These observations can help managers see more clearly both the risks and rewards of the different types of strategic change available to them, and to assess their options accordingly.
record.headline1: To Thine Own Self Be True
record.headline2: Sustaining superior performance requires knowing what should change and what should stay the same

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 11
record.desc: We often hear “technology” and “tool” used as synonyms. It’s intuitive to regard a commercial website as a digital storefront, for example, and email as an alternative to the postal system. But a better analogy, harkening back to my geology texts from college, might be eolian systems—wind, which alters landscapes slowly and can erode or empower what it touches. It can propel objects designed with it in mind.

record.title: Cloud Hits the Enterprise
record.sub-title: Five things business leaders need to know about cloud computing and software-as-a-service
record.desc: Businesses of every shape and size are using cloud and SaaS to gain rapid access to world-class IT capabilities without having to invest in acquiring, developing and maintaining their own systems and applications. Despite its technological allure, however, SaaS is not always the plug-and-play panacea imagined. How ready is your organization?
record.headline2: Five things business leaders need to know about cloud computing and software-as-a-service

record.title: Cloud Wars
record.sub-title: How incumbents can respond to cloud disruption
record.desc: Cloud computing and fast-moving, innovative start-ups seem a natural match. Yet some very large incumbents have been using the cloud to leverage their natural advantages in relationships associated with an existing customer base, capabilities and often considerable assets, and in-house data than can be mashed with information and insights from public sources. The “perfect” cloud organization may be larger than stereotypes would suggest.
record.headline2: How incumbents can respond to cloud disruption

record.title: Decision quality: Improving value from capital allocation
record.desc: Without well-developed decision systems and processes to address the complexities of capital allocation, organizations often resort to long, drawn-out debates; politicking and gaming the system; the gut instincts of a brave executive and staff; or deferring to quantitative analysis alone. With large amounts at stake, the opportunities for improved decision quality can be considerable.
record.headline1: Decision quality: Improving value from capital allocation

record.title: From Mad Man to Superwoman
record.sub-title: The inevitable rise of the chief marketing officer in the age of the empowered consumer
record.desc: The Chief Marketing Officer role is as high as it gets in marketing—but so are the expectations that go with it. To deliver, CMOs will need to adopt new operational frameworks for harnessing the art, science and individuals involved.
record.headline2: The inevitable rise of the chief marketing officer in the age of the empowered consumer

record.title: Growth through M&A: Promise and reality
record.desc: Mergers and acquisitions can be a potent path to growth. Yet implementation complexities and the lure of immediate cost synergies often take precedence over formulating, isolating and tracking revenue metrics and growth efforts. Cost reduction goals can even conflict with revenue growth opportunities. An analysis of 100 deals with growth as the stated goal suggests a set of priorities that can produce better outcomes.
record.headline1: Growth through M&A: Promise and reality

record.title: Pulling Ahead vs. Catching Up
record.sub-title: Tradeoffs and the quest for exceptional profitability
record.desc: To pull away from the pack one needs to break performance tradeoffs by getting better in several ways at once. The struggle for greatness, however, is far more complex and subtle. Prevailing over capable adversaries requires accepting and exploiting tradeoffs and very often seeking an advantage in only a very small number of very carefully identified ways, while frequently accepting a performance disadvantage along other dimensions.
record.headline2: Tradeoffs and the quest for exceptional profitability

record.title: The Automation Evolution
record.sub-title: How I learned to stop worrying and love the future of manufacturing
record.desc: Emerging trends in the next phase of manufacturing’s evolution have already begun to alter the competitive landscape. Labor arbitrage is ceding center stage to emerging production technologies and the associated talent models required to realize their potential. Companies that treat manufacturing as a strategic lever, rather than solely as a cost management exercise will likely be well positioned as the next generation of manufacturing takes hold.
record.headline2: How I learned to stop worrying and love the future of manufacturing

record.title: The engagement economy: How gamification is reshaping businesses
record.desc: While elements of gamification — leaderboards, badges and levels — have appeared in a business context for years, recent technologies are driving increased interest and greater potential in this field. Real-time data analytics, mobility, cloud services, and social media platforms can accelerate and improve the outcomes of gamification, while a broader understanding of behavioral science suggests new applications.
record.headline1: The engagement economy: How gamification is reshaping businesses

record.title: The Ito Factor
record.sub-title: In the world of digital start-ups, Joi Ito is a bona fide rock star, but the outspoken entrepreneur faces his biggest challenge yet in revitalizing MIT’s venerable Media Lab
record.desc: Joi Ito is a sage voice on the Internet, web innovation and technology policy, with a keen interest in communities and the role of technology in community innovation. An early investor in start-ups such as Twitter and Flickr, he established a powerful network that saw his impact in the Valley soar. More recently, Ito made headlines when he was named director of the world renowned MIT Media Lab.
record.headline2: In the world of digital start-ups, Joi Ito is a bona fide rock star, but the outspoken entrepreneur faces his biggest challenge yet in revitalizing MIT’s venerable Media Lab

record.title: The price of pricing effectiveness: Is the view worth the climb?
record.desc: Great companies do pricing very well, and reap the rewards. For those that don’t, however, establishing or broadening these capabilities can be a complex, risky and sometimes costly investment that requires specific skills and commitment on the part of leadership. Research suggests measures that can reduce that risk and position a company more advantageously with regard to pricing as a strategic tool.
record.headline1: The price of pricing effectiveness: Is the view worth the climb?

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 12
record.desc: Behavioral economists and cognitive scientists seem to have made a career out of showing how our judgments tend to be wrong in glaring ways. In the case of big data—the pervasive term for the expanded and growing pool of data available to power business decisions—they may once again be onto something. When it comes to identifying the right data, we’re more often impulse buyers than paragons of analytical skill.

record.title: As one
record.sub-title: Better collaboration where it counts the most
record.desc: As any frustrated executive can vouch, the best plans count for naught if they are not implemented. Yet what exists, other than gut instinct, to inform leaders’ decisions around organizational engagement? In focusing on strategy execution and changes that depend on large numbers of people working together, we identify three factors that are present when organizations achieve their goals.
record.headline2: Better collaboration where it counts the most

record.title: Big data 2.0
record.sub-title: New business strategies from big data
record.desc: For many businesses, research suggests that the focus on efforts related to big data has been largely on improved efficiency and operations. While those opportunities are impressive, the possibilities as to how big data might be used to ask new business questions and meet market needs can be even more intriguing.
record.headline2: New business strategies from big data

record.title: Finding the value in environmental, social, and governance performance
record.desc: Not surprisingly, environmental, social, or governance issues can trigger a crisis that leads to fundamental changes in a company’s management, culture, and of course its financial health. As investors seek value from ESG, however, there is evidence that companies demonstrably prepared for these shocks can better mitigate downside risks, capture investor interest, and establish the long-term value of ESG management.
record.headline1: Finding the value in environmental, social, and governance performance

record.title: Getting ahead of the “ripple effect”
record.sub-title: A framework for a water stewardship strategy
record.desc: Water scarcity creates risks and opportunities. While companies seek to manage and mitigate impacts such as higher water costs, disruption to water-dependent operations, regulatory and pricing changes, and loss of social license to operate, a water stewardship strategy should also help business leaders identify and pursue value-creating initiatives, from cost reduction and innovation to a reputation that creates further opportunities.
record.headline2: A framework for a water stewardship strategy

record.title: Reframing the talent agenda
record.sub-title: The shift, the race, and the riddle
record.desc: Talent remains a top concern for business leaders—not the availability of workers so much as the shortage of critical skills, experiences, and specialized capabilities of leaders, managers, creators, and producers required in changing industries. Yet the employee view of this talent paradox is also revealing and points to an emerging agenda around a "war to develop talent."
record.headline2: The shift, the race, and the riddle

record.title: Telling a story with data
record.desc: Despite the respect it commands in concept, analytics can be difficult to explain and understand. As a result, analytical capabilities may not get used effectively as decision makers fall back on their intuition or experience. Yet there are approaches that can help quantitative analysts tell a story with data and tactics that can help decision makers develop beneficial relationships with analysts.

record.title: The Mobile Chasm
record.sub-title: Bridging the gap between expectations and the as-is
record.desc: There is little argument that mobile has been transforming business models and marketplaces at a surprising rate. Yet there is a big disconnect between consumer and employee expectations and corporate mobile offerings, including those of larger companies. The full potential remains untapped, hindered in part by an assumption that mobile is next in a line of regimented technology projects.
record.headline2: Bridging the gap between expectations and the as-is

record.title: The profit parfait
record.sub-title: Exploring the deeper layers of corporate profitability
record.desc: In previous articles, the authors established the importance of retaining a differentiated, nonprice position in the market. Exceptional companies face a trade-off between increasing ROA through return on sales (ROS) or through total asset turnover (TAT), and the best performers systematically choose higher ROS. We now focus on the primary driver of superior profitability, ROS, and on its determinants: revenue and cost.
record.headline2: Exploring the deeper layers of corporate profitability

record.title: The rise of safety innovations in intelligent mobility
