record.desc: The pursuit of vehicle safety is a key driver in the emergence of a new stage of intelligent transportation systems, involving new technologies and business opportunities. A whirlwind of changes may disrupt industry dynamics, ushering in new players and shifting the roles of established ones. Still, there are challenges that these potentially transformative new technologies will have to overcome.
record.headline1: The rise of safety innovations in intelligent mobility

record.title: Too big to ignore
record.sub-title: When does big data provide big value?
record.desc: Much of the language surrounding big data conveys a muddled conception of what data, “big” or otherwise, means to the majority of organizations pursuing analytics strategies. Big data is shrouded in hyperbole and confusion, which can be a breeding ground for strategic errors. Big data is a big deal, but it is time to separate the signal from the noise.
record.headline2: When does big data provide big value?

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 13
record.desc: Can we define innovation in a way that is useful, and recognize what it is – and what it isn’t? With this issue of Deloitte Review, we consider the strategic implications of getting that definition right (or wrong), and explore opportunities for innovation in talent acquisition, data marketplaces, and technology.

record.title: Courting the candidate-customer
record.desc: Brand-conscious companies are beginning to interact with potential employees with the same care they would give to their customers. They are redefining the talent acquisition experience by making sure their candidate-customers gain tangible value from the interview process and have the capabilities to navigate and succeed within the organization should they be offered a position.

record.title: Data as the new currency
record.sub-title: Government’s role in facilitating the exchange
record.desc: Government is one of the biggest producers of data—and one of the few that deliver data to the public free of charge. Governments already regulate how organizations may use personal data and myriad other issues related to data. The question, then, isn’t really whether government should get involved in the new data marketplace, but rather how it should take part.
record.headline2: Government’s role in facilitating the exchange

record.title: Disegno di Pininfarina
record.desc: The chairman of the venerable Italian design house discusses creativity the Italian way, how to extend a luxury brand into new markets, and how to bring tradition forward into a technology-driven world—and of course offers his opinion on his company’s best-ever Ferrari design.

record.title: Innovation: A chimera no more
record.desc: Innovation is celebrated far and wide, but the lack of a shared, accurate definition has undermined our collective ability to manage it effectively. The implications are anything but academic. Companies that treat an attack based on differentiation as if it were breaking important trade-offs may overreact, but mistake a true innovator for the merely different and the pain can last for decades.

record.title: Location, learning, and logistics
record.sub-title: A framework for managing trade-offs in capacity location decisions
record.desc: Business leaders who misjudge the location of production relative to the location of product and process development resources may adversely impact the company’s long-term competitive position. We explore the link between production location decisions, the nature of the capabilities required to create a product, and the ability of a company to develop the next-generation technologies it may seek.
record.headline2: A framework for managing trade-offs in capacity location decisions

record.title: Making open innovation work in mobile
record.desc: Select semiconductor companies have taken the standard open innovation playbook and are evolving and shape-shifting critical elements in order to lead innovation in mobile—with a specific emphasis on five tactics that seem to have paid off. Turning our attention to prominent new markets in sectors undergoing rapid transition, we have seen growth opportunities flourish for those able to compete with innovative mobile business models.
record.headline1: Making open innovation work in mobile

record.title: Multirational multinationals
record.desc: A growing number of influential companies are adopting the position that business should no longer cede the solving of social problems solely to government and nonprofits. When larger societal problems are seen not as just charity but as market opportunities, then actions by business are more scalable and viable over the long term.

record.title: The future of health care insurance: What’s ahead?
record.desc: The US health insurance industry plays a ubiquitous role in the nation’s economy. Major changes are afoot—from employer activism, to increased participation in government-sponsored health insurance plans, to the state-by-state implementation of the Affordable Care Act of 2010. The implications for products and services, costs, and the role of trust in the system are worth a closer look.
record.headline1: The future of health care insurance: What’s ahead?

record.title: The open talent economy
record.sub-title: Beyond corporate borders to talent ecosystems
record.desc: What the open source model did for software development, the open talent economy is doing for work. Today’s younger, connected, and mobile workers are managing their careers on their own terms and often outside categories that have defined the workforce for decades. Organizations will need to reassess what they have to offer talent and even what it means to “have” talent in the first place.
record.headline2: Beyond corporate borders to talent ecosystems

record.title: Three rules
record.desc: In their recently published The Three Rules: How Exceptional Companies Think, the authors suggest that such companies all follow the same recipe but use different ingredients, and that they deliver superior levels of performance for longer than anyone has a right to expect. Is persistent, exceptional performance a function of deep moats and thick ramparts, or agility and flexibility in response to competition?

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 14
record.desc: Must behavioral-based big data erode trust in the name of profit? Deloitte Review issue 14 delves into socially responsible innovation, with other features on high performance manufacturers and supply chains; additive manufacturing paths to performance; and a better answer to the “virtual versus campus” debate.

record.title: 3D opportunity: Additive manufacturing paths to performance, innovation, and growth
record.desc: Additive manufacturing technology can break existing performance trade-offs by reducing the capital needed to achieve scale and scope economies. Understanding how this can be done requires a review of how scale and scope economies shape certain product manufacturing and distribution decisions.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity: Additive manufacturing paths to performance, innovation, and growth

record.title: Beyond Yahoo: Breaking down the “virtual” versus “campus” debate
record.desc: Marissa Mayer’s decision to revoke Yahoo’s telecommuting policy stirred the debate about flexible workplace strategies. Is the move to virtual work inevitable? Both virtual work and campus-based approaches have benefited employers who use them. Hybrid models, which couple elements of campus and virtual models, can offer the best of both.
record.headline1: Beyond Yahoo: Breaking down the “virtual” versus “campus” debate

record.title: The datafication of HR
record.desc: HR departments capture enormous amounts of data, but these typically stagnate in various systems and are rarely used for strategic purposes. It’s not that companies haven’t tried, with HR data warehouses and “HR analytics” teams that run reports. But the returns have been frustrating—until recently.

record.title: Democratizing technology: Crossing the “CASM” to serve small and medium businesses
record.desc: SMBs are an attractive yet challenging market for technology companies. Fortunately, by applying current technology tools—cloud, analytics, social, and mobile—technology companies can exploit new ways of effectively redeploying existing products, services, and people to stay ahead of evolving SMB needs.
record.headline1: Democratizing technology: Crossing the “CASM” to serve small and medium businesses

record.title: A design for life: An hour with Alain de Botton
record.desc: Philosopher and author Alain de Botton talks with Scott Wilson on what it means to be a philosopher in the modern age, explains his views on enlightened capitalism, and discusses what we should all do to navigate the pleasures and sorrows of work and make our lives more meaningful.
record.headline1: A design for life: An hour with Alain de Botton

record.title: Disrupting the CHRO: Following in the CFO’s footsteps
record.desc: Much as CFOs evolved from their money-counter roots to become the CEO’s strategic partner, CHROs are on the cusp of a transformation as they focus on an asset that is critical for corporate growth.
record.headline1: Disrupting the CHRO: Following in the CFO’s footsteps

record.title: Found in translation: The lingua franca of exceptional performance
record.desc: The three rules that provided the title for Raynor and Ahmed’s recent book on exceptional performance are based on the large-scale and detailed study of American corporations. But do these findings mean anything outside of the American context? Do they need to be adapted? Are they even relevant?
record.authors: Michael E. Raynor|Mumtaz Ahmed|Rob Del Vicario
record.headline1: Found in translation: The lingua franca of exceptional performance

record.title: Cracking the genetic code of high-performing manufacturers
record.desc: What enables high-performing manufacturers to excel consistently? How are they positioning themselves for the future? How do they differentiate themselves? And what capabilities are table stakes? We examine the capabilities that set high-performing manufacturers apart today, and likely will in the future.
record.authors: Craig A. Giffi|Bharath Gangula|Michelle Drew Rodriguez
record.headline1: Cracking the genetic code of high-performing manufacturers

record.title: The personalized and the personal: Socially responsible innovation through big data
record.desc: The possibility of creating data products and services fueled by fine-grained behavioral information, and informed by behavioral science and choice architecture, offers a framework for innovations that enhance rather than diminish public trust. Organizations that take such ideas on board can distinguish themselves through superior, consumer-oriented product design.
record.headline1: The personalized and the personal: Socially responsible innovation through big data

record.title: From risk to resilience: Using analytics and visualization to reduce supply chain vulnerability
record.desc: Complex supply chains require sophisticated, connected tools to monitor risks, predict disruptions, and support rapid recovery as part of an overall resilience strategy. For leading companies, this line of thinking has led to an increase in adoption of advanced tools grounded in analytics and visualization.
record.headline1: From risk to resilience: Using analytics and visualization to reduce supply chain vulnerability

record.title: The answer is 9,142: Understanding the influence of disruption risk on inventory decision making
record.desc: The question was how many units of inventory a manager should order when faced with a possible disruption in supply. The correct answer is not guesswork, but based on 150 years of theory and practice. We examine individual choices made in this critical situation—and the results are not encouraging.
record.headline1: The answer is 9,142: Understanding the influence of disruption risk on inventory decision making

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 15
record.desc: Is the romance gone? An extensive new study suggests that Gen Y takes a more pragmatic view of car ownership. Deloitte Review issue 15 also explores analytics and predicting behavior; new players in the intellectual property arena; the economics of additive manufacturing, and the persistent problem of labor abuse in supply chains.

record.title: 3D opportunity for production: Additive manufacturing makes its (business) case
record.desc: The business case for additive manufacturing (AM) starts with careful consideration of the direct costs driving AM and traditional production economics, and continues with an examination of less direct factors that can add dramatic value for companies and their customers.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for production: Additive manufacturing makes its (business) case

record.title: The changing nature of mobility
record.desc: Does Gen Y want the keys to the car? The results of an extensive study paint a complex mosaic of opportunities and challenges for automakers, with a large and powerful consumer segment more willing than prior generations to forego vehicle ownership altogether.
record.authors: Craig A. Giffi|Joe Vitale|Michelle Drew Rodriguez|Bharath Gangula

record.title: Two dogmas of big data: Understanding the power of analytics for predicting human behavior
record.desc: The vogue for big data obscures the fact that the economic value of analytics projects often has as much to do with the psychology of de-biasing decisions and the sociology of corporate culture change as with the volumes and varieties of data involved.
record.headline1: Two dogmas of big data: Understanding the power of analytics for predicting human behavior

record.title: Behavioral traps and innovation: What innovators can learn from investors’ failures
record.desc: The field of behavioral finance has identified persistent biases that affect investment decisions. Similarly, the pursuit of innovation entails a future orientation, uncertainty, and tensions between the long- and short-term—shared traits that suggest lessons learned from the former can inform the latter.
record.headline1: Behavioral traps and innovation: What innovators can learn from investors’ failures

record.title: The cash paradox: How record cash reserves are influencing corporate behavior
record.desc: Financial conservatism served companies well in the downturn but in an economic recovery may be dragging companies into a vicious circle of cash accumulation at the expense of investment in growth. New research suggests markets are more rewarding of companies spending astutely in the pursuit of growth.
record.headline1: The cash paradox: How record cash reserves are influencing corporate behavior

record.title: Supply unchained: Fighting labor abuse in your supply chain
record.desc: The persistence of labor abuse reflects the complexity of the problem and its resistance to many of the solutions currently in place. Leaders should avoid the search for silver bullets and instead focus on incremental steps that consistently improve the status quo.
record.headline1: Supply unchained: Fighting labor abuse in your supply chain

record.title: Wizards and trolls: Accelerating technologies, patent reform, and the new era of IP
record.desc: Not long ago, protecting intellectual property was primarily the purview of technology and pharmaceutical companies. More recently, however, industries in the path of these accelerating technologies have begun to find themselves grappling with an urgent and often critical need for IP fluency.
record.headline1: Wizards and trolls: Accelerating technologies, patent reform, and the new era of IP

record.title: Social by the numbers: An interview with Sandy Pentland
record.desc: Data and privacy, social network analysis, sensors, wearable computing, and location intelligence: Name a technological trend that’s revolutionizing commerce and society, and Sandy Pentland and MIT’s Media Lab were likely doing it before anyone else was even writing about it.
record.headline1: Social by the numbers: An interview with Sandy Pentland

record.title: Editorial: Scale and innovation
record.desc: When it comes to innovation, scale is often seen as a hindrance. Common wisdom is that the best ideas come from people with nothing to lose – the company run out of a garage. Yet many large organizations do innovate successfully, taking advantage of their scale to cultivate the patience to let an idea breathe.

record.title: Different temptations, same rules
record.desc: Do the Three Rules of exceptional performance apply to smaller companies? Differences in size and ownership structure, as well as resources and the demands of explosive growth, can make for a very different set of pressures and opportunities.
record.authors: Michael E. Raynor|Mumtaz Ahmed|Rob Del Vicario

record.title: Fueling growth: You can’t always buy what you need
record.desc: For a company that needs water for manufacturing, in its supply chain, or even for product use, a lack of access to water may jeopardize its growth. The risks point to a need to align water stewardship and business growth strategies, and to go beyond an efficiency focus.
record.headline1: Fueling growth: You can’t always buy what you need

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 16
record.desc: It’s the last mile for big data—creating products and services from crowd-based insights, and applying behavioral economics at a personal level. In addition, Deloitte Review issue 16 takes a practical look at cognitive technologies; unlocking the value of the Internet of Things; the manufacturing skills gap and how to address it; and the journey to exceptional performance.

record.title: The last-mile problem: How data science and behavioral science can work together
record.desc: If we want to act on data to get fit or reduce heating bills, we need to understand not just the analytics of the data, but how we make decisions.
record.headline1: The last-mile problem: How data science and behavioral science can work together

record.title: Cognitive technologies: The real opportunities for business
record.desc: Because cognitive technologies extend the power of information technology to tasks traditionally performed by humans, they can enable organizations to break prevailing trade-offs between speed, cost, and quality. We present a framework by which to explore where cognitive technologies can benefit your company.
record.headline1: Cognitive technologies: The real opportunities for business

record.title: Backyards without fences: Carving out territory in the changing consumer products terrain
record.desc: Today, many brands struggle to maintain relevance and a price premium. Shifts in channels and a more heterogeneous consumer base are weakening the traditional fences they once maintained around sizeable consumer populations. Building new, more effective fences amid the complexity will require a different approach.
record.headline1: Backyards without fences: Carving out territory in the changing consumer products terrain

record.title: Rising consumerism: Winning the hearts and minds of health care consumers
record.desc: The intersection between rising consumerism and a growing retail orientation in the health care sector presents challenges, some unprecedented, for existing players. We explore three shifts that health industry players should respond to, and that can set the scene for greater consumer involvement.
record.headline1: Rising consumerism: Winning the hearts and minds of health care consumers

record.title: Becoming irresistible: A new model for employee engagement
record.desc: The employee-work contract has changed, compelling business leaders to build organizations that engage employees as sensitive, passionate, creative contributors. Two years of research and discussions with hundreds of clients suggest five major elements and underlying strategies that work together to make organizations “irresistible.”
record.headline1: Becoming irresistible: A new model for employee engagement

record.title: Digital education 2.0: From content to connections
record.desc: Integrated next-generation technologies may equip students to continue their education their entire lives, and can address three goals: fortifying student skills, increasing education’s ROI, and enabling students to be innovative and entrepreneurial. Education technology providers will likely need to shift their focus from content to connections.
record.headline1: Digital education 2.0: From content to connections

record.title: Running on data: Activity trackers and the Internet of Things
record.desc: The fitness tracker on your wrist may be the most evident sign of the Internet of Things, but it is just one node resting on top of communications, analytics, policy, and even behavioral infrastructure.
record.headline1: Running on data: Activity trackers and the Internet of Things

record.title: Help wanted: American manufacturing competitiveness and the looming skills gap
record.desc: A skills gap is the US manufacturing sector’s Achilles’ heel, with nearly 3.5 million jobs at stake over the next decade. It is no longer a short-term issue of filling current hard-to-fill open positions, or one that can reasonably be expected to be solved in time by government policy-makers.
record.authors: Craig A. Giffi|Ben Dollar|Bharath Gangula|Michelle Drew Rodriguez
record.headline1: Help wanted: American manufacturing competitiveness and the looming skills gap

record.title: Editorial: New tools, new opportunities
record.desc: The power of emerging technologies can help organizations glean insights at a more rapid pace than ever before. This presents an opportunity for leaders to better design and more quickly adjust the talent strategies they need to compete successfully and invest confidently for the future.

record.title: A billion to one: The crowd gets personal
record.desc: The creation of products and services derived from crowd-based insights is the foundation of the “billion-to-one” experience. Taking your characteristics and behavior and contextualizing them with data from many thousands of other individuals allows designers to deliver products and services that are, or at least feel, unique.
record.headline1: A billion to one: The crowd gets personal

record.title: The journey to exceptional performance
record.desc: When it comes to corporate financial performance, we typically think in absolute terms, measuring ROA in percentage points. We are less accustomed to thinking of corporate performance in relative terms, but knowing a company’s relative performance is essential to setting and achieving performance improvement targets and, eventually, exceptional performance.
record.authors: Rob Del Vicario|Michael E. Raynor|Mumtaz Ahmed

record.title: Water as a shared challenge: From societal expectations to collective action
record.desc: Leadership by multinational companies in addressing social problems aligns with a trend for companies to internalize these issues. In the case of water, collective action can parlay awareness of this shared dependence and vulnerability into coordinated efforts with a greater impact than any single party acting alone.
record.headline1: Water as a shared challenge: From societal expectations to collective action

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 17
record.desc:
Introduction

For all of its importance and impact, the Internet of Things enables, rather than determines, an organization’s strategy. Deloitte Review issue 17 features a special section on the IoT and its associated possibilities and perils, from the balance of power between consumers and companies, to supply chains reimagined, to innovation driven by data that are uniquely human.

record.title: 3D opportunity for the future: Industry participants speak out
record.desc: Additive manufacturing continues to expand and, as the technologies move beyond prototyping, managers struggle with how to apply AM within their businesses. Data from our 3D Opportunity course suggest where stakeholders want to see AM investments made, and how to assess the benefits these avenues of choice provide.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for the future: Industry participants speak out

record.title: From groupthink to collective intelligence: A conversation with Cass Sunstein
record.desc: The concept of groupthink has seldom received the rigorous scrutiny it deserves. Noted legal scholar and author Cass Sunstein discusses how we can put the intuitive notion of groupthink on a scientific foundation, and how to promote collective intelligence to counteract that dynamic.
record.headline1: From groupthink to collective intelligence: A conversation with Cass Sunstein

record.title: A theory of relativity: Setting priorities and goals for financial performance improvement
record.desc: There is a way to measure a company’s relative performance, set targets, and estimate the probability of achieving specified targets over different time periods that allows managers to resist the pull of methods that are widely used, yet can be dangerously misleading.
record.authors: Michael E. Raynor|Mumtaz Ahmed|Derek M. Pankratz|Rob Del Vicario
record.headline1: A theory of relativity: Setting priorities and goals for financial performance improvement

record.title: Power struggle: Customers, companies, and the Internet of Things
record.desc: The data flowing through the Internet of Things can change the relationships between customers and companies, sometimes benefiting both parties. But sometimes customers, companies, or both can find themselves either failing to benefit from or potentially disadvantaged by various IoT-enabled deployments, compromising the sustainability of a given strategy.
record.headline1: Power struggle: Customers, companies, and the Internet of Things

record.title: Safeguarding the Internet of Things: Being secure, vigilant, and resilient in the connected age
record.desc: Smart, connected objects offer tremendous opportunities for value creation and capture, but can also create tremendous risk, demanding new strategies for value protection. A single vulnerable device can leave an entire ecosystem open to attack, with potential disruptions ranging from individual privacy breaches to massive breakdowns of public systems.
record.headline1: Safeguarding the Internet of Things: Being secure, vigilant, and resilient in the connected age

record.title: IoT’s about us: Emerging forms of innovation in the Internet of Things
record.desc: The observation that the Internet of Things encompasses people holds a number of transformative business and societal implications. The data and information flows that continually emanate from people and devices can be aggregated and analyzed to create fundamentally new types of products and services that go with the grain of human psychology.
record.headline1: IoT’s about us: Emerging forms of innovation in the Internet of Things

record.title: Forging links into loops: The Internet of Things’ potential to recast supply chain management
record.desc: Faced with external pressures, US companies often cut costs to remain competitive. True to form, many have focused their Internet of Things strategies on how the technology can cut costs and improve efficiency. But the IoT can also serve as a foundation for greater differentiation and innovation.
record.headline1: Forging links into loops: The Internet of Things’ potential to recast supply chain management

record.title: In the heat of corporate crisis: Mind over matter
record.desc: Behavioral science now provides some answers to why individuals and organizations can fail to recognize the road to a crisis, and suggests techniques to counteract the cognitive impediments that can make a bad situation worse.
record.headline1: In the heat of corporate crisis: Mind over matter

record.title: The more things change: Value creation, value capture, and the Internet of Things
record.desc: Some changes enabled by the Internet of Things will be incremental, while others will be transformative. Yet the need to capture value remains as acute as ever. The established principles of strategic differentiation, process flow, and network economics will go a long way toward revealing a path to long-term success.
record.headline1: The more things change: Value creation, value capture, and the Internet of Things

record.title: Deflecting the scarcity trajectory: Innovation at the water, energy, and food nexus
record.desc: Shortfalls of water, energy, and food can sabotage economic and business growth as well as compromise social well-being. Fortunately, there are signs that the public sector, private sector, and NGOs are beginning to work together to take us off the scarcity trajectory.
record.headline1: Deflecting the scarcity trajectory: Innovation at the water, energy, and food nexus

record.title: Redesigning work in an era of cognitive technologies
record.desc: Cognitive technologies, a product of the field of artificial intelligence, can and will be used to eliminate jobs. But leaders face choices about how to apply cognitive technologies. These decisions will determine whether workers are marginalized or empowered, and whether their organizations are creating value or merely cutting costs.
record.headline1: Redesigning work in an era of cognitive technologies

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 18
record.desc:
Introduction

Humans are not perfect. We overgeneralize from our personal experience, often neglect logical analyses, and are generally overconfident in our judgments. These biases extend beyond our personal lives to impact economic, regulatory, and management decisions more than we may realize. Concepts of modern psychology and behavioral economics arising from the work of Daniel Kahneman, Richard Thaler, Cass Sunstein, and others, have begun to offer tools enabling us to better shape programs, policies and products – and ultimately to design our technological future – in a human-centric spirit.

record.title: Nudging New Mexico: Kindling compliance among unemployment claimants
record.desc: Deterring small-scale fraud, such as by those who file exaggerated weekly unemployment reports, often requires more resources than the effort is worth. But by applying concepts from behavioral economics—from making a process less confusing to communicating that accurate filing is the social norm—administrators can induce more honest behavior.
record.headline1: Nudging New Mexico: Kindling compliance among unemployment claimants

record.title: HR for Humans: How behavioral economics can reinvent HR
record.desc: People may be the heart of our organizations, but HR practices are often based on outdated ideas of human psychology and organizational design. When it comes to hiring decisions, employee motivation, and helping workers make better choices, behavioral insights and evidence-based practices can drive a new generation of HR strategies.
record.headline1: HR for Humans: How behavioral economics can reinvent HR

record.title: The importance of Misbehaving: A conversation with Richard Thaler
record.desc: It’s common sense that people routinely make irrational decisions—“misbehave”—yet economics models stubbornly assume that everyone is perfectly rational. Behavioral-economics pioneer Richard Thaler explains the divide between Econs and Humans, and the role of “choice architecture” in enabling long-term goals.
record.headline1: The importance of Misbehaving: A conversation with Richard Thaler

record.title: Editorial: Behavioral insights – Putting Humans in the loop
record.desc: As the march of “smart” technologies seemingly takes on a life of its own, it is worth remembering that advances in the behavioral sciences can better enable the human-centric design of programs, technologies, and organizations.
record.headline1: Editorial: Behavioral insights – Putting Humans in the loop

record.title: 3D opportunity for engineers: Using behavioral science to help build a new mindset
record.desc: Additive manufacturing can be transformative, yet many engineers use these technologies only rarely. Behavioral economics suggests why many companies are holding back, and how to move past both organizational inertia and engineers’ mental blocks and fears about expanding the use of AM.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for engineers: Using behavioral science to help build a new mindset

record.title: Think slower: How behavioral science can improve decision making in the workplace
record.desc: We couldn’t function without fast thinking—the autopilot decisions that guide us through many ordinary situations. But fast thinking can lead us to blurt out the wrong thing in a meeting, make a poor strategic decision, or turn self-destructive. How to slow down? Cognitive behavioral therapy is proving helpful.
record.headline1: Think slower: How behavioral science can improve decision making in the workplace

record.title: Nothing for money: A behavioral perspective on innovation and motivation
record.desc: Can you pay people to innovate? Companies increasingly look to knowledge workers to advance new strategies, products, services, and processes, but making it happen is tricky: Dangling financial rewards can actually prove counterproductive. Behavioral research points to ways to effectively kindle employees’ motivation to innovate.
record.headline1: Nothing for money: A behavioral perspective on innovation and motivation

record.title: Crossing the mental Rubicon: Don’t let decisiveness backfire
record.desc: We demand that leaders be decisive, but research in social psychology and behavioral economics suggests that decisiveness is not an unequivocal good. Studies on “mindset” reveal that, when contemplating an important decision, prematurely focusing on execution can exacerbate decision-making biases and lead to overconfidence and excessive risk-taking.
record.headline1: Crossing the mental Rubicon: Don’t let decisiveness backfire

record.title: Patient engagement strategies in a digital environment: Life sciences companies respond to changing patient expectations
record.desc: In a shifting health care landscape, patients are demanding care and solutions that are coordinated, convenient, customized, and accessible. In response, nontraditional players—pharma companies in particular—are coming forward to address these emerging expectations and establish their brands for patient engagement services.
record.headline1: Patient engagement strategies in a digital environment: Life sciences companies respond to changing patient expectations

record.title: From dirt to data: The second green revolution and the Internet of Things
record.desc: The postwar transformation of agriculture saved more than a billion people from starvation—with serious unintended environmental costs. Now, a second revolution, built largely on technologies that comprise the Internet of Things, promises to make the farm of the future more productive and efficient.
record.headline1: From dirt to data: The second green revolution and the Internet of Things

record.title: Exceptional performance: A nonrenewable resource
record.desc: What happens when a company achieves the summit? Is there nowhere to go but down? Superior performance, research shows, is neither quite as fragile nor robust as many believe—rather, it’s an attainable albeit slippery plateau. The key is to focus on profitability rather than revenue growth or value creation.
record.authors: Michael E. Raynor|Derek M. Pankratz|Selvarajan Kandasamy

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 19
record.desc:
Introduction

The old image of the thrill-seeking hacker breaking into protected systems for fun seems almost quaint today. Cybercrime has gone professional, with organized crime and national governments sponsoring cyberattacks on everything from sensitive government data to corporations’ intellectual property. Still, we’re not wholly defenseless. Deloitte Review issue 19 explores ways that organizations can effectively fight back and implement measures to manage cyber risk, drawing on new technologies to make themselves stronger.

record.title: 3D opportunity for life: Additive manufacturing takes humanitarian action
record.desc: As the need for post-crisis humanitarian aid increases, additive manufacturing (AM) can have a profound impact on aid efforts. While it can start by addressing the single largest challenge in relief work—getting the aid on site—AM also has the potential to drive a new, sustainable approach to aid.
record.headline1: 3D opportunity for life: Additive manufacturing takes humanitarian action

record.title: Minds and machines: The art of forecasting in the age of artificial intelligence
record.desc: The human/artificial intelligence (AI) relationship is just heating up. So when is AI better at predicting outcomes, and when are humans? What happens when you combine forces? And more broadly, what role will human judgment play as machines continue to evolve?
record.headline1: Minds and machines: The art of forecasting in the age of artificial intelligence

record.title: Who’s buying your pricing strategy? Applying behavioral insights to understand the psychology of pricing
record.desc: Pricing products and services is a tricky business: Strategies based on utilitarian logic can fail in the face of the irrational ways humans often perceive value. Executing a winning pricing strategy starts—and ends—with understanding how customers and the front line answer the question, “Is this really worth that?”
record.headline1: Who’s buying your pricing strategy? Applying behavioral insights to understand the psychology of pricing

record.title: The new CISO: Leading the strategic security organization
record.desc: As customer data and intellectual property evolve and invite new forms of information theft, the leadership role of the chief information security officer must become stronger and more strategic—moving beyond the role of compliance monitor to help create an organizational culture of shared cyber risk ownership.
record.headline1: The new CISO: Leading the strategic security organization

record.title: Humanizing change: Developing more effective change management strategies
record.desc: Research shows that most large change management efforts fail. Why? Something’s been left out of the equation: the human element. Organizations can draw on new behavioral economics lessons to powerfully connect change to human behavior—and keep employees engaged in the process.
record.headline1: Humanizing change: Developing more effective change management strategies

record.title: Editorial: Risk powers performance
record.desc: There is no reward without risk—and this, in a world where digital technology is vital to all aspects of business, is especially true of cyber risk.

record.title: From security monitoring to cyber risk monitoring: Enabling business-aligned cybersecurity
record.desc: No IT system can catch every phishing email and data breach. But what happens when a virus infects your network? Executives from the C-suite down need to better understand today’s cyber risks, emphasizing careful monitoring and quick response plans—and, yes, prevention.
record.headline1: From security monitoring to cyber risk monitoring: Enabling business-aligned cybersecurity

record.title: Leading to chaos: A conversation with General Stanley McChrystal
record.desc: As a former US military leader in Iraq and Afghanistan, General Stanley McChrystal knows firsthand what it’s like to operate under chaotic conditions. His wartime innovations in leadership and organization could also have broad applicability for businesses as they strive to deal with kaleidoscopic change and uncertainty.
record.headline1: Leading to chaos: A conversation with General Stanley McChrystal

record.title: The hidden costs of an IP breach: Cyber theft and the loss of intellectual property
record.desc: Losing customer data to hackers can be costly and embarrassing, but losing intellectual property to cyber thieves could threaten a company’s future. The first step toward prioritizing IP protection and incident readiness: properly valuing possible IP losses.
record.headline1: The hidden costs of an IP breach: Cyber theft and the loss of intellectual property

record.title: A world beyond passwords: Improving security, efficiency, and user experience in digital transformation
record.desc: There’s a reason why so many of us use the same simple password for every login: Who can remember dozens of different combinations of numbers and letters? The good news is that technology is on the verge of rendering passwords obsolete, bolstering security as well as making users and customers happier.
record.headline1: A world beyond passwords: Improving security, efficiency, and user experience in digital transformation

record.title: Government’s cyber challenge: Protecting sensitive data for the public good
record.desc: For government, cybersecurity isn’t only a challenge—it’s a big obstacle to long-awaited digital transformation. Plus, the stakes are sky-high: Hacking public-sector information might imperil national security as well as citizens’ trust. Is government up to the task?
record.headline1: Government’s cyber challenge: Protecting sensitive data for the public good

record.title: Quantifying risk: What can cyber risk management learn from the financial services industry?
record.desc: Quantitative models to measure cyber risk—the same kinds of models widely used by financial services firms—are starting to gain broader acceptance. But risk managers may be led astray if they rely too much on models out of context. What lessons in effectively using models does the financial services industry hold for cyber risk management?
record.headline1: Quantifying risk: What can cyber risk management learn from the financial services industry?

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 2
record.desc: Madison Avenue was once the final word on what was fashionable, dependable or simply the best. While advertising is thriving, however, the isolated consumer is gone, replaced by an informed network with unprecedented access to product, pricing and company information. Likewise, companies have never been more able to learn about, and reach, customers. This transparency brings a remarkable opportunity to involve customers more thoughtfully in creating the product and service experience.

record.title: Chronic Misalignment
record.sub-title: How a simple "value language" can remove common barriers
record.desc: Why can’t all employees think like owners? A lofty goal, but one that often comes across as an empty slogan. Even if all involved want a company to prosper, do all parts of the organization really understand what makes the business succeed? We suspect not. But there’s hope.
record.headline2: How a simple "value language" can remove common barriers

record.title: IQ Improvement Starts Here
record.sub-title: Opportunities and options for gaining better control of corporate performance
record.desc: With great strides in IT, why does information quality remain the Achilles’ heel of corporate decision making? More importantly, what can we do about it?
record.headline2: Opportunities and options for gaining better control of corporate performance

record.title: On Transformation
record.sub-title: A conversation with Governor Tom Ridge
record.desc: Tom Ridge, the first secretary of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security in the wake of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, made his name as a reformer during his two-terms as governor of Pennsylvania. We spoke with Governor Ridge on topics ranging from education and business competitiveness, to the synergies between the private and public sectors. We also found out how he fared in airport security.
record.headline2: A conversation with Governor Tom Ridge

record.title: The Risk Intelligent Board
record.sub-title: Viewing the world through risk-colored glasses
record.desc: Risk is properly seen as a key issue, but too often it is delegated to various departments — the IT group manages data security, the treasury function manages credit risk, and so on. This delegation brings with it the benefits of specialized expertise. At the same time, it can obscure the unique and crucial role of the board when it comes to managing risk.
record.headline2: Viewing the world through risk-colored glasses

record.title: The View from the Glass House
record.sub-title: How to compete in the transparent marketplace
record.desc: A world in which customers—and suppliers—know seemingly everything sounds scary. Life must have been simpler when the customer was in the dark. But in fact this unprecedented access to information creates unparalleled opportunities for business leaders who can turn this access to their advantage.
record.headline1: The View from the Glass House
record.headline2: How to compete in the transparent marketplace

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 3
record.desc: Talent has the distinction of being both a crucial topic and a shorthand for some of the not-so-cleverly repackaged common sense that chokes the business shelves in bookstores. For our third issue, we’ve put aside all of those admittedly exciting demographics charts and graphs – call it the "Talent Crisis" genre of business art. Instead, we explore how people and companies shape careers, and how companies score or stumble when all of that talent is oceans away.

record.title: Deep Talent, Vast Distances
record.sub-title: Realizing the full value of global knowledge workers
record.desc: The India team is brilliant but isolated. The best people are leaving. The investment in global talent looked good on paper, but dissatisfaction permeates the organization. Offshoring has become commonplace, as the quest for knowledge workers sends executives across continents. With the right people in place, decision making and workflow take on added importance.
record.headline2: Realizing the full value of global knowledge workers

record.title: Finance Masters
record.sub-title: How finance is quietly emerging as a key to business transformation
record.desc: In assessing their companies’ strengths, executives tend not to focus on the ubiquitous finance function. Yet recent survey data suggest that many strong-performing companies, and those with superior alignment between strategic and operational goals, have elevated finance beyond stewardship and honed it to a fine competitive edge.
record.headline2: How finance is quietly emerging as a key to business transformation

record.title: Getting Pricing Right
record.sub-title: The value of a multifaceted approach
record.desc: It should be straightforward enough: Set prices according to the mathematics handed over by the pricing analytics team, and revenues will increase. Too often, intervening factors defeat the wisdom of the number crunchers, however, suggesting that pricing capabilities are something broader.
record.headline2: The value of a multifaceted approach

record.title: Mass Career Customization
record.desc: The notion of the corporate ‘ladder’ has outlived the telegraph and the typewriter, but the new realities of generational expectations and technology have eroded the usefulness of the old metaphor. More importantly, these realities suggest a model that could serve us far better.

record.title: Opening Up: The Promise and Pitfalls of Alliances
record.sub-title: Open network alliances offer tremendous promise—but with their own set of risks
record.desc: Open business models, which can bolster companies’ RandD capabilities, present an attractive route to innovation in a competitive market. Not surprisingly, alliances have become increasingly popular. Yet the results are often something less — or different — than expected.
record.headline1: Opening Up: The Promise and Pitfalls of Alliances
record.headline2: Open network alliances offer tremendous promise—but with their own set of risks

record.title: Predictably Irrational: Beer, Pricing and the Human Mind
record.sub-title: An interview with NYT bestselling author Dan Ariely
record.desc: The calculating consumer of economics texts may be a fond fiction after all. Irrationality shapes many of our decisions. But it is a systematic irrationality, which offers clues as to how we might construct environments that predispose us to make better decisions.
record.headline1: Predictably Irrational: Beer, Pricing and the Human Mind
record.headline2: An interview with NYT bestselling author Dan Ariely

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 4
record.desc: Through the lens of traditional business strategy, emerging markets look more like a quagmire than an opportunity. Transport costs are high; delivery schedules are precarious; electricity can be a luxury; and red tape comes by the spool. If not for labor arbitrage, it would be tempting to sit on the sidelines. But waiting has its costs. In Necessity Breeds Opportunity, we consider whether these constraints can also frame innovation and lead to competitive advantage.

record.title: Beyond Reproach
record.sub-title: Why compliance with anti-corruption laws is increasingly critical for multinational businesses
record.desc: For much of the last 25 years, the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act has been on the books and in the background. More recently, its enforcement has begun to be felt worldwide, and multinational business leaders will need to consider the implications.
record.headline2: Why compliance with anti-corruption laws is increasingly critical for multinational businesses

record.title: Innovation State
record.sub-title: Adapted from The Public Innovator's Playbook
record.desc: Innovation is often viewed as the province of the private sector, but the current economic climate presents an unprecedented need — and opportunity — for government to innovate in the face of crucial challenges. We preview an excerpt from The Public Innovator's Playbook, a forthcoming handbook from Deloitte Research on how the public sector can bring good ideas to fruition.
record.headline2: Adapted from The Public Innovator's Playbook

record.title: Irrational Expectations
record.sub-title: How statistical thinking can lead us to better decisions
record.desc: Predictive analytics is emerging as a practical discipline, one that can help business leaders make better decisions. In a world whose complexity in many respects has moved beyond our cognitive abilities, numbers are nothing to fear. In fact, they may be your greatest ally.
record.headline2: How statistical thinking can lead us to better decisions

record.title: Necessity Breeds Opportunity: Constraints, Innovation and Competitive Advantage
record.desc: From immense, untapped markets, to roads that would make a grown logistics director cry, emerging markets are a study in dichotomy. But the constraints that can frustrate can also frame innovation and lead to competitive advantage.
record.headline1: Necessity Breeds Opportunity: Constraints, Innovation and Competitive Advantage

record.title: Rethinking Emerging Market Strategies
record.desc: A decade ago, offshoring was synonymous with labor arbitrage, and decisions often could be made on the back of an envelope. Increasingly, however, expansion into emerging markets requires a broader look at the value chain. From market expansion to engineering and rapid product development, the opportunities are both greater and more complex.

record.title: Talent AND work: Playing to your strengths
record.desc: The match between talent and strategy is often interpreted as a need to recruit the right bodies to fit the strategy we had in mind. Often overlooked, however, are the benefits of changing the way work is defined given the team already on the ground.
record.headline1: Talent AND work: Playing to your strengths

record.title: The Responsible and Sustainable Board
record.desc: In economic downturns, good intentions can be sidelined in the name of short-term cost cutting. In the case of corporate responsibility and sustainability (CRandS), a board might be tempted to hit the pause button and wait for brighter days. But a combination of impending regulation and pervasive expectations suggests that the time for CRandS is now.

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 5
record.desc: Predicting the future is a fool’s errand. Preparing for it, however, is everyone’s business. While there is much to learn from the next hundred postmortems on the real estate boom and credit behaving badly, there are green shoots among the financial burn — signs of what may be coming next. The world after the current economic contraction promises to be a different and exciting place.

record.title: How profitable are your customers … really?
record.desc: No company can afford a flawed understanding of customer profitability, least of all in a recession when the margin for error is whisper-thin. Now may be a good time to invest in changes that can not only deliver a badly needed revenue boost but also position your company advantageously for an economic recovery.
record.headline1: How profitable are your customers … really?

record.title: IFRS Roadmap: Planning a Safe, Economical Trip
record.desc: IFRS, with proper planning, may now be comparatively economical as well as beneficial to a business.
record.headline1: IFRS Roadmap: Planning a Safe, Economical Trip

record.title: Platforms and the Open Door
record.sub-title: High stakes in platform leadership may rewrite the rules for value capture in wireless — and beyond
record.desc: Some of the world’s best companies made their name with closed, proprietary business models. But, as open innovation has gone from a trickle to flood stage, platform ownership and new ways of capturing value are challenging entire industries to rethink how they innovate and make money.
record.headline2: High stakes in platform leadership may rewrite the rules for value capture in wireless — and beyond

record.title: Solar's push to reach the mainstream
record.sub-title: The race to grid parity and the push to expand global adoption
record.desc: After decades relegated to powering calculators, parking meters and roadside telephones, solar energy is positioned to deliver abundant clean energy at an industrially scaled level. Yet without more dramatic action by governments and solar companies, solar’s great potential will go unrealized.
record.headline1: Solar's push to reach the mainstream
record.headline2: The race to grid parity and the push to expand global adoption

record.title: The Open-Minded Professor
record.sub-title: An interview with Eric von Hippel
record.desc: Professor Eric von Hippel of MIT’s Sloan School of Management is known for pioneering research that has prompted a major rethinking of how the innovation process works. Scott Wilson of Deloitte Research met with von Hippel to find out how established companies are — or could be — managing in the face of the open innovation phenomenon.
record.headline2: An interview with Eric von Hippel

record.title: Where did our employees go?
record.sub-title: Examining the rise in voluntary turnover during economic recoveries
record.desc: Nowhere to run to, the song says, and that would seem to be a reason to put talent retention strategies on hold in a recession. A recent study, however, suggests a worrisome trend accompanying economic recoveries, and a new set of problems that could hobble companies when they can least afford it.
record.headline2: Examining the rise in voluntary turnover during economic recoveries

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 6
record.desc: Life after the Great Recession likely will be quite different. And perhaps it should be. In The Long Unwinding Road, we look at the imbalances that shaped the global economy until recently. The recalibration of consumer borrowing, saving and spending worldwide suggests that the rules for consumer businesses, in particular, will change, with government policy playing a key role.

record.title: If We Can Put a Man on the Moon
record.sub-title: An excerpt from a new book on getting big things done in government
record.desc: Government is taking a larger role in commerce, and new roles in automobile manufacturing, finance and potentially health care. Media coverage focuses on partisan disagreements that impede government action. There are approaches, however, that can enable the two camps to constructively work through differences, and these strategies can also be helpful when competing visions are at play in the private sector.
record.headline1: If We Can Put a Man on the Moon
record.headline2: An excerpt from a new book on getting big things done in government

record.title: Lock It Up or Set It Free?
record.sub-title: A risk intelligent approach to data and intellectual property
record.desc: Businesses collect mountains of data and spend vast sums storing and protecting them. Yet excess data carry a steep price tag for storage, maintenance and protection, and incalculable potential costs in terms of liability. Similarly, most companies guard their intellectual property at great expense. Yet many efforts to safeguard intellection property are ineffectual or even counterproductive — depressing the value of that which they hope to protect.
record.headline1: Lock It Up or Set It Free?
record.headline2: A risk intelligent approach to data and intellectual property

record.title: Money and Borders
record.sub-title: Cross-border investments in a changing global marketplace
record.desc: Governments appear to have become bigger players in economic affairs, and we may be entering an era in which nationalist ambitions will make globalization more difficult to manage. What is clear is the need for companies and funds pursuing cross-border investments to adapt their investment strategies and operations to function effectively at the intersection of government, business and finance.
record.headline2: Cross-border investments in a changing global marketplace

record.title: On Public-Private Partnerships
record.sub-title: A conversation with Ambassador Elizabeth Frawley Bagley
record.desc: In April 2009, U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton established the Global Partnership Initiative and subsequently appointed Elizabeth Frawley Bagley as the first Special Representative for Global Partnerships. The goal: to enhance the ability of the State Department to work with foundations, corporations and non-governmental organizations on issues of common importance to the public and private sectors.
record.headline2: A conversation with Ambassador Elizabeth Frawley Bagley

record.title: Post merger integration: Hard data, hard truths
record.desc: Much common wisdom surrounding post merger integration is anecdotal, at best. An empirical examination of one of the world’s largest PMI databases suggests a set of risk factors that help define risk profiles, with each profile having a unique statistical likelihood of success and failure even before any integration measures have been implemented. These profiles can point to crucial areas on which to focus.
record.headline1: Post merger integration: Hard data, hard truths

record.title: Stimulus spending and transparency: A false sense of security?
record.desc: Many companies may underestimate the government’s intent to show accountability to the electorate and to weed out fraud. Whether by miscalculation or simple misunderstanding of how far government mandates extend, failure to comply could leave unsuspecting companies vulnerable.
record.headline1: Stimulus spending and transparency: A false sense of security?

record.title: Survival of the Fattest
record.desc: Over the last 40 years, a gradual shift in the shape of winning and losing has been playing out. The best-performing firms have seen their profitability surge. The worst performers are doing worse than ever. In the middle, however, performance is in decline even as the asset base controlled by ever more mediocre firms relegates ever-greater asset bases to stagnation.

record.title: Talking about Whose Generation?
record.sub-title: Why Western generational models can't account for a global workforce
record.desc: Differences between generations can affect the way organizations recruit and build teams, deal with change, motivate and manage people, and boost productivity and service effectiveness. Yet global companies often oversimplify their talent strategies, basing decisions on an incomplete picture of their global workforces by assuming the same generations exist across the countries where they operate.
record.headline2: Why Western generational models can't account for a global workforce

record.title: The Long Unwinding Road
record.sub-title: Global consumers and the economic unbalance
record.desc: “If something cannot go on forever, it will stop,” wrote economist Herbert Stein. In some ways, that describes the borrowing-saving imbalance in the global economy. While it may not stop soon, it is unlikely to increase and may wane. There are several scenarios through which the imbalance might be corrected, and the unwinding of that imbalance may well lead to a new path for global consumer spending.
record.headline2: Global consumers and the economic unbalance

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 7
record.desc: A decade back, technology was more about solving process problems – the systems integration discipline takes its name from a specific challenge. But the wish list was longer: better platforms for delivering and collecting information; better wireless capabilities for commerce and communication; better and more varied sensors to monitor supply chains. For the most part, that wish list has been fulfilled, and society and businesses are playing catch-up.

record.title: A Profitable Shade of Green
record.sub-title: Compounding the benefits of carbon management and sustainability measures
record.desc: The momentum behind sustainability, carbon intensity and resource scarcity seems here to stay. Proactively embracing sustainability and carbon management is no longer a philosophical or political debate. It is a strategic decision. Moreover, it can be a profitable one.
record.headline2: Compounding the benefits of carbon management and sustainability measures

record.title: A roadmap for sustainable consumption
record.desc: Sustainable consumption will require many companies innovating and collaborating across value chains and engaging consumers in a redefinition of value.

record.title: Charging Ahead
record.sub-title: Battery electric vehicles and the transformation of an industry
record.desc: Henry Ford didn’t invent the automobile, but his Model T influenced manufacturing for generations. The advent of the battery electric vehicle—sometimes viewed as an incremental change to an iconic product—may reshape the value chain and perhaps society.
record.headline2: Battery electric vehicles and the transformation of an industry

record.title: Geeks, Tweets and Cash
record.sub-title: A conversation with Riley Crane of MIT Media Lab
record.desc: Social media have emerged as a boardroom topic: there is a vague sense that something important is happening. Yet for business leaders several fundamental questions remain around social media and more broadly around the use of online social networks in enabling business models.
record.headline2: A conversation with Riley Crane of MIT Media Lab

record.title: Good Medicine or a Bitter Pill?
record.sub-title: Implications of health care reform for businesses in America
record.desc: The full implications of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, and other legislative and regulatory initiatives affecting health care, will unfold over the next decade and beyond. But the journey to a new health care system has begun, with enormous implications for American businesses.
record.headline1: Good Medicine or a Bitter Pill?
record.headline2: Implications of health care reform for businesses in America

record.title: Integrating distressed assets
record.sub-title: Creating value from a mix of opportunity and risk
record.desc: As the economy improves, the move to purchase assets in default or under bankruptcy protection has become an attractive path to growth. Often significantly discounted, they can represent the deal of a lifetime. But they also present a unique set of hazards.
record.headline2: Creating value from a mix of opportunity and risk

record.title: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
record.sub-title: How rational managers came to be seen as reckless risk-takers … but have been behaving sensibly all along
record.desc: A steady drip of research that mis-specifies the role of individual and group decision-making as a determinant of firm-level risk has combined with a surge in behavioral economics to place far too much emphasis on managers. The answer may lie with more structural elements.
record.headline1: It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World
record.headline2: How rational managers came to be seen as reckless risk-takers … but have been behaving sensibly all along

record.title: Risk intelligent decision making
record.sub-title: Ten essential skills for surviving and thriving in uncertainty
record.desc: Conventional risk management has focused on avoiding the risks to a business strategy, rather than understanding and managing the risks of the strategy itself. While the protection of existing assets is necessary, a diet of pure risk aversion likely will lead to extinction.
record.headline2: Ten essential skills for surviving and thriving in uncertainty

record.title: Signal Strength
record.sub-title: The rise and promise of asset intelligence
record.desc: From factory floors to finished goods, almost anything now can hold a sensor. The result can be an ocean of data that can overwhelm as easily as it nourishes.
record.headline2: The rise and promise of asset intelligence

record.title: Tailored to the Bottom Line
record.sub-title: People management practices and profitability in manufacturing
record.desc: People are billed as companies’ most important asset, yet people management practices are more often an afterthought than a core strategy linked to business performance. Recent research suggests that the most profitable large companies share three practice areas that set them apart.
record.headline2: People management practices and profitability in manufacturing

record.title: The battle for brands in a world of private labels
record.desc: Many consumers sense little difference between the quality of national brands and their private label counterparts as retailers focus on store brands and consumer product companies cede connections to retailers and customers. Yet there are strategies available to national brands that may level the playing field.
record.headline1: The battle for brands in a world of private labels

record.title: Three Levels of Pull: How Serendipity Can Lead to Success
record.sub-title: Adapted from The Power of Pull
record.desc: Our economy is chock-a-block with businesses that maximize efficiency at scale. They presume predictability to mass-produce and mass-market products. Yet this “push” view is no longer a path to leadership. Rather than scalable efficiency, we need scalable connectivity, learning and performance. Rather than push, we need institutions that pull.
record.headline1: Three Levels of Pull: How Serendipity Can Lead to Success
record.headline2: Adapted from The Power of Pull

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 8
record.desc: In the strategy and operations space, the cost of guessing wrong is rising. Or, as our colleagues in the renascent field of analytics suggest, the cost of guessing at all  is one we should put behind us. While there is comfort in intuition, a better answer is out there: Not acting on it represents an opportunity lost, and potentially money left on the table. In this issue ofDeloitte Review,  we consider analytics and its implications for business strategy and operations.

record.title: Beyond the contract: Driving value from the renegotiation process
record.desc: Strategic outsourcing demands a core competency in maintaining an extended network of suppliers, distributors and other partners. The recent downturn has put the focus on contract costs — understandable, but also problematic, as it overlooks the renegotiation process as a key opportunity to reassess operational efficiencies, a valuable process in its own right.
record.headline1: Beyond the contract: Driving value from the renegotiation process

record.title: Beyond the numbers: Analytics as a strategic capability
record.desc: The business landscape is rapidly changing thanks to big computing, big data and correspondingly robust machine learning and optimization techniques. Forward-thinking companies that embrace analytics early can change the competitive dynamic by executing their core competencies and strategies better than their competitors.
record.headline1: Beyond the numbers: Analytics as a strategic capability

record.title: Caught in the Middle
record.sub-title: How government contractors—and other businesses—can use analytics and continuous monitoring to address improper payment risk across the value chain
record.desc: The U.S. government now uses sophisticated analytics to identify and investigate improper payments. By adopting similar tools and processes, companies doing business with the government can reduce the risk of improper payments caused by the misdeeds of subcontractors or employees. Moreover, these tools can help any company to identify improper or erroneous payments in its own value chain.
record.headline2: How government contractors—and other businesses—can use analytics and continuous monitoring to address improper payment risk across the value chain

record.title: Common Good
record.sub-title: An interview with Lord Stephen Green, UK Minister for Trade and Investment
record.desc: Corporate social responsibility is not some kind of appendage that has to do with the philanthropic budget. It is the very essence of what the business is about and needs to be thought of as such in terms of the governance and the culture that the leaders are responsible for maintaining within the company.
record.headline2: An interview with Lord Stephen Green, UK Minister for Trade and Investment

record.title: Did You Say Free?
record.sub-title: What it takes to win in a world where “free” is the optimum point
record.desc: Free is well on its way to becoming a sustainable business model for companies that make money by giving something away. Beyond the gimmickry and the academic discussion, companies that are serious about testing the waters of Free often benefit from a set of rules and principles important to its successful application.
record.headline2: What it takes to win in a world where “free” is the optimum point

record.title: Diversity as an engine of innovation
record.sub-title: Retail and consumer goods companies find competitive advantage in diversity
record.desc: As the retail consumer landscape evolves, diverse communities represent a larger and more important part of total buying power. Forging connections with those communities effectively and for the long term depends, to a significant degree, on having an employee population that reflects the population overall, as well as specific communities served.
record.headline1: Diversity as an engine of innovation
record.headline2: Retail and consumer goods companies find competitive advantage in diversity

record.title: Rank Ignorance
record.sub-title: To get beyond the myths told of champions born of randomness we need an entirely new way to think about corporate performance
record.desc: The intent of performance rankings is to identify which companies have demonstrated exemplary performance. But to understand the relative performance of individual companies, we must strip away the influence of factors that obscure the contributions of firm-level attributes. Otherwise, it is nearly inevitable that we will derive general principles from what are fundamentally idiosyncratic and context-specific practices.
record.headline2: To get beyond the myths told of champions born of randomness we need an entirely new way to think about corporate performance

record.title: Red ink rising: Navigating the perils of public debt
record.desc: Money has been spent that has not been earned, and promises made that cannot be met. This will challenge democratic governance models in many countries, requiring systemic, structural changes to bend the government’s cost curve down. Getting from here to there requires the navigation of three distinct phases in a long journey to fiscal sustainability.
record.headline1: Red ink rising: Navigating the perils of public debt

record.title: Smarter Moves
record.sub-title: Improving the value of global mobility by aligning strategy, investments and operations
record.desc: Growth can hinge on penetrating and scaling operations in rapidly growing and emerging markets unlocked by globalization — a challenge when critical market and production opportunities and key talent are oceans away. Yet many companies continue to handle international assignments in ways similar to how they operated decades ago.
record.headline2: Improving the value of global mobility by aligning strategy, investments and operations

record.title: The Corporate Lattice
record.sub-title: A strategic response to the changing world of work
record.desc: The hierarchical structure of the corporate ladder governs how information flows and whose ideas matter, defining career success as a linear climb to the top. The ladder’s one-size-fits-all approach assumes employees are more alike than different, and want and need similar things to deliver results. But the workplace isn’t what it used to be.
record.headline2: A strategic response to the changing world of work

record.title: The great debate: Inflation, deflation and the implications for financial management
record.desc: Executives must bet on whether the economy, their industry and their business will experience rising prices or the balance sheet and operational effects of deflation. The decision is made still more difficult by the simple fact that few senior managers have had to deal with either high inflation or deflation in their careers.
record.headline1: The great debate: Inflation, deflation and the implications for financial management

record.title: Deloitte Review issue 9
record.desc: As we produce and capture increasing quantities of situational data – a trail of transactions, travels and interactions – we open the door to a revolution in deriving value from data. While we have already seen strategies founded upon the innovative use of online data, still more epic possibilities have to do with understanding and acting on behavioral, attitudinal and psychographic data.

record.title: Brand resilience
record.sub-title: Protecting your brand from saboteurs in a high-speed world
record.desc: With the continued ascent of social media and mobile technologies, brand sabotage incidents seem poised to increase. Building a great and resilient brand now requires playing aggressive defense, as well as offense. Building the capabilities to detect, respond to and recover from incidents of brand sabotage is emerging as a priority.
record.headline2: Protecting your brand from saboteurs in a high-speed world

record.title: Ecosystems for Innovation
record.sub-title: An interview with U.S. CTO Aneesh Chopra
record.desc: The advent of new digital infrastructures is enabling small groups of individuals with small investments to make a big impact, challenging traditional models of innovation. Among the prominent figures in the innovation space is US CTO Aneesh Chopra, who shares his views on the role of technology in enabling innovation.
record.headline2: An interview with U.S. CTO Aneesh Chopra

record.title: Evolve or Fail
record.sub-title: Is your security capability evolving with your business strategy?
record.desc: With policies in place for technology governance, risk and compliance, many business leaders have assigned responsibility for security to IT, confident that their fiduciary and legal obligations are being met. But a compliance oriented approach to enterprise and IT risk may overlook many of the threats that matter most.
record.headline2: Is your security capability evolving with your business strategy?

record.title: Gold Rush
record.sub-title: The scramble to claim and protect value in the digital world
record.desc: With the press of a key or swipe of a card, the Internet of Things moves information from the physical to the digital world and back again. But how can the movement of information create value for a company?
record.headline2: The scramble to claim and protect value in the digital world

record.title: Government and the Publicly Accountable Enterprise
record.sub-title: How citizens are defining the next age of intervention
record.desc: An explosion of mobile communications and social media is empowering citizens to define the next age of intervention and set new standards for public accountability. The light of transparency has never been brighter nor has the tolerance for misinformation ever been lower.
record.headline1: Government and the Publicly Accountable Enterprise
record.headline2: How citizens are defining the next age of intervention

record.title: Growth's Triple Crown
record.sub-title: When it comes to exceptional performance, the best companies don't make tradeoffs. They break them.
record.desc: It is tempting to assume that, as companies grow, they will see a decline in profitability, shareholder returns, or both. What if we could find and learn from companies that have delivered superior growth, league-leading profitability and shareholder returns at the same time? What does it take to win growth’s “triple crown”?
record.headline2: When it comes to exceptional performance, the best companies don't make tradeoffs. They break them.

record.title: I'm OK, You're OK … But Will We Be All Right?
record.sub-title: With the U.S. health care system undergoing massive change, some stakeholders are taking bold, innovative steps
record.desc: While the implications of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act remain a hot topic, the law is in some ways merely the tipping point for an industry under pressure from a variety of economic, demographic and competitive stressors. A closer look at how early innovators are tackling the dramatic change may be instructive.
record.headline1: I'm OK, You're OK … But Will We Be All Right?
record.headline2: With the U.S. health care system undergoing massive change, some stakeholders are taking bold, innovative steps

record.title: Making sense of social data
record.desc: We create data constantly, leaking information about our actions, whereabouts and characteristics. Increasingly, these data are stored, analyzed and put to use to understand us and our behaviors at an extraordinarily granular level — and forcing executives to rethink how they understand, reach and even influence their customers.

record.title: Mind the Gap
record.sub-title: What business needs to know about income inequality
record.desc: There is a widening gap between the affluent and everyone else in the US. Trends suggest the affluent will be able to spend more while the rest of the population may be seriously constrained, with widespread leveraging of home values now a memory. What are the implications for companies that sell goods and services to consumers?
record.headline2: What business needs to know about income inequality

record.title: Tearing Up the Box
record.desc: For emerging markets, the real value of innovation is its ability to create prosperity.
