Prosperity transcends economic growth to establish social stability, educational attainment and increased quality of life, resulting in a kind of virtuous cycle. This creates a foothold for further economic development.

record.title: The innovator's manifesto: A problem of prediction
record.sub-title: An excerpt from the forthcoming book, The Innovator's Manifesto
record.desc: Disruption, as originally described by Clayton Christensen, is a theory of innovation—of how particular types of new products and services achieve success or dominance in markets, often at the expense of incumbent providers. But is disruption just another theory, or does it promise predictability?
record.headline1: The innovator's manifesto: A problem of prediction
record.headline2: An excerpt from the forthcoming book, The Innovator's Manifesto

record.title: Economics
record.desc: Organizations today operate amid the constant push and pull of powerful global economic forces. If planning for the future begins with understanding the present, how will the economic trends of the day shape your organization's path?

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook
record.desc: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook offers a quarterly analysis of economic trends affecting countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook - Q1 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

This edition gives a near-term outlook for China, Japan, Malaysia, and Singapore. China continues to implement short-term fixes to the economic slowdown. Japan is starting to ease policies in order to boost growth. Malaysia is on the path of fiscal reform. And Singapore faces subdued growth due to global volatility. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook - Q2 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

This edition gives a near-term outlook for Australia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Thailand. Australia faces slowing growth. The Philippines is entering 2015 on a high. Taiwan is in the shadow of China. And Thailand’s economic recovery depends on its internal stability. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook - Q3 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

This edition gives a near-term outlook for Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea, and Vietnam, apart from a report on household debt in Asia. Indonesia’s growth story is under a shadow. Economic activity gathers pace in Singapore. South Korea’s export-oriented economy weakens. And Vietnam’s growth continues to accelerate. The special report analyzes the likely effect of rising household debt on Asian economies. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook - Q4 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

This edition gives a near-term outlook for Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Thailand. The unexpectedly severe weakness in the Chinese economy is taking a toll on these countries. Though Malaysia and the Philippines are expected to continue to grow despite this challenge, the state of the economy in Taiwan and Thailand will depend on other factors including the political situation. Read the report online or download the PDF.

record.title: China: Close to deflation?
record.desc: While China continues to implement short-term fixes to the economic slowdown, it has so far failed to implement major reforms aimed at shifting the structure of the economy.

record.title: India: Growth gaining momentum gradually
record.desc: Economic growth has been gradually picking up since the beginning of the fiscal year. However, factors such as the pace and quality of fiscal consolidation and high inflation pose downside risks.

record.title: Indonesia: Some promising signs
record.desc: The new president’s subsidy cuts signal his intent to address structural flaws in the economy. Other proposed reforms could draw interest from global businesses and help Indonesia become more competitive.

record.title: Japan: New hopes in 2015 as policymakers spring into action
record.desc: The impact of the April 2014 tax hike has been harder on economic activity than initially expected. Japan’s policy authorities are now starting to ease policies in order to boost growth.
record.headline1: Japan: New hopes in 2015 as policymakers spring into action

record.title: Malaysia: On the path of fiscal reform
record.desc: The Malaysian government has announced several actions to reform public finances, including stopping fuel subsidies and implementing a new goods and services tax.
record.headline1: Malaysia: On the path of fiscal reform

record.title: Myanmar: Riding high on foreign investment
record.desc: Economic growth is set to remain strong in the medium term on the back of FDI inflows into sectors such as telecommunications and oil and gas, but obstacles include a pre-election slowdown in reforms.
record.headline1: Myanmar: Riding high on foreign investment

record.title: Singapore: Subdued growth due to global volatility
record.desc: Singapore’s near-term growth prospects have been curbed by an uneven recovery in the global economy. An overvalued housing sector and high household debt are also on the country’s list of concerns.
record.headline1: Singapore: Subdued growth due to global volatility

record.title: Australia: Growth to limp through 2015
record.desc: Australia’s economic growth slowed further in Q4 2014. Reasons include a weak labor market, high household debt, sliding commodity prices, and poor domestic demand.

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: With this edition, we transition from being a monthly to a quarterly publication that focuses on the smaller but important economies of the Asia Pacific region.

record.title: Philippines: Entering 2015 on a high
record.desc: The Philippines’ positive momentum is likely to continue in the medium term as policymakers try to set the foundation for sustainable manufacturing and services activity.

record.title: Taiwan: In the shadow of China
record.desc: Taiwan’s economy faces contradictory influences: Lower oil prices are helping domestic demand, while the worsening condition of the Chinese economy is hurting Taiwan’s exporting prowess.
record.headline1: Taiwan: In the shadow of China

record.title: Thailand: Economic recovery depends on internal stability
record.desc: 2014 was a difficult year for Thailand’s economy. However, a recent rebound in tourism, along with the low price of oil, is expected to initiate an economic recovery.
record.headline1: Thailand: Economic recovery depends on internal stability

record.title: Prudent no more
record.sub-title: Household debt piles up in Asia
record.desc: The prudent Asian consumer is soon becoming a thing of the past, as households in many countries of the region go on a credit binge, aided by loose monetary and fiscal sops.
record.headline2: Household debt piles up in Asia

record.title: Indonesia
record.desc: President Joko Widodo, who came to power last year, is finding the going tough. Economic growth has slowed, investors appear wary, and political constraints are casting a shadow on reforms.

record.title: Singapore
record.desc: Measures to curb the inflow of low-skilled foreign workers could lead to near-term challenges, but in the long term, these measures will help Singapore remain one of the world’s most competitive nations.

record.title: South Korea
record.desc: Weakness in exports has put the South Korean economy under stress. And though consumer finances are currently good, high household debt could curb further growth in consumer spending.

record.title: Vietnam
record.desc: The year began well for Vietnam, with strong economic activity setting the stage for acceleration in GDP growth. The economy is benefitting from a recovery in domestic spending and FDI inflows.

record.title: Malaysia: Under severe stress, but not frail yet
record.desc: Economic growth lost momentum in the second quarter, driven by the introduction of the goods and sales tax and low LNG prices, but the economy is expected to maintain a robust growth track.
record.headline1: Malaysia: Under severe stress, but not frail yet

record.title: The Philippines: Going good in turbulent times
record.desc: Despite global economic uncertainty, the Philippines appears to be doing well, benefitting from strong domestic demand and a rise in public spending. With its fundamentals solid, the Philippines is likely to ride out this sluggish phase of the world economy.
record.headline1: The Philippines: Going good in turbulent times

record.title: Taiwan: China's weakness takes a toll
record.desc: Given the fact that Taiwan’s economy is closely intertwined with that of China—Taiwan’s exports to China and Hong Kong account for 40 percent its total exports—the current weakness in the Chinese economy is likely to affect Taiwan’s growth.
record.headline1: Taiwan: China's weakness takes a toll

record.title: Thailand: A lackluster recovery
record.desc: Thailand’s economic growth continues to be reined in by weak investment, perilously high household debt, an uneven global recovery, and an uncertain political future.

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook, Q1 2016
record.desc: This edition gives a near-term outlook for Australia, Indonesia, Singapore, and South Korea. The Australian economy’s move away from export-driven to domestic demand-driven activity could help it sustain growth. In Indonesia, uncertainty continues due to the impending rate hike by the US Federal Reserve and China’s weak economic data. Singapore is going through a rough patch, driven by both internal and external economic forces. And South Korea counts on domestic demand to drive growth.

record.title: Asia Pacific Economic Outlook, Q3 2016
record.desc: This edition gives the near-term economic outlook for Australia, Indonesia, Singapore, and South Korea and includes a special article defending Hong Kong’s currency peg. In Australia and Indonesia, flagging business investments are a cause for concern, while South Korea struggles with a lag in exports and Singapore’s economy faces both cyclical and structural problems. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Packing a mightier punch: Asia’s economic growth among global markets continues
record.desc: The recent strong global impact of weakness in the Chinese economy has made it clear that China is now a powerful economic force. Other Asian countries such as India, Japan, and South Korea are also strong, and the region’s ascendancy in the global economy is likely to continue.
record.headline1: Packing a mightier punch: Asia’s economic growth among global markets continues

record.title: Australia: Economic rebalancing will boost growth
record.desc: The composition of the Australian economy is gradually shifting from export-driven activities to those driven by domestic demand and from the resources to the nonresources sectors. These shifts, in response to declining mining investment and a fall in commodity prices, are expected to help the economy sustain growth.
record.headline1: Australia: Economic rebalancing will boost growth

record.title: Indonesia: Trudging through uncertain times
record.desc: Indonesia’s economy is moving at a moderate pace in the midst of uncertainty due to the impending rate hike by the Fed, along with weakness in China. Though exports have been weak, key components of the economy, such as private consumption, seem to be in place.

record.title: Singapore: Steering through challenging times
record.desc: Singapore recorded modest growth in Q3 2015. Manufacturing was a sore spot. The policy decision to stem the inflow of cheap foreign labor poses challenges for integral sectors of the economy, such as manufacturing, that rely heavily on low-skill foreign labor.

record.title: South Korea: Positive signs
record.desc: With China’s slowdown and Japan’s currency appreciation affecting exports, South Korea’s hope for a revival in growth lies in domestic demand. The government's attempts to boost demand by temporarily reducing taxes on automobiles and durable consumer goods resulted in a surge in real GDP growth in Q3.

record.title: Realty check: Asian real estate market feels the heat
record.desc: As housing runs into rough weather in Asia, various economies in the region are considering different approaches to spruce it up, while some, such as Singapore, are trying to put curbs on demand itself. All in all, every effort points in one direction: preventing a housing bubble.
record.headline1: Realty check: Asian real estate market feels the heat

record.title: Malaysia: Cautiously walking the tightrope
record.desc: The Malaysian economy continues to deteriorate. Despite stable growth momentum, global uncertainties and political developments and weak domestic fundamentals, are weighing on the economic outlook.

record.title: Taiwan: In the shadow of the Chinese slowdown
record.desc: A drop in Chinese exports is hurting Taiwan, as many of China’s exported products are assembled from components manufactured in other East Asian countries, including Taiwan. For 2016, the question is whether domestic demand will offset weak exports and how closely the recently elected government will work with the mainland.
record.headline1: Taiwan: In the shadow of the Chinese slowdown

record.title: Thailand: Getting back on its feet
record.desc: Thailand seems to be recovering from the lackluster performance of 2014, though questions remain with regard to the rising tide of financial market volatility, slower growth in other Asian countries, and the results of a referendum on a new constitution.
record.headline1: Thailand: Getting back on its feet

record.title: Vietnam: In the fast lane
record.desc: Vietnam’s growth is powered by foreign direct investment, and free trade agreements as well as the prospects offered by the Trans-Pacific Partnership are likely to keep foreign investors interested in the country.

record.title: Australia: Positive in the near term, but a blurred horizon
record.desc: GDP growth for Q1 2016 was the highest recorded since Q1 2012, driven mainly by exports and household consumption. Business investment in engineering construction and new buildings, however, fell sharply. This reliance on exports over investments makes the economy susceptible to external shocks, a cause for concern in the future.
record.headline1: Australia: Positive in the near term, but a blurred horizon

record.title: In defense of Hong Kong’s currency peg
record.desc: As economies across the world ride the ebb and flow of business cycles, fixed exchange rate regimes sometimes come under immense pressure, mostly due to the limited ability of their central banks to respond to these cycles. And, given its strong economic links to China, Hong Kong’s currency peg with the US dollar has come under pressure due to the economic slowdown in the mainland.
record.headline1: In defense of Hong Kong’s currency peg

record.title: Indonesia: Struggling to grow faster
record.desc: The 4.9 percent year-over-year growth during the first quarter falls short of President Widodo’s target of 7.0 percent. Investments are key to pushing GDP growth to targeted levels. But so far the pace of investments has been slow.

record.title: Singapore: Through choppy waters with an eye on the future
record.desc: Singapore faces both the cyclical problem of weak global demand as well as the structural problems of an ageing population and competition from economies that have a cost advantage. Though the latter could be tackled through transition to value creation and higher value addition, increasing labor costs and muted productivity growth are significant barriers.
record.headline1: Singapore: Through choppy waters with an eye on the future

record.title: South Korea: Headwinds, and a policy response
record.desc: Two factors are driving economic weakness in South Korea: declining exports and a weakening of domestic demand. The central bank has cut the benchmark interest rate for the first time in a year, in the hope that it will suppress the value of the Korean won, thus lifting exports.
record.headline1: South Korea: Headwinds, and a policy response

record.title: Behind the Numbers
record.desc:
Introduction

Each month, Deloitte University Press examines a topic of interest on its economics blog, which is called Behind the Numbers.

record.title: Seasonal factors in retailing
record.sub-title: ’Tis the season … but not as much as it used to be
record.desc: Is it possible we overestimate the impact of the holiday sales season?
record.headline2: ’Tis the season … but not as much as it used to be

record.title: No respite in sight: US export growth faces a shaky 2016
record.desc: US export growth took a hit in 2015 and the prospects for 2016 are not looking good—so which industries are feeling the most pain?
record.headline1: No respite in sight: US export growth faces a shaky 2016

record.title: The US debt crisis: Bumping against the ceiling again
record.desc: At some point during the next couple of months, the Treasury will not likely be able to make timely payments to holders of US debt and other creditors. So who are those debt holders that might not get paid?
record.headline1: The US debt crisis: Bumping against the ceiling again

record.title: Employment by sector
record.desc: Economies rarely look the same after a recession. So where are the jobs being created?

record.title: Business cycle length and the probability of a recession
record.desc: The length of a recovery has little to do with the probability that a recession might occur. Business decision makers should look elsewhere to gauge where the economy might be headed.
record.headline1: Business cycle length and the probability of a recession

record.title: Investment in equipment: From processing materials to processing information
record.desc: Businesses are spending more money on computers and communications tools, at the expense of industrial machinery and transportation. This shift in investment away from traditional equipment reflects a need for businesses to strengthen the ways they process information.
record.headline1: Investment in equipment: From processing materials to processing information

record.title: Comparing economies: How is economic size measured and why does it matter?
record.desc: How do we compare economies? GDP is generally measured in a country’s own currency, but for comparing economies, one must convert to a common measure. The choice of conversion factor can make a huge difference in our understanding of relative size.
record.headline1: Comparing economies: How is economic size measured and why does it matter?

record.title: Shifting sands: Examining patterns of spending on consumer durable goods
record.desc: Durable goods have been a key driving force behind real consumer spending since the Great Recession. What is interesting though is within consumer durable goods there is a marked change in spending patterns over time, with consumers increasingly focusing on recreational products.
record.headline1: Shifting sands: Examining patterns of spending on consumer durable goods

record.title: The dismal state of consumer finances
record.desc: Falling incomes and lack of asset accumulation may make retirement at a “normal” retirement age difficult.
record.headline1: The dismal state of consumer finances

record.title: The treasury yield curve explained: Factors shaping the curve
record.desc: Several factors shape the treasury yield curve—monetary policy, inflation expectations, investor preferences, and macroeconomic influences from around the world.
record.headline1: The treasury yield curve explained: Factors shaping the curve

record.title: Housing construction
record.sub-title: What happens when the kids finally leave?
record.desc: How much housing construction will we need to meet the needs of the growing US population? And will college graduates have houses waiting for them when they move out?
record.headline2: What happens when the kids finally leave?

record.title: Behind the Numbers: US capital stock part II
record.desc: Businesses are investing more in knowledge generation, but can private investment make up for less government investment?
record.headline1: Behind the Numbers: US capital stock part II

record.title: Household debt
record.desc: An overall increase in household debt levels signals a movement toward more normal lending patterns with one major exception: the explosive growth in student loan debt.

record.title: How does the country grow?
record.desc: The United States continues to grow through a combination of natural increase and positive net international migration. However, growth among the states is further differentiated by trends in domestic migration.

record.title: Macroeconomic implications of the Affordable Care Act
record.desc: The Affordable Care Act (ACA) is a significant change in the US economy’s institutional framework. This FAQ examines the evidence for the direction and size of the impact on the ACA on overall economic activity in the United States. It does not consider whether the ACA will achieve its goals or how it might affect health care delivery and outcomes.
record.headline1: Macroeconomic implications of the Affordable Care Act

record.title: The curious case of manufacturing capacity utilization: Why hasn’t it recovered from the Great Recession?
record.desc: Manufacturing capacity utilization—an important measure of inflation—is yet to reach pre-recessionary levels. What does this mean for different industries, and for the economy as a whole?
record.headline1: The curious case of manufacturing capacity utilization: Why hasn’t it recovered from the Great Recession?

record.title: Geographic variations in consumption
record.desc: A new data series allows for comparisons of consumption patterns among the states.

record.title: The potential for labor force participation
record.desc: Participation in the labor force declined substantially after the financial market crash in 2008. Demographics accounted for about half of this decline, but even adjusted for demographics, labor force participation has fallen significantly. In a way, that’s good news. It suggests that there are plenty of unused resources to be put to work as the US recovery finally begins to pick up steam.
record.headline1: The potential for labor force participation

record.title: Reshoring manufacturing jobs to the United States: Myth or reality?
record.desc: Early signs such as increased foreign direct investments and announcements by multinationals to design and manufacture products locally point to a renewed interest in reshoring manufacturing jobs to the United States. But is it too early to rule out the lure of lower labor costs and untapped consumer markets offered by emerging markets?
record.headline1: Reshoring manufacturing jobs to the United States: Myth or reality?

record.title: Single-person households: Another look at the changing American family
record.desc: Single-person households in the United States are set to grow steadily over the next 15 years, which could have implications for several industries, ranging from housing to health care.
record.headline1: Single-person households: Another look at the changing American family

record.title: Sources of mortgage lending: Who’s financing American homeowners?
record.desc: US government agencies have been virtually the only financial institutions providing new financing for home mortgages since the mortgage meltdown. Only recently have private-sector lenders been willing to provide new money for homeowners.
record.headline1: Sources of mortgage lending: Who’s financing American homeowners?

record.title: Are jittery US credit markets leading to tighter financial conditions?
record.desc: Falling oil prices and a rate hike by the Federal Reserve have impacted the market for high-yield bonds, but could these jitters result in an overall tightening of the US credit markets?
record.headline1: Are jittery US credit markets leading to tighter financial conditions?

record.title: Behind the Numbers
record.desc: Falling oil prices dominate the news, but of longer-term interest is how the US energy profile is changing.

record.title: US government debt
record.desc: Markets have been more than willing to invest in the US government, as evidenced by record-low interest rates. But how long can this continue?

record.title: US capital stock: Fewer buildings, more knowledge
record.desc: Most types of nonresidential construction have been stagnant for a long time, suggesting the changing structure of the US economy is having some surprising impacts on the construction sector.
record.headline1: US capital stock: Fewer buildings, more knowledge

record.title: Behind the Numbers: Professional sports and the merits of being big and connected
record.desc: The NBA is the only major professional sports league that has set an attendance record over the last couple of years, but the big 4—NFL, NHL, NBA, and MLB—continue to enjoy impressive growth. A recent surge in average valuation across all four leagues has likely been driven by cheap credit, a bull run in the equity market since 2009, and ever-larger television broadcast deals.
record.headline1: Behind the Numbers: Professional sports and the merits of being big and connected

record.title: A growing skills mismatch? Not necessarily
record.desc: Job vacancy announcements are rising much faster than hires, even as unemployment remains high. Although there is some evidence of the skills mismatch rising after 2008, other evidence is more equivocal.
record.headline1: A growing skills mismatch? Not necessarily

record.title: What’s the matter with investment?
record.desc: Why are businesses sitting on top of piles of cash, and if business is so profitable, why are they not putting it back into more and/or better capital investment?

record.title: Global Economic Outlook
record.desc: A quarterly publication that offers insights from Deloitte economists around the world on trends and events shaping the marketplace. Each issue features region-by-region economic outlooks.

record.title: Are emerging markets losing their brand appeal?
record.desc: Many emerging markets faced financial volatility in the wake of the US Federal Reserve’s discussion about tapering. Countries with poor fundamentals and weak policies have been hardest hit during this period of uncertainty, and sustaining growth will require a renewed focus on fundamentals.
record.headline1: Are emerging markets losing their brand appeal?

record.title: The boom and beyond: Managing commodity price cycles
record.desc: The end of the commodity price boom is leaving many countries scrambling for ways to diversify their economies accordingly.
record.headline1: The boom and beyond: Managing commodity price cycles

record.title: Special topic: Revival in international trade and the resurgence of bilateralism
record.desc: An integrated global economy, including cross-border investments, distributed production lines across continents, innovations in IT and communications, and advancement in transportation are heightening international trade’s role as a harbinger of economic growth.
record.headline1: Special topic: Revival in international trade and the resurgence of bilateralism

record.title: Global Economic Outlook, Q1 2015
record.desc: A sharp drop in the price of oil; a shift in US monetary policy; and weaker growth along with low inflation in the Eurozone, Japan, and China are significantly influencing the global economy.

record.title: Global Economic Outlook - Q2 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

The economic situation is very different in each of the world’s leading markets: Europe is torn between two poles; the government is acting to thwart China’s slowdown; Japan is recovering; India is strengthening; and Brazil and Russia continue to face serious challenges. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Global Economic Outlook - Q3 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

The Eurozone economy is on the mend, the Brazilian and Russian economies are in recession, the US economy is rebounding from a bad first quarter, and the Chinese economy is growing relatively slowly. The third-quarter Global Economic Outlook offers outlooks for the United States, Eurozone, China, Japan, Russia, United Kingdom, India, and Brazil. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Global Economic Outlook - Q4 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

This summer, the global business climate was shaken by events in Greece and China. Despite evidence of economic strength in the United States and a continuing recovery in Europe, China’s slowdown has raised many questions about the overall global economic outlook. Read the report online, or download the PDF.

record.title: Economic indices
record.desc: GDP growth rates, inflation rates, major currencies versus the US dollar, yield curves, composite median GDP forecasts, composite median currency forecasts, and OECD composite leading indicators

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: As the new year begins, there are a handful of trends that are driving the global economy.

record.title: Brazil: Into the storm
record.desc: As the Brazilian president starts her second term in office, it is clear that the economic picture is not pretty. Private consumption, a key driver of growth, has slowed, and the labor market has worsened.

record.title: China: Government response to the slowdown
record.desc: The Chinese economy continues to decelerate, and the government continues to take action to thwart the slowdown—mainly easing monetary policy. The result has been acceleration in credit expansion.
record.headline1: China: Government response to the slowdown

record.title: Economic indices
record.desc: GDP growth rates, inflation rates, major currencies versus the US dollar, yield curves, composite median GDP forecasts, composite median currency forecasts, and OECD composite leading indicators.

record.title: Eurozone: Consumers to the rescue
record.desc: The economic outlook for the Eurozone economy is torn between two poles: better-than-expected performance of the real economy vs. growing doubt about the integrity of the Eurozone.

record.title: India: Big-bang changes to growth and a forward-looking budget
record.desc: Q1 2015 was action packed: India witnessed a dramatic revision of GDP and CPI estimates, the first full budget of the new government, and a rate cut by the Reserve Bank of India.
record.headline1: India: Big-bang changes to growth and a forward-looking budget

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: In recent months, the global economy has been rocked by a dramatic decline in oil prices and a dramatic increase in the value of the dollar. Diverging policies of different countries have contributed to exchange rate volatility.

record.title: Japan: Finally, growth
record.desc: Japan has come out of recession. A large share of growth came from strong exports, while consumer spending remained weak, and business investment declined. The job market remains a bit of a puzzle.

record.title: Russia: In reverse gear
record.desc: Russia’s economy is in the midst of difficult times, in part due to low oil prices and Western-imposed sanctions. The central bank and government have been desperately trying to steady the economy.

record.title: United States: Cheap oil and an expensive dollar—what a difference a year makes
record.desc: Although 2014 ended with a moderate rate of growth, the United States is well positioned for a stronger 2015. However, the economic trends shaping this year will create counterbalancing impacts.
record.headline1: United States: Cheap oil and an expensive dollar—what a difference a year makes

record.title: Brazil: No escape from a contraction
record.desc: This year was never going to be easy. It started with a fiscal austerity overdrive, and, with the labor market deteriorating and pessimism rife among consumers and businesses, the stage is set for a potential recession.
record.headline1: Brazil: No escape from a contraction

record.title: China: Uncharted territory
record.desc: After a lingering slowdown, the Chinese economy has begun to show some signs of possibly bottoming out. The country is in the midst of an equity market boom—or possibly a bubble.

record.title: Economic indices
record.desc: GDP growth rates, inflation rates, major currencies versus the US dollar, yield curves, composite median GDP forecasts, composite median currency forecasts, OECD composite leading indicators.

record.title: Eurozone: Combining crisis and recovery
record.desc: Beneath the surface of the intensifying Greek crisis, the recovery in the Eurozone has continued, and there are even signs that it is broadening. European corporates are moderately optimistic about their prospects.

record.title: India: Different stories from the same book
record.desc: Economic activity picked up during Q1—in fact, India’s GDP growth was higher than China’s. Yet, apart from GDP numbers, other economic indicators have been rather subdued, leading to concerns about growth.
record.headline1: India: Different stories from the same book

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: In the third-quarter outlook for the global economy, Deloitte’s far-flung economists offer their views on the economic situation and the outlook for the near and longer term.

record.title: Japan: Slow liftoff
record.desc: The economy is having trouble taking off; areas of concern include slowing exports, consumer and industrial sectors, and retail sales. First-quarter GDP growth provides hints on the path of the economy.

record.title: Russia: The slide continues
record.desc: Russia is in the throes of a recession. A contraction in the first quarter is likely to be repeated as the effects of low oil prices and Western sanctions continue to dent the economy.

record.title: United Kingdom: Good growth ahead
record.desc: Growth unexpectedly eased in the first half of 2015. Poor productivity, in part the flip side of increasing employment, seems to have weighed on exports. Yet the fundamental drivers of growth are generally supportive.

record.title: United States: Another negative start—or was it?
record.desc: For a second year in a row, the first-quarter GDP estimate indicated a contracting economy—a fact many economists find disconcerting, since employment growth remained strong and wage growth finally started to pick up.
record.headline1: United States: Another negative start—or was it?

record.title: Economic indices
record.desc: GDP growth rates, inflation rates, major currencies versus the US dollar, yield curves, composite median GDP forecasts, composite median currency forecasts, OECD composite leading indicators.

record.title: Brazil: A troubling dive into the known
record.desc: Brazil’s economy is struggling, with inflation running high, rating agencies weighing downgrades, and low business confidence. Will lawmakers move beyond recent scandals to make necessary reforms and lay the groundwork for long-term competitiveness?
record.headline1: Brazil: A troubling dive into the known

record.title: Canada: When is it recession?
record.desc: The Canadian economy shrank for two quarters in a row, and journalists immediately declared a recession. But it’s a bit more complicated than that. The slowdown was blamed on slow growth in the United States and the drop in the price of oil.

record.title: China: The slowdown and its global impact
record.desc: China has been front and center in the world’s financial news lately—with plummeting equity prices, a slowing economy, and policy-directed currency depreciation. What is the reality of China’s slowdown and its potential impact on the world?
record.headline1: China: The slowdown and its global impact

record.title: Are emerging markets prepared for the Fed rate hike storm?
record.desc: Are emerging economies ready for the US Federal Reserve’s impending rate hike? Five countries—Brazil, India, Indonesia, South Africa, and Turkey—show different levels of preparedness.
record.headline1: Are emerging markets prepared for the Fed rate hike storm?

record.title: Eurozone: Growing despite headwinds
record.desc: This summer’s events had the potential to derail the tepid recovery of the Eurozone, yet the recovery has continued. Its speed is still not overwhelming, but it has become more stable. Consumers remain the main driver of growth, while exports continue to be a driver despite emerging-market weakness.

record.title: Global value chains: More a development strategy than a mere process
record.desc: “Made in the world” perhaps describes the origin of most goods and services today, as they go through global value chains (GVCs) that cut across geographies. GVCs are set to benefit both developed and emerging economies as they enable firms and economies to participate more in global trade.
record.headline1: Global value chains: More a development strategy than a mere process

record.title: India: Don't believe what numbers say but what investors do
record.desc: India seems to be riding the ebb and flow of economic activity. Growth has primarily been driven by consumption expenditure. Amid confusion over growth numbers, capital investment has lagged, with investors waiting to see enough change in economic activity before taking the plunge.
record.headline1: India: Don't believe what numbers say but what investors do

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: This summer, the global business climate was shaken by events in Greece and China. In this edition of the Global Economic Outlook, our team of economists provide their outlooks for China, United States, Eurozone, Japan, India, Brazil, Canada, United Kingdom, and South Africa.

record.title: Japan: Struggling to recover
record.desc: The outlook for Japan indicates continued slow economic growth. Inflation is likely to remain low, especially with declining energy prices and a weaker Chinese renminbi. While quantitative easing has been used to address the economic situation, that it is not enough is increasingly clear.

record.title: South Africa: In a commodities trough
record.desc: With stubbornly high unemployment and falling labor force productivity, South Africa’s economy desperately needs a boost. The question is whether the government can overcome both internal problems and external pressures from Chinese and US policies.
record.headline1: South Africa: In a commodities trough

record.title: United Kingdom: Domestic strength, external worries
record.desc: After a long period of austerity, things are looking up for UK consumers, with rising incomes and low inflation. Growing demand may well offset global instability and China’s slowdown to make the country a European bright spot.
record.headline1: United Kingdom: Domestic strength, external worries

record.title: United States: Back to fiscal uncertainty
record.desc: As the US labor market recovers, the big question—in the United States and around the world—is when the US Federal Reserve will raise the federal funds rate. And close to home, political drama once again threatens to upend the ongoing recovery.
record.headline1: United States: Back to fiscal uncertainty

record.title: Global Economic Outlook, Q1 2016
record.desc: In the first-quarter edition of Global Economic Outlook, our far-flung economists examine the global economic environment and offer their thoughts on the current situation and the likely future path.

record.title: Global Economic Outlook, Q3 2016
record.desc: This summer, the global economy has been facing new uncertainties, not the least of which is Brexit. Other areas of concern include weak job numbers in the United States, continued deflationary pressures in Europe, and rising corporate debt in China. Meanwhile, other issues seem to have disappeared from the headlines.

record.title: Fed rate hike and economic instability in emerging markets
record.desc: Emerging markets have been witnessing a rapid increase in capital outflows. Apart from a Fed rate hike, other potential risks are lurking that may trigger paranoia among investors. Will a tighter monetary policy in the United States trigger a domino effect in the global financial world?
record.headline1: Fed rate hike and economic instability in emerging markets

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: In the first-quarter edition of Global Economic Outlook, our far-flung economists examine the global economic environment and offer their thoughts on the current situation and the likely future path.

record.title: Economic indices
record.desc: GDP growth rates, inflation rates, major currencies versus the US dollar, yield curves, composite median GDP forecasts, composite median currency forecasts, OECD composite leading indicators.

record.title: Brazil: Yearning for the good times
record.desc: Last year was perhaps one of the toughest for Brazil. The economy contracted sharply, even as political challenges hindered economic policy, amid concerns about fiscal dominance. Exports proved to be a bright spot, though.
record.headline1: Brazil: Yearning for the good times

record.title: Canada: Keynes arrives
record.desc: In Canada’s current low-inflation environment, the fiscal stimulus promised by the new government will likely be welcome. However, a potential housing bubble and high household debt pose risks.

record.title: China: On the horns of a trilemma
record.desc: Chinese authorities are striving to stave off a sharp decline in the renminbi’s value. Yet the government’s uncertain economic goals have put the country in an untenable spot.
record.headline1: China: On the horns of a trilemma

record.title: Eurozone: Recovery intact, institutional turmoil ahead
record.desc: Even though significant internal and external risks exist for the European Union, the main institutional and political risk is the possibility of a Brexit. While its consequences are difficult to predict, the political effects for the European Union could range between two scenarios.
record.headline1: Eurozone: Recovery intact, institutional turmoil ahead

record.title: Impact of negative interest rates: Living in the unknown
record.desc: Imagine a lender paying interest to a borrower instead of the other way round—which is precisely what’s happening in Europe and Japan. Negative interest rates join the long list of central banks’ unorthodox policies to counter deflation and revive economic growth—but have they been successful?
record.headline1: Impact of negative interest rates: Living in the unknown

record.title: India: It’s going to be all about consumption
record.desc: The Indian economy has maintained strong macroeconomic fundamentals in the face of the global economic slowdown, rising global uncertainty, and even drought. The government’s latest budget primarily focuses on stimulating rural demand in order to sustain domestic demand.
record.headline1: India: It’s going to be all about consumption

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: In the second-quarter edition of the Global Economic Outlook, our team of economists tries to explain the factors driving the uncertainty in the global economy.

record.title: Japan: Finding the right policy mix
record.desc: Despite the monetary stimulus undertaken by the Bank of Japan, the economy is clearly not recovering in the manner that the government had hoped. Introducing negative rates for the first time, the bank is looking for a new tool to boost inflation.
record.headline1: Japan: Finding the right policy mix

record.title: Russia: In austere times
record.desc: Russia’s dependence on oil is likely to intensify its economic troubles. Though oil prices have recovered slightly, they remain below the level required to balance Russia’s budget, requiring a further cut in expenditure that will hit the working class and pensioners hardest.

record.title: United Kingdom: Brexit or not to Brexit?
record.desc: High on the list of risks the United Kingdom faces is uncertainty over the outcome of the referendum on its EU membership. If voters choose to remain, it’s going to be status quo, but a vote to leave would be the start of a long, complex process of negotiation and a period of great uncertainty.
record.headline1: United Kingdom: Brexit or not to Brexit?

record.title: United States: Moderate growth to continue, but when will wages begin rising?
record.desc: US consumers are carrying the economy in the face of slowing business investment, falling exports, and rising imports. But the strength of the consumer is largely based on a greater number of people working, rather than the increased spending power of individual workers.
record.headline1: United States: Moderate growth to continue, but when will wages begin rising?

record.title: Economic indices
record.desc: GDP growth rates, inflation rates, major currencies versus the US dollar, yield curves, composite median GDP forecasts, composite median currency forecasts, OECD composite leading indicators.

record.title: Brazil: A glimmer of hope
record.desc: Brazil’s new government, though temporary, has its work cut out. GDP contracted for the fifth straight quarter, fiscal deficit is in double digits, and inflation is way above target. However, the president has started on the right note by putting in place a credible economic team.

record.title: China: The deceleration continues
record.desc: Data related to industrial production, manufacturing, electricity output, and retail sales all indicate that the Chinese economy continues to decelerate. Growing debt is also a cause for concern. There are warnings that unless China takes up serious reforms, the expansion of debt could lead to a financial crisis, low economic growth, or both.

record.title: Eurozone: Life after Brexit
record.desc: While the Eurozone’s economic recovery has continued and even gained momentum, the outlook is shaped by Brexit. Key among the questions now are how to structure the future relationship with the United Kingdom as well as how to manage political risks.

record.title: India: Slow and steady may not be enough to win the race
record.desc: Two years into the new Indian government, how has the economy fared? It has been a mixed bag so far: Much-needed reforms have been initiated, but their progress has been slow. Uncertainty in the tax environment, poor implementation of structural reforms, and the lack of an assertive stance to improve trade are among the problem areas.
record.headline1: India: Slow and steady may not be enough to win the race

record.title: Introduction
record.desc: Our team of global economists offer their views on the United Kingdom, Eurozone, United States, China, Japan, Brazil, Mexico, South Africa, India, and the economic implications of oil price fluctuations.

record.title: Japan: Will households oblige by spending more?
record.desc: Private consumption holds the key to growth at a time of slowing exports—so how can Japan’s policymakers create incentives for consumers to spend? The Bank of Japan actually may already be doing that, by both lowering borrowing costs and reducing the government’s debt burden.
record.headline1: Japan: Will households oblige by spending more?

record.title: Mexico: Embracing the advantage of its northern neighbor
record.desc: Previously, Mexico attempted to keep its distance from the United States. Since the resolution of the 1980s’ debt crisis, however, Mexico has instead embraced the advantages of its large neighbor. There are signs that this strategy may be starting to pay off.
record.headline1: Mexico: Embracing the advantage of its northern neighbor

record.title: South Africa: In search of an economic foothold
record.desc: South Africa’s economic challenges have intensified. The economy contracted in the first quarter of 2016; and weak growth, political unrest, and deteriorating fundamentals have resulted in the currency slipping and inflation climbing. Policymakers will likely face difficulty in navigating internal and external challenges.
record.headline1: South Africa: In search of an economic foothold

record.title: The oil mighty: The economic impact of oil price fluctuations
record.desc: Wide fluctuations in oil prices have played an important role in driving recessions and even regimes collapsing—which is why oil price movements are closely watched by economists, investors, and policymakers. The two recent cycles of historic highs and lows suggest that the world economy is in unchartered territory.
record.headline1: The oil mighty: The economic impact of oil price fluctuations

record.title: United Kingdom: After Brexit, what lies ahead?
record.desc: After Brexit, the final shape of Britain’s economic and political relationship with the European Union and the rest of the world may take years to fully emerge. Right now, the most useful response would be for the UK government to signal the direction of its negotiations with the European Union.
record.headline1: United Kingdom: After Brexit, what lies ahead?

record.title: United States: Businesses take a (hopefully) temporary breather
record.desc: What effect will the first-quarter contraction in business investment and slower employment growth have on the outlook for US economy? Going by recent trends, annual GDP growth may not slow down overall. However, unless business investment picks up, longer-term growth might be at risk.
record.headline1: United States: Businesses take a (hopefully) temporary breather

record.title: Issues by the Numbers
record.desc: What gets measured gets managed, as the saying goes. But sometimes, the numbers don't turn out the way you expect. In Issues by the Numbers, we take a deep dive into the quantitative aspects of business and govermnent's pressing concerns, exploring the sometimes surprising implications for organizational leaders and public policy.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers, April 2015
record.desc: High unemployment rates among America’s youth, coupled with the country’s growing number of seniors, raise a question of intergenerational equity: How much is fair to ask from today’s younger people to help support their elders?

record.title: Issues by the Numbers, August 2015
record.desc: With growth in health care spending slowing and the number of people with access to health insurance rising, the stage is set to see whether the United States can become a more efficient producer and consumer of health care.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers, January 2015
record.desc: US employment tied to foreign direct investment (FDI) fared better in the aftermath of the recession than did employment in general. How has FDI affected job growth across various industries and states since 2007?

record.title: Issues by the Numbers, June 2014
record.desc: Complex shifts in employment are occurring throughout the American economy, with unique mixtures of gains and losses sweeping across the spectrum of industries and in different regions of the country.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers, June 2016
record.desc: The United States is nearing the end of the era of ultralow interest rates that began at the height of the financial crisis. As interest rates begin their gradual rise, various sectors of the economy will need to rethink the math of their spending and financing decisions.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers: March 2014
record.desc: The joint OECD-WTO “Trade in Value-Added” (TiVA) initiative has constructed a series of indicators that are designed to provide new—and more meaningful—insights into the commercial relations between nations.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers - May 2013
record.desc:
Introduction

With immigration reform high on the US Congress and Administration’s agenda, it is important that the discussion be informed by an understanding of the role that immigration currently plays in the US economy.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers - November 2013
record.desc:
Introduction

Prompted by widespread dissatisfaction with the results of the US educational system, multiple actors from outside traditional governmental participants have been working to transform education in the United States.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers - October 2015
record.desc:
Introduction

Many of the perceived differences between Millennials and previous generations are just that: perceived rather than actual. It behooves employers to better understand Millennials' life goals, and craft tailored interventions aimed at engaging this vital workforce segment.

record.title: Issues by the Numbers - September 2014
record.desc:
Introduction

Job growth finally appears to be on a sustained upswing, but how are variations in growth among and within industry segments impacting wage growth at the national and state level?

record.title: Obamacare and the changing health care landscape: Current health care trends
record.desc: With the last major legal challenge to the Affordable Care Act (ACA) settled, now comes the real test: Can the ACA help rein in one of the major drivers of rising health care costs—the cost of care per case?
record.headline1: Obamacare and the changing health care landscape: Current health care trends

record.title: The geography of jobs, part 3: Mapping the effects of international investment flows
record.desc: Manufacturing and professional, scientific, and technical services stand out as industries where foreign direct investment in the United States has had a surprising impact on job creation.
record.authors: Dr. Patricia Buckley|Dr. Peter Viechnicki|Lara Wigmore
record.headline1: The geography of jobs, part 3: Mapping the effects of international investment flows

record.title: An unbalanced age: Effects of youth unemployment on an aging society
record.desc: If young adults’ current high unemployment rate follows them across their work lives, funding retiree pensions and health care may be even more challenging than otherwise, as those with lessened prospects for income will be asked to support an ever-growing number of retirees.
record.headline1: An unbalanced age: Effects of youth unemployment on an aging society

record.title: In whose interest? Examining the impact of an interest rate hike
record.desc: Explore the impact that rising interest rates could have on the US economy as seen through the lens of five economic sectors: the financial services industry, households, the nonfinancial corporate sector, state and local government, and the federal government.
record.headline1: In whose interest? Examining the impact of an interest rate hike

record.title: The geography of jobs: Mapping the recovery
record.desc: The current boom in energy production, the hangover from the housing bubble, and the long-term decline in manufacturing employment are combining to shift the employment profile of the US economy.
record.headline1: The geography of jobs: Mapping the recovery

record.title: How immigration is shaping the United States
record.desc: Immigration and immigration reform are perennial topics of debate in the United States. What do the data say about how immigration is shaping the country?
record.headline1: How immigration is shaping the United States

record.title: A new view of international trade
record.desc: A fresh take on the numbers suggests that the United States’ international trade position is stronger than widely assumed.
record.headline1: A new view of international trade

record.title: The solution revolution in education
record.desc: Prompted by widespread dissatisfaction with the results of the educational system, actors from outside traditional governmental participants are working to transform education in the United States.

record.title: A new understanding of Millennials: Generational differences reexamined
record.desc: Millennials are widely thought to be less loyal to their employers than their older colleagues. But a look at the numbers suggests that many of the traits attributed to Millennials are related to prevailing economic conditions rather than to fundamental differences in their aspirations.
record.authors: Dr. Patricia Buckley|Dr. Peter Viechnicki|Akrur Barua
record.headline1: A new understanding of Millennials: Generational differences reexamined

record.title: The aging water infrastructure: Out of sight, out of mind?
record.desc: The United States’ water infrastructure needs an overhaul, and the cost of doing so is climbing rapidly. Where will the money come from?
record.headline1: The aging water infrastructure: Out of sight, out of mind?

record.title: The geography of jobs, part 2: Charting wage growth
record.desc: Job growth finally appears to be on a sustained upswing, but how are variations in growth among and within industry segments impacting wage growth at the national and state level?
record.headline1: The geography of jobs, part 2: Charting wage growth

record.title: US Economic Forecast: Volume 3 Issue 1
record.desc: The fall in oil prices is very important for the US economy. However, other factors will moderate the oil price impact, including a rising dollar, falling US exports, and increasing risk in Europe.

record.title: US Economic Forecast: Volume 3 Issue 2
record.desc: Unexpected weakness in the first quarter and indications that the second quarter will also be weak make our previous forecast for 2015 unlikely (or, at least, highly improbable).

record.title: US Economic Forecast: Volume 3 Issue 3
record.desc: Many US pundits are too anxious about recent news pertaining to the European and Chinese economies. But economic conditions abroad would need to deteriorate significantly before they would compromise growth in the United States.

record.title: US Economic Forecast: Volume 3 Issue 4
record.desc: As Europe and China show continued weakness and uncertainty, the US economy appears strong—though, as always, outside events and internal conflict may intervene. The big question is whether the pace of productivity will pick up.

record.title: US Economic Forecast: 2016 Q1
record.desc: After six years of waiting for productivity to pick up, we're reconciled to a new normal of slower US growth. While a recession remains unlikely, question marks in Europe and China—and an expensive dollar—will likely temper any boom in the near future.

record.title: United States Economic Forecast
record.desc: Notwithstanding chatter on cable TV, today's US economy is comparatively stable and borderline dull. Yes, volatility threatens in Europe and China, and the presidential election is raising temperatures, but we expect the gradual upturn to continue, hampered by nagging slow productivity growth.

record.title: Infographic—A strategic oil and gas ecosystem

record.title: A flexible and holistic integrity platform design

A system that learns from its own experiences—both from the effects of its own actions and from external data—can adapt over time to accommodate changing fraudster tactics.
