record.title: Mapping the effects of international investment flows
record.desc: View the relationship between employment supported by foreign direct investment in major industries and overall foreign direct investment employment on a state-by-state basis.
record.authors: Lara Wigmore|Dr. Peter Viechnicki|Dr. Patricia Buckley

record.title: Understanding Millennials in government
record.sub-title: Debunking myths about our youngest public servants
record.desc: Explore the data underlying the view that Millennials may not be as averse to government jobs as many may think.

record.title: A new understanding of Millennials: Generational differences reexamined
record.desc: Dig into the numbers to investigate similarities and differences in economic behavior across the generations in the United States.

record.title: A Sensor-Enabled World
record.desc: The world is increasingly represented by a series of 0's and 1's. Pair small, inexpensive sensors with needed communications, analytics, and behavioral infrastructure, and you have Internet of Things applications in many aspects of daily life.

record.title: Alternative transportation atlas
record.sub-title: Part of the "Smart mobility" research report
record.desc: View the potential for ridesharing, bike commuting, carsharing, and on-demand ride services to change the way Americans get around.
record.authors: Dr. Peter Viechnicki|Abhijit Khuperkar|Tiffany Dovey Fishman|William D. Eggers

record.title: Impact of alternative transportation by metropolitan area
record.sub-title: Part of the "Smart mobility" research report
record.desc: Investigate the benefits your metropolitan area could reap from expanding shared transportation and bike commuting.
record.authors: Dr. Peter Viechnicki|Abhijit Khuperkar|Tiffany Dovey Fishman|William D. Eggers

record.title: The solution revolution in education
record.desc: What are wavemakers accomplishing in US education? Explore the numbers.

record.title: The future of wealth in the United States
record.desc: How might the distribution of wealth across the generations shift over the next 15 years? Explore the numbers through this interactive graphic.

record.title: Work environment redesign case studies
record.desc: Research suggests that redesigning the work environment can be central to achieving sustainable business performance improvement. Explore these principles and case studies in an interactive graphic.

record.title: Case Studies: Customer experience in government
Additive manufacturing: A 3D opportunity
record.desc: The emergence of additive manufacturing technologies can lead to exciting opportunities...or obsolescence. Companies can explore four tactical paths as they deploy these technologies across their businesses.

record.title: Augmented government
record.desc: Augmented reality (AR)—the use of technology to overlay information on a view of a real-world environment—is already used in manufacturing and by the military. Now, with advances in mobile technology and an increasing volume of digital data at our fingertips, AR is positioned to serve as a valuable asset in civilian government as well.

record.title: Automotive trends and Gen Y
record.desc: Generation Y will soon become the automotive industry’s biggest demographic, and to many of them, the automobile is more appliance than status symbol. The results of an extensive study paint a complex mosaic of opportunities and challenges for automakers, with a large and powerful consumer segment more willing than prior generations to forego vehicle ownership altogether.

record.title: Nudging New Mexico
record.desc: Deterring small-scale fraud, such as by those who file exaggerated weekly unemployment reports, often requires more resources than the effort is worth. Watch how applying concepts from behavioral economics can induce more desired behavior.

record.title: Beyond Yahoo: Breaking down the “virtual” versus “campus” debate
record.desc: To address ebbing engagement and lost productivity, companies often consider two diametric approaches to they way we work—the campus and virtual environments. But neither is a one-size-fits-all approach.

record.title: Data Security and the Internet of Things
record.sub-title: Being secure, vigilant, and resilient in the connected age
record.desc: Welcome to the Internet of Things, where security cannot be an afterthought.

record.title: Supply unchained: Fighting supply chain labor abuse
record.desc: Prioritizing the prevention of human rights violations can help organizations open an important dialogue with empowered consumers, preserve the integrity of their supply chains, and protect their brand identity.

record.title: Gov2020: Envisioning the future of government
record.desc: By 2020, the world could look very different. How will government adapt to keep up with the needs of citizens?

record.title: GovCloud and Generation Y
record.desc: Hear what the class of 1997 thinks about government work and GovCloud.

record.title: The new organization: Different by design
record.desc: Powerful forces are dramatically changing the work landscape for both HR functions and the organizations they serve, creating talent challenges—as well as potential solutions—radically different from those faced by previous generations of leaders.

record.title: What is the Internet of Things?
record.desc: We all know what the Internet is, but what is the "Internet of Things"?

record.title: Industry 4.0: Exploring the world of connected enterprises
record.desc: The marriage of advanced manufacturing techniques with information technology, data, and analytics is driving another industrial revolution—one that invites manufacturing leaders to combine information technology and operations technology to create value in new and different ways.

record.title: Insuring the future of mobility
record.sub-title: The insurance industry's role in the evolving transportation ecosystem
record.desc: If people stop driving, what will auto insurers, well, insure? The rise of ridesharing and autonomous cars—as part of the new mobility ecosystem—means that the insurance industry should reconsider its time-honored business model. While some revenue streams will likely dry up, new ones will begin flowing.

record.title: Covering all the bases
record.sub-title: Overcoming behavioral biases to help individuals achieve retirement security
record.desc: A full 86 percent of Americans believe we’re facing a looming retirement crisis. So how can organizations help people save enough? Understanding—and leveraging—behavioral economics tools can have a huge impact. Here’s how.

record.title: How can pharmaceutical companies engage with patients?
record.desc: In a shifting health care landscape, patients are demanding care and solutions that are coordinated, convenient, customized, and accessible. In response, nontraditional players—pharma companies in particular—are coming forward to address these emerging expectations and establish their brands for patient engagement services.

record.title: Getting ahead of the "ripple effect"
record.sub-title: A framework for a water stewardship strategy
record.desc: Water scarcity creates risks and opportunities. A water stewardship strategy should help business leaders identify and pursue value-creating initiatives, from cost reduction and innovation, to a reputation that creates further opportunities.

record.title: (interactive video) Shift Index organizational self-assessment tutorial
record.desc: Our 2013 Shift Index findings indicate that US firm performance has declined over the past four decades. In such an environment, organizations need the ability to adapt as rapidly as the world is changing around them, continuously learning from each challenge. Understand how well your organization is ready for the Big Shift by taking this 20-minute tutorial.

record.title: Social innovation
record.desc: Solving societal problems is no longer just government’s job. A broadening array of individuals and organizations—public, private, not-for-profit—are working together to address societal issues.

record.title: (interactive video) The journey to exceptional performance
record.desc: What does it take to deliver superior business performance? Perhaps more importantly, what does it take for your business to deliver superior performance?

record.title: Success or struggle: ROA as a true measure of business performance
record.desc: Despite turmoil in Washington, the news has been upbeat on many fronts, yet other metrics tell a different story, one of increasing pressures and stress as our institutions fail to harness the promise of technology and connection.

record.title: Innovating in the digital era
record.desc: Yesterday’s science fiction fantasies are evolving into tomorrow’s business realities, putting technology leaders in a rare position to imagine a future and then harness innovation to build it responsibly.

record.title: Inspiring disruption
record.desc: The rate of technology change continues at an astonishing pace, irreversibly transforming how businesses operate. Disruptive technology forces such as analytics, mobile, social, cloud, and cyber security are having exponential impacts - disrupting and reshaping companies, business models, and even entire industries

record.title: Tech Trends 2015 overview
record.sub-title: The fusion of business and IT
record.desc: As business and IT are fused together, a number of emerging trends are transforming “business as usual” across industries, functions, and geographies.

record.title: The exceptional company: defying gravity
record.desc: Find out what exceptional companies (and exceptional glider pilots) have in common as Deloitte's Michael Raynor summarizes the Three Rules from his latest book and Deloitte Review issue 13 feature.

record.title: The personalized and the personal
record.sub-title: Socially responsible innovation through big data
record.desc: The possibility of creating data products and services fueled by fine-grained behavioral information, and informed by behavioral science and choice architecture, offers a framework for innovations that enhance rather than diminish public trust.

record.title: A framework for societal problem solving
record.desc: Explore the robust framework presented in Deloitte’s Solution Revolution for tackling the world’s toughest tasks by bringing the right technologies, players, and strategies to the table.

record.title: Where will the future of mobility take us?
record.sub-title: How transportation technology and social trends are creating a new business ecosystem
record.desc: Imagine a world where vehicles hardly crash, traffic jams are rare, and trip costs plummet. The emergence of autonomous vehicles and car- and ride-sharing will affect almost everyone—forcing business leaders in most industries to start asking tough questions about the future of mobility.

record.title: The future of wealth in the United States
record.desc: As household assets grow over the next 15 years, understanding the evolution of wealth among different generations can help wealth managers exploit future opportunities.

record.title: Making retirement security a reality
record.desc: How can financial services firms reach consumers with products and advice that more effectively prompt people to save for retirement?

record.title: 3D opportunity for the supply chain: Additive manufacturing delivers
record.desc: Additive manufacturing, or 3D printing, is poised to revolutionize industries such as health care and defense. Kelly Marchese of Deloitte Consulting LLP spoke to Tanya Ott about the implications across industries—from supply chain transformation, to challenges around intellectual property and talent.

record.title: Aligning the organization for its digital future
record.sub-title: Findings from the 2016 digital business global executive study and research report
record.desc: Almost every company expects digital disruption in some form or another—but how are they actually preparing for it? Perhaps surprisingly, this preparation may need to be more cultural than technological. Tanya Ott spoke with Gerald Kane about companies’ differing levels of digital maturity as they compete in a rapidly changing world.

record.title: Patterns of disruption
record.sub-title: Anticipating disruptive strategies in a world of unicorns, black swans, and exponentials
record.desc: Why are potentially disruptive forces so hard to see? And how can executives make sense of the endless headlines on the subject? John Hagel and John Seely Brown spoke with Tanya Ott on how executives might need to change their lens to identify patterns of disruption.

record.title: Ignoring bad news
record.sub-title: How behavioral factors influence us to sugarcoat or avoid negative messages
record.desc: Whether and how to report bad news is a constant issue in organizations, with employees agonizing over the consequences. Tanya Ott spoke to Deloitte’s Mark Cotteleer and Timothy Murphy about how a framework—the message, messenger, and masses—can help organizations understand human biases to better communicate negative messages.

record.title: Life-hacks, nudges and choice architecture
record.desc: We all make bad decisions—but that doesn’t mean we make them for no reason. Behavioral economics aims to explain why we act the way we do, in large and small ways, and helps us better understand our family, neighbors, employees, customers—and ourselves. The goal: to put our natural irrationality to good use.

record.title: The last-mile problem: How data science and behavioral science can work together
record.desc: If we want to act on data to get fit or reduce heating bills, we need to understand not just analytics, but how we make decisions. Press Room host Tanya Ott talks with Jim Guszcza about the art and science of applying the findings from masses of data in the context of how people actually behave.

record.title: Nudging New Mexico
record.sub-title: Kindling behavior change among unemployment claimants
record.desc: After the Great Recession, New Mexico’s Department of Workforce Solutions (DWS) tackled the difficult job of recovering money from people who’d been overpaid unemployment insurance. Joy Forehand of DWS and Deloitte’s Mike Greene spoke with Tanya Ott about how a combination of behavioral economics and analytics proved surprisingly effective.

record.title: Deloitte Review 18
record.desc: Human biases extend beyond our personal lives to impact economic, regulatory, and management decisions more than we may realize. Deloitte’s Jon Warshawsky spoke with Tanya Ott about how behavioral economics can offer tools to better shape programs, policies, and products in a human-centric spirit, as presented in the upcoming issue of Deloitte Review.

record.title: Delivering on digital
record.sub-title: The innovations and technologies that are transforming government
record.desc: Even though healthcare.gov was initially called a public policy disaster, it ended up being one of the best things to happen to a government unable to keep up with evolving citizen expectations. Bill Eggers spoke with Tanya Ott on how government agencies must change their traditional culture to a digital, innovative one to continue to successfully deliver services.

record.title: Strategy, not technology, drives digital transformation
record.desc: What's the most important driver of organizational digital maturity—social, mobile, analytics, or cloud? None of the above, according to the latest MIT Sloan Management Review and Deloitte digital business study.

record.title: Preparing the doctor of the future: Medical school and residency program evolution
record.desc: Health care consumers are looking for the same quality of service that they get in other industries, while doctors find they increasingly need business skills: leadership, marketing, communication. Harry Greenspun discusses how physicians and medical schools are responding to these different pressures in the current health care environment.

record.title: HR for humans
record.sub-title: How behavioral economics can reinvent HR
record.desc: Is it true that the more you pay people, the harder they will work? How can human resources move from focusing on processes to thinking about human motivation? Josh Bersin spoke with Tanya Ott about how behavioral economics disrupts HR—in a good way.

record.title: Executive transitions
record.sub-title: The myth of the first 90 days
record.desc: It’s not uncommon for top companies to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars to recruit C-suite execs—but the failure rate is high. Ajit Kambil spoke with Tanya Ott about the 90-day myth, and the three main areas newly hired C-level executives need to focus on to be successful.

record.title: The hero's journey
record.sub-title: The future of the business landscape
record.desc: Massive changes in digital technology are reshaping the business world—from more power to consumers, to business models that are more about ecosystems than competition. John Hagel of Deloitte Services LP spoke to Tanya Ott about digital disruption’s challenges and opportunities—for companies big and small.

record.title: The future of mobility
record.sub-title: How transportation technology and social trends are creating a new business ecosystem
record.desc: Lighter, self-driving cars; no parking lots; lower revenue from traffic violations: What does the future of mobility promise? Tanya Ott spoke with Deloitte’s Scott Corwin about how industry incumbents must figure out where to play and how to win.

record.title: Gaming away the leadership gap
record.sub-title: Linking gamification and behavioral science to leadership development
record.desc: Can video games help organizations develop better leaders?

record.title: Global economic outlook
record.desc: China’s slowdown, plummeting oil prices, the risk of a US recession: Tanya Ott spoke with Ira Kalish, Deloitte’s chief global economist, about the major economic factors affecting today’s post-OPEC world.

record.title: Deloitte's 2015 holiday survey
record.desc: Retailers can look forward to shoppers spending more this holiday season, with the economy picking up and low gas prices putting more money into consumers’ pockets. So what do they plan to buy and from where? Tanya Ott talks to Rod Sides, leader of Deloitte’s US Retail Distribution practice, about trends that came to the fore in the annual holiday survey.

record.title: Power struggle
record.sub-title: Customers, companies, and the Internet of Things
record.desc: As the Internet of Things (IoT) permeates people’s daily lives, potentially useful information can now be created at every turn. But sometimes customers, companies, or both can find themselves disadvantaged by IoT-enabled deployments. Host Tanya Ott spoke to Michael Raynor and Brenna Sniderman of Deloitte Services LP on how to balance this power struggle.

record.title: Safeguarding the Internet of Things
record.sub-title: Being secure, vigilant, and resilient in the connected age
record.desc: With 20 billion Internet of Things (IoT) devices in the world, do companies have a strategy for how to use—and protect—the data collected? Irfan Saif and Sean Peasley of Deloitte & Touche LLP spoke to Tanya Ott about how companies can mitigate the various risks across the IoT value loop.

record.title: Running on data
record.sub-title: Activity trackers and the Internet of Things
record.desc: The fitness tracker on your wrist may be the most evident sign of the Internet of Things, but it is just one node resting on top of communications, analytics, policy, and even behavioral infrastructure. Host Tanya Ott talked to Tom Davenport, independent senior advisor to Deloitte LLP, about the future of IoT.

record.title: Hidden risks of a cyber breach
record.sub-title: Cyber theft and the loss of intellectual property
record.desc: Losing customer data to hackers can be costly and embarrassing, but losing intellectual property to cyber thieves could threaten a company’s future. Tanya Ott talks to Emily Mossburg and Ash Raghavan about the risks facing business today.

record.title: Smart device, smart pay: Taking mobile payments from coffee shops to retail stores
record.desc: Mobile payments, or mPayments, have grown from a niche market to a potential $700–800 billion opportunity by 2017. Deloitte’s Craig Wigginton spoke with Tanya Ott about the factors related to mPayment’s growth, such as new wearable technology, consumer habits, and retailer investment.

record.title: A billion to one
record.sub-title: Using analytics to make the crowd personal
record.desc: The creation of products and services derived from crowd-based insights is the foundation of the “billion-to-one” experience. Taking your characteristics and behavior and contextualizing them with data from many thousands of other individuals allows designers to deliver products and services that are, or at least feel, unique.

record.title: A new understanding of Millennials
record.desc: Popular opinion considers Millennials to be lazy and immature—but do the numbers corroborate this? Tanya Ott spoke with Deloitte’s Patricia Buckley about how economic conditions affect generational trends, such the regions where Millennials live and their mobility choices.

record.title: The aging water infrastructure
record.sub-title: Out of sight, out of mind?
record.desc: Water pipes in most US cities are more than 50 years old, and some even double that age—leading to major health concerns and enormous costs from main breaks. Tanya Ott spoke with Patricia Buckley about the water infrastructure’s “hidden crisis,” and from where the money to prevent it will come.

record.title: Making retirement security a reality
record.sub-title: What can financial institutions and advisors do?
record.desc: The retirement advisory industry is positioned to make a significant dent in alleviating the looming retirement crisis. Host Tanya Ott talks to Deloitte University Press authors Sean Cunniff, Sam Friedman, and Val Srinivas about how financial services firms may need to devise new ways of delivering appropriate, affordable retirement advice to a wider range of clients.

record.title: Deflecting the scarcity trajectory
record.sub-title: Innovation at the water, energy, and food nexus
record.desc: Shortfalls of water, energy, and food can sabotage economic and business growth as well as compromise social well-being. Host Tanya Ott talks to Will Sarni, director of Deloitte Consulting LLP's Enterprise Water Strategy practice, about signs that the public sector, private sector, and NGOs are beginning to work together to take us off the scarcity trajectory.

record.title: Women, energy, and economic empowerment
record.sub-title: Applying a gender lens to amplify the impact of energy access
record.desc: Research shows that one of the leading predictors of the stability of a country is not its GDP or its resources; it’s the way its women are treated. And one way to empower women is through access to energy. Kathleen O’Dell talks to Tanya Ott about the link between gender inequality and the energy sector, making a case for looking at energy projects through a gender lens.

record.title: Redesigning work in an era of cognitive technologies
record.desc: Since the first caveman picked up a sharp rock, technology has been changing the way we work and the jobs we do. What effect will the rise of artificial intelligence and cognitive technologies have on jobs of the future? Host Tanya Ott talks to David Schatsky about the kinds of work computers can do now, what they'll be able to do soon, and how it may affect your business.

record.title: Cognitive technologies: The real opportunities for business
record.desc: This complimentary business course is designed to help demystify artificial intelligence, provide an overview of a wide range of cognitive technologies, and offer a framework to help you understand the business implications of AI and cognitive technologies.

record.title: 3D opportunity: The course on additive manufacturing for business leaders
record.desc: Our online course is designed to help expand your knowledge of the business implications of additive manufacturing and inform your choices about how and where to invest in these technologies.
